The Acacia Ridge Technology and Information Centre, ARTIC, has been born out of a community need and a desire for local people to have access to library and information services within easy reach. Following the closure last year of the Acacia Ridge library, the community, led by Anne McNamara and Robyn Wooster, embarked on a project to establish a new library and information centre. This has now become a reality. While ARTIC is still in its infancy, this project has demonstrated what can be done through community action and determination. Many people have been involved in the development of the centre, including local representatives. ARTIC is staffed by volunteers and has gained all of its materials and resources from local donors and through the assistance of the Brisbane City Council in donating computers, bookshelves and other items.
—Order! It being 2 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 106A. The time for members' statements has concluded.
—I move:

speech.para: That this House expresses its deep regret at the death on Wednesday, 3 February 1999, of the Honourable James Francis Cope, Speaker of the House of Representatives from 1973 to 1975; Member of the House of Representatives for the Division of Sydney, New South Wales, from 1969 to 1975, for the Division of Watson, New South Wales, from 1956 to 1969 and for the Division of Cook, New South Wales, from 1955 to 1956; places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service, and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

Mr Speaker, there are probably now only three members of this House who sat in the parliament with Jim Cope: me, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and the member for Mitchell. I remember Jim Cope with a genuine personal regard. I thought he represented the very best of the traditions of his party and was a faithful reflection of the origins of the Australian Labor Party. I thought his life revealed the best of that party. He was a great advocate for the cause of working people. When he was elected Speaker he was referred to as the `battler' from Sydney who had lived in a small terrace house in a tiny street in Redfern for the previous 44 years. He always defended his Redfern origins, saying once, `I am proud to be one of them and would hazard a guess that people in more affluent areas would like to have such friends and neighbours in times of stress.'

Before entering politics, he was Federal Treasurer of the Australian Glassworkers Union from 1952 and an alderman of the Redfern Municipal Council before its amalgamation with the Sydney City Council. He did experience in his own life genuine deprivation, and this was his motivation for entering parliament. He spoke of his experiences before and during the Depression. He once said, `I remember how we looked for work—50 or 60 men lined up outside this place at Camperdown each day, like a line of cattle, waiting for a job.' When he was elected to parliament he spoke very powerfully and emotionally in his maiden speech of his working background.

He had the distinction, which a number of people have enjoyed, of being the representative of three electorates in the federal parliament. He is, of course, best known for having been the Speaker of the parliament from 1973 to 1975. The circumstances of his ceasing to be Speaker are well known and I do not intend to canvass those in any way today. The stories have been written about them and views have been formed about them. I see no particular purpose to be gained by going over those details today.

But there is one aspect of that rather dramatic day which has not been recalled in some of the stories that have been written over the past few days, and it illustrates the marvellous sense of humour that I remember Jim Cope had. As all honourable members will know, when there is a vacancy in the Speakership you have to meet and elect a new Speaker. You do not do it by a division or a show of hands; you actually write the name out. We, then being the opposition, had absolutely no chance of having our nominee elected. In the time honoured tradition, however, we nevertheless nominated the late Geoffrey O'Halloran Giles, who was then the federal Liberal member for the now abolished seat of Angus in South Australia. It was a fairly dramatic sort of day and everybody was a little bit tense. We were all gathered in that raucous. The Labor Party nominee and subsequent Speaker—and I think a very fine Speaker—Gordon Scholes was nominated by the then govern ment. Geoff Giles was nominated by the opposition. With his absolutely unmistakable voice Jim Cope pierced the silence and called out very loudly and undeniably, `How do you spell Giles?'

Given the circumstances, it illustrated the great sense of humour that he had. Of course, as a loyal Labor man he voted for Scholes. It is to his very great credit that, although he would have felt a degree of personal hurt because of those circumstances, he never publicly bore any grudges against his party.

His politics were like the politics of many people of that generation on both sides. They were moulded by the searing experiences of the Great Depression. He came to parliament with the simple desire to improve the lot of everyday working Australians. His priorities were their priorities and he spoke passionately about them in his maiden speech and during his years in parliament.

On behalf of the government I want to record my respect for Jim Cope. I remember him as a very friendly, decent man for a relatively new member of the parliament to deal with. I certainly remember those dramatic days and months of 1975—and we will be saying something in a moment about another player in the events of 1975, the late Jim McClelland. On behalf of myself, the Liberal Party and the government, I record my respect for Jim Cope. I am sad at his passing, but he lived to the great age of 91. He and his wife, Myrtle, were together for 67 years, which in anybody's language is an astonishing partnership. It was a 67-year period that embraced not only the First War but the Second War and the years of the Great Depression and the postwar revival and reconstruction of Australia.

On behalf of the government, I extend to Myrtle, their family and all of their many friends our sorrow at Jim's passing and record our respects for his contribution to his party, the Australian parliament and the Australian people.

talk.start.para: —I would like to support the remarks made by the Prime Minister, on this very sad occasion, in recognition of the long service to this parliament in Australia by Jim Cope. The Prime Minister, as he says, is one of the few members of this parliament who can remember serving with Jim Cope as a member of parliament. I as a small boy can remember being introduced to him from time to time by my father, as he was one of my father's friends in successive parliaments for a very lengthy time.

speech.para: It is a great country where it is possible for somebody who is a glassblower by trade to rise to the senior position of this chamber. Jim Cope did that. He did it in his own time. One of the things that you can note about Jim Cope is that he was never in a hurry for any particular thing that he wanted to achieve with this life. Nor did he have unrealistic expectations about what that life would produce for him or necessarily even unrealistic expectations about what government would do for the people. In fact, it was quite late in life that he came to parliament, but he served here for a very long time. Given the quiet temper of the passage of years for Jim Cope, it is quite surprising he did not make it to the next century, despite the fact that he was born in 1907.

He was a servant of this House for a long time. When he came into this parliament he was not unique, but he probably would have been almost unique in this chamber in that he believed the first thing that he ought to do was to sit down and study standing orders to make himself as knowledgeable on standing orders as he was in any aspect of political policy or in any aspect of political endeavour in general. It was a view on his part that there was an absolute obligation on members of parliament to understand the standing orders, if not necessarily to assist the Speaker to at least be able to participate in any of the discussions that went on in parliament in an orderly—if disorderly from time to time—fashion.

He became as a member of parliament an expert on standing orders and also one who added to the lightness of the place. He was a great humorist. The Prime Minister had one example of that in the remarks that he made. There were another couple of examples that my father drew to my attention. Once when the then Prime Minister, Sir Robert Menzies, was in full flight about the extent to which the Australian people loved him, he regaled the parliament with a story of a truck driver moving alongside him at the traffic lights, leaning out of the cabin and shouting to the Prime Minister, `Good on you, Bob. You're doing a terrific job.' In the midst of the quiet titters of recognition from at least the government side at that stage, Jim's distinctive voice could be heard coming out with, `And did they pinch him for drunken driving?'

On another occasion, and I do not think it would be appropriate to go through the full extent of this particular story, there was a debate in this chamber at one time about three locations for where we are now and one member of parliament had failed to obtain Mr Speaker's attention, despite repeated efforts to get on his scrapers to opine his views. On the way out of the chamber, the Speaker drew attention to the fact that he was exiting in a huff in a slightly disorderly manner, at which point he turned and said to the Speaker precisely where he ought to place his particular call. Instantly, Jim Cope jumped up and said, `I think we have a fourth site.' It is indeed fortunate that site was not chosen and this one was. That site, however, was a mobile site and was unlikely to be.

He was a man who had a great sense of humour but also had a great sense of honour. He had a great sense of the role of Speaker. The Prime Minister did not allude to the circumstances of his termination but I will. He was wrongly treated. There is no question in my mind that that was the case. He was wrongly treated.

talk.start.para: —Your father said that too.

—My father was one of a number of Labor members who absented themselves from the vote when that occurred. From time to time it may be necessary to remove a Speaker; that was not the way for a Speaker to be removed. But he bore no bitterness for it. He had no rancour at all and was enormously supportive of the subsequent Labor Speaker, Gordon Scholes, who also joined my father in exiting the chamber at that point. So he was a man without rancour, a man of very great decency and a man of great humour.

speech.para: He was an example of a style of Australian who, I suppose, to some degree is disappearing certainly from public life and perhaps from Australian life—a person who was essentially self-educated but with an absolute determination to know as much as he could to do his fellow man and woman in Australia as much good as he conceivably could in this place.

He was not in any sense a careerist. He was a person who took the view that he was he here for a purpose and that he would perform that purpose and conduct his activities as effectively as he could. He was an ordinary bloke. One of the things he did on coming to office was to continue a habit of Labor speakers prior to that of dispensing with the gown and wig and, given the lengthy period of time that there had been between Labor speakers, that appeared to be something of an innovation at the time.

I could be wrong about this but I think he was the first Speaker appointed by Labor in the postwar era—I think it was a continuing Speaker after World War II—so he would have been the first to actually obtain that office when he did, and it was a very long time between drinks as far as Labor Speakers were concerned. He brought great credit to that office. He brought great credit to this parliament. Our condolences go to his family, of whom he was a loving and proud head.

talk.start.para: —I would like to build on the remarks of the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition and particularly refer to that day in 1975. In support of what the Leader of the Opposition has said, it was good to see Clyde Cameron reiterate the apology he subsequently tendered to former Speaker Cope in respect of his conduct on that particular day. In fact, history records that there were four people who absented themselves from the Labor government on the subsequent division when the member for New England, then Leader of Opposition Business, moved for the suspension of Mr Cameron. I learned today, inter alia, that one of those was Mr Beazley Sr.

speech.para: These were momentous times in the history of Australian politics. That was at the start of 1975, and it was an intense period of activity in the federal parliament. Two days before, the former federal Leader of the National Party, Doug Anthony, had been suspended and there was a further set of altercations. There was some brilliant thinking by Mr Sinclair at the time in moving that motion in support of the Speaker's position. Of course, the motion was defeated and the Speaker tendered his resignation. It was a class act and a courageous act. It was the best of the Westminster tradition a la the Australian parliament's interpretation thereof. In saluting the life and times and work of former Speaker Cope, I particularly salute his stepping out of the Speaker's chair in the circumstances, very difficult as they were, immediately following that particular incident and the non-carriage of that particular motion.
I single out in his maiden speech his strong link with wide groupings of workers, including the Glassworkers Union and also the pensioners. I will quote briefly. He said:
Recently the Treasurer (Sir Arthur Fadden) announced a surplus of more than £70,000,000 for the financial year 1954-55.
He went on to argue that that surplus should be used variously, and said:

It is a responsibility of this Government or, for that matter, of any government, to see that age and invalid pensioners are decently housed and fed in keeping with Australian standards of living. Those people are the pioneers of this country. They built it to what it is to-day. I remind honorable members that the vast majority of them had to raise their families without the assistance of child endowment payments, and in so doing they nullified their prospects of saving for their years of retirement.

Those are very interesting words uttered in 1955 by the member who subsequently became the member for Sydney. He gave great service to his beloved Labor Party but also to the state and to the nation, especially in his role for that critical period as Speaker of the House. On behalf of the National Party, I extend sympathy to members of the Cope family.

talk.start.para: —I join with the Prime Minister, Leader of the Opposition and Deputy Prime Minister in expressing my condolences and joining in this motion on the passing of Jim Cope. I, like the Leader of the Opposition, knew Jim Cope not as a parliamentarian but as a regular visitor here as part of family visits. Jim Cope was one of those people who in many ways instilled into me the importance of the parliament and subsequently the role of the Speaker and, significantly, the importance of the standing orders. Whether it was a brilliant tactic by the member for New England, I think all of us who have studied the standing orders would have moved precisely that way—including Jim Cope, had he been in that position. But I join with the Leader of the Opposition in saying that there were many on our side of the parliament who thought that Jim Cope in those circumstances had been harshly dealt with.

speech.para: Whilst reference has been made to the fact that he was a glassworker and a trade unionist, it is also true to say that before he came to parliament Jim Cope experienced several years of unemployment, and that experience shaped him as a staunch defender of lower income and unemployed people throughout his parliamentary career. In his first speech in the House he gave a glimpse of that. He said:

I have been through the mill. I know what it is to go without a meal . . . But I doubt very much whether the Prime Minister or the Treasurer would know what it is to go without a meal. It is only by seeing these people, it is only by "going through the mill" that one can speak with sincerity on these matters.

In his first speech he also advocated the need for government to care more for aged and invalid pensioners. In a statement of renewed significance in the current debate over the GST, he noted very forcefully that the high prices of food `do not affect the tables of the rich; but they place pensioners in the semi-starvation class'.

Reference has been made to the dry wit of Jim Cope in the anecdote that Kim Beazley told. I think it is also important to place on record that he was a very dedicated local member of parliament. He believed in the importance of representation and of constituency. Whilst he did rise to the significant position of Speaker of the House, he never forgot the roots from which he came. I think it is a testament to this democracy and this institution that someone of Jim Cope's background could rise to become Speaker of the parliament. He served the parliament and he served the people of his electorate with great distinction. I join in expressing my condolences to his wife of 67 years, Myrtle, to their daughter, Bonnie, and to their family and friends.

talk.start.para: —I seek the indulgence of the House. As the person currently honoured to occupy the position of Speaker of the House of Representatives, I would like to say a few words about my distinguished predecessor, the late James Francis Cope. As we have heard this afternoon, he was clearly a man committed to the principles of the party he served so well, to the parliament he loved and to the people he represented. Those of us who did not know Mr Cope personally have had portrayed for us in this condolence motion a man with a sense of humour and a sense of justice and a man whose disposition did this office honour. I extend my condolences to his family, and thank them for his service to the nation.

speech.para: Debate (on motion by Mr Reith) adjourned.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That this House expresses its deep regret at the death on Saturday, 16 January 1999, of the Honourable James Robert McClelland, Chairman of the Royal Commission into British Nuclear Weapons Tests in Australia from 1984 to 1985; Chief Justice of the Land and Environment Court of New South Wales from 1980 to 1985; Judge of the New South Wales Industrial Court from 1978 to 1980; Minister for Labour and Immigration and Minister assisting the Prime Minister in matters relating to the Public Service from June until November 1975; Minister for Manufacturing Industry from February until June 1975; and Senator for New South Wales from 1971 until 1978; places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service, and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

It is ironic that, on this very first day that parliament has resumed, we should be involved in condolence motions concerning two people who were very heavily and directly involved in the very active and dramatic political events of 1975.

Jim McClelland, I know, would want to be remembered for many things, but he would not want to be remembered as somebody who indulged in humbug or hypocritical utterances when it came to people in public life or people in political positions. It is indeed interesting, when one thinks of the character, the attitudes and the disposition of Jim Cope and Jim McClelland, how very different they were as people. They may have had some origins in common, but in style, demeanour, attitude and deportment I cannot think of two people in the Australian Labor Party, or indeed in any political party, more dramatical ly different than the late Jim Cope and the late Jim McClelland.

Jim McClelland was a great hater. He was a passionate believer in the things that he supported and he was a passionate and vitriolic opponent and critic of any philosophy or person with whom he disagreed. I read his column in the Sydney Morning Herald from time to time. He was absolutely consistent in his unrelenting criticism of the Liberal Party, of me and of just about all of the positions that I held in political life. Let me say that the compliment, whilst he was alive, was robustly returned. Jim was not a person whose views I shared on just about anything, and I make no bones about it. I do not think—and I know he does not think for a moment that he is listening to me—he would respect me for saying otherwise or pretending otherwise.

He was, of course, somebody who had a very long association with some of the most vigorous and significant battles within the trade union movement of Australia, such as his fights with the Stalinists within the Federated Iron Workers Association. His animosity for many years with the late B.A. Santamaria after the Labor Party split of 1955 was I think marvellously reconciled in life, you might say, in that very interesting interview both of them conducted on Lateline a couple of years ago.

The most legendary of his hostilities was his bitterness towards his former ally in trade union fights, the last Sir John Kerr. That has been very heavily rehearsed over the years. I simply record for the House a personal exchange that took place between me, Jim McClelland and Bob Ellicott, the former Liberal member for Wentworth and Attorney-General in the Fraser government, on the night of 11 November in King's Hall in the old Parliament House. The passion and the character of the exchange indicated the depth of feeling that he had on that particular issue.

He fell out with his long-time friend Neville Wran, even though Neville had appointed him to the Land and Environment Court. Not wanting us to think we were alone, he expressed great disappointment in Bob Hawke and his government. He held very passionately to his abandonment of Catholicism and his embrace of atheism. He was a person who believed very strongly in the role of the arts within the Australian community. I think it is fair to say that even his fiercest critics would acknowledge the contribution he made in the years since he left politics towards assisting the arts, particularly in Sydney.

Jim McClelland was born in Richmond, Victoria, on 3 June 1915, the son of a painter employed by the Victorian railways. He was a conscientious student and he earned scholarships to study at St Kevin's College with the Christian Brothers and, later, at Melbourne University. He completed a Bachelor of Arts degree while being active in the Melbourne University Labor Club and working as a builder's labourer and, later, as an ironworker. He served Australia during World War II, from 1943, in the Royal Australian Air Force as a radio operator. After he was discharged from the Air Force in 1946 he completed a law degree at Sydney University.

I first met Jim McClelland not in parliament but in 1966 at a hearing of appeals into a redistribution of electoral boundaries in New South Wales, presided over by a late judge and two other members. Jim McClelland was representing the New South Wales branch of the Labor Party and he was instructing an up-and-coming QC by the name of N.K. Wran. I was representing the New South Wales division of the Liberal Party. I had the opportunity, during a period of about 10 days, of exchanging political ideas and arguments about the rightness and wrongness of electoral boundaries and how outrageous it was that lines should be drawn in particular areas. I saw a person who was very meticulous and very committed to his client and the Labor Party cause.

Jim McClelland played a very significant role in two very important policy issues: the introduction of FM radio and Lionel Murphy's Family Law Bill, of which he was a passionate supporter. I might say that I voted against a lot of that too in 1975. The support that Lionel Murphy and Jim McClelland gave to the Family Law Bill invoked enormous and passionate opposition from within the Australian Labor Party. It was one of the few issues that I can remember in 25 years on which the Labor Party was allowed a completely free vote on an issue of great significance. Being liberated from the caucus constraint, I can assure you that many of the opponents of Murphy and McClelland gave very strong vent to their feelings.

He was a significant figure within the Labor Party. As I said earlier, on many subjects he held views that I totally disagreed with, but I respected the passion with which he held those views. I thought he had a very interesting and productive post-political life serving as a judge, as a royal commissioner, as a part-time columnist and as somebody who involved himself very heavily in the art scene in New South Wales, particularly in Sydney.
On behalf of the government I extend to his wife Gillian and his family our very sincere sympathy on the loss of Jim McClelland.

talk.start.para: —I would like to add my remarks in support of the condolence motion moved by the Prime Minister for the late Hon. Jim McClelland. It is sometimes said that, in a very long life, at the end of the day all your enemies become your friends. In the case of Jim McClelland's very long life, many did not quite make it. As the Prime Minister said, Jim was a man of great passion, and many of us annoyed him. The Prime Minister did not feel particularly upset about the fact that he was from time to time—or I should say quite frequently—the butt of his columns.
—Persistently.

—Persistently the butt of his columns. I have to inform the Prime Minister—as I am sure he is aware, because I suspect that is why he read them—that we on this side of the House were almost as frequently and persistently attacked in the same columns.

speech.para: But we have to say that, whether we were attacked or not, never for one instance did those columns lack erudition or elegance. He was a very good writer. His works are collected in his autobiography Stirring the Possum, a collection of essays An Angel Bit the Bride, and a collection of journalism Conversations in Cabs. For those who want to collect or read them it was the Sydney Morning Herald that ran his regular column.

He was educated at St Kevin's College and then Melbourne University. He worked as a builders labourer and ironworker, and served in the RAAF in a radar unit in New Guinea. He completed a law degree at the University of Sydney and became an industrial solicitor. It was at that point that he engaged most heavily in the political debates of this nation.

Firstly he engaged them as a passionate Trotskyite in support of a removal of the communist leadership of the ironworkers at the time. As his position shifted rightwards towards the centre he became actively involved in Laurie Short's campaigns to turn over the leadership of the ironworkers. It was during those activities that he briefed John Kerr in the case which ultimately enabled Laurie Short to win control of that operation.

Though these are now in dim, dark memory for most Australians, the struggles between those who were devotees of the communist cause, neutral in it, regarded it as irrelevant or were passionately anti-communist were the defining debates of the nation. Jim McClelland cut his political teeth in hard ideological discourse, in hard political argument. There was nothing sloppy and sentimental about the debates in which the found himself engaged, and he carried that forensic skill and that discipline of mind into subsequent careers in politics and also in the ministry.

He served only briefly in the Whitlam ministry between 1972 and 1975, though he held two important portfolios in the short time that he was in that ministry. When he was added to the ministry, he was seen as giving that ministry a bit of new life, as giving it a bit of forensic skill, a bit of toughness of mind, as he operated in the Senate chamber at the time. He was a skilled debater and a skilled partisan.

When he left politics—and left it probably with more bitterness and rancour then most, understandable bitterness and rancour, particularly directed at the then Governor-General—he continued a career of public service, as the Prime Minister has indicated, as a judge of the New South Wales Industrial Commission and Chief Judge of the New South Wales Land and Environment Court. Subsequently for the Labor government of Bob Hawke he was the royal commissioner into nuclear testing in Australia. We were confident, when we appointed Jim McClelland as the royal commissioner to examine the issue of nuclear testing, that he would approach it without any particular sentimental regard for the circumstances which may have seen those tests take place in the first instance and that he would bring to it a hard-nosed view about where liabilities lay and what ought to be done. And we were not disappointed in the results that he came up with.

In old-fashioned terms he would be known as a controversialist. He was a person who never saw a fight that he did not want to be in, and always found himself an opportunity to engage. His views were manifold on many subjects. He was also distinctly of the view that there was no virtue at all in not pursuing a cultural interest and using the offices that he held or using the power of government to advance the culture of the nation. He had a very distinct view about the role of arts in the community and, in his latter years, it was his activities in that regard that probably gave him most joy from life. We on this side of the House join the Prime Minister in extending our condolences to Jim McClelland's family. A real character has passed from our midst.

talk.start.para: —I wish to add to the comments of the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition regarding Diamond Jim McClelland. I have to confess that I once voted for Jim McClelland to enter the Senate.
—Oh?
—Let me explain, Prime Minister.
—You had better.

—The occasion was somewhere between the ides of March and Saint Patrick's Day 1971. The location was the Legislative Council of the New South Wales parliament. The nomination was on the behest of the then Premier of New South Wales, Sir Robert Askin, and it was to fill a vacancy that had been created by the death of Senator Ormonde. For a few months Senator McClelland filled out that part of the term and he then took his seat in his own right, having been elected for a term commencing 1 July 1971. It was a unanimous vote on that occasion in that hallowed first chamber of parliaments in this country.

speech.para: One thing that Jim McClelland made clear was that he hated political waffle and political cant. His `stirring the possum' approach to life, as manifested by his autobiography, is I think a good challenge to all of us. It was to not be driven by the paradigms of the day but to push the envelope, to head down a path of particular belief, to make his stand—in that regard, he was on the opposite side of politics from the Liberal and National parties—and to provide intellectual rigour in respect of that stand. That flowed through from his days as a senator and a minister to heading up the New South Wales Land and Environment Court during particularly turbulent times with regard to the design and high rise dimensions associated with the city of Sydney.

I also salute his RAAF service during World War II in Papua New Guinea. I guess as time passes there will not be too many more motions referring to those who served in World War II, but we should never forget that they gave service at an extraordinarily difficult time in the history of this country, at the height of World War II, in one of the theatres of war which meant so much directly to the freedom of this country, and to the non-occupation of this country by enemy forces, most notably the Axis and Japanese forces who came so close—indeed, as close as Papua New Guinea. He was one of so many who made a very big contribution of courage, dedication and determination in those circumstances as a member of the Royal Australian Air Force.

One thing he might have shared in common with the Prime Minister was an abiding interest in cricket. I did meet him after a test at the SCG one very hot Sydney day. In fact, we had a drink together in that little pub just outside the Paddington gate to the SCG back in the late 1970s.
I acknowledge the contribution he made to the Australian parliament, to the state of New South Wales and to the nation. I extend sympathy to members of the McClelland family.

talk.start.para: —I join in recognising the distinguished career of Jim McClelland, not only as a politician but also as a lawyer, a judge, a royal commissioner, a journalist and an all-round activist. I came to know Jim over many years, firstly when he assumed both of the ministerial positions that have been referred to and when I was just embarking on a career as a research officer with the then Storemen and Packers Union.

speech.para: Reference has been made to the fact that Jim was born in Richmond. He asked for a meeting to be convened of unions involved in the manufacturing sector because he wanted to talk about this new notion of job enrichment and I think half the audience thought he was talking about getting jobs back in Richmond. They were scratching their heads because all of these places had been closed down.

There was also Jim's involvement with the trade union movement in trying to then convince them of the need for wage restraint. He believed he had this wonderfully articulated case, as only he could put it. The story, which I saw referred to again by John Button in his piece, was that when he was asked by John Button how he went, he said, `I was cut to pieces by Norm Gallagher.' John Button said, `What do you mean?' Jim said Norm just looked at him with those dreary eyes and said, `That's a wonderful story, Jim. I think I'll tell it to me mother.' This sunk the whole push for wage restraint back in 1975.

I had occasion as well to draw on not only the findings but to get the advice of Jim in relation to the compensation for the victims of the British nuclear tests at Maralinga when, together with Gareth Evans, I was responsible for negotiating the settlement with the UK government.

Jim McClelland was a colourful character. You could not help but be affected by his style. He was a true wordsmith and he had great style. Whether or not you agreed with him, I think it is a great craft to be able to articulate and write as well as he did, and I think there are important lessons there.

He was a great friend of Lionel Murphy. Indeed, it was Lionel Murphy's position in the cabinet that Jim filled when Lionel was appointed to the High Court. Theirs was a friendship that went back over many years. He served with distinction in the ministry, although for a short period of time. He resigned from the Senate on 21 July 1978. He continued to express his views in the way that only he could. There were many quotes attributed to Jim McClelland, but the one which I identified with most was his saying, `You've got to have a go, don't you.' In many senses, Jim had many goes. The Australian nation is richer for it and the labour movement has certainly benefited from it.
Debate (on motion by Mr Reith) adjourned.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That this House expresses its deep regret at the death on Friday, 5 February 1999, of Neville Thomas Bonner, AO, Senator for the State of Queensland from 1971 to 1983; places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service, and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

Neville Thomas Bonner was born on 28 March 1922 on Ukerebagh Island, in the mouth of the Tweed River, in New South Wales. He was born under a tree as his mother, being Aboriginal, had to be out of the town before sunset and could not return until sunrise the next day. He never knew his father, an Englishman, who, although married to his mother, returned to England before he was born. Orphaned at the age of nine, Neville was raised by his grandmother in what he referred to as `a blacks' camp under lantana bushes'.

Neville first worked as a dairy hand, stockman and carpenter, mainly in the western part of Queensland. A Jagera elder, he was devoted to Australia and to the cause of the indigenous people. As is very well known, Neville Bonner was the first indigenous person to be elected to the national parliament and, until 1 July this year, the only indigenous person to have served in the national parliament. He was a Liberal Party senator for the state of Queensland between 1971 and 1983. He was elected on three occasions and, being the first indigenous person to serve in the national parliament, he was of course something of a role model to many Australians. He did not see his role as only representing the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of this country, although he was very conscious of the responsibility he carried as the first indigenous person to come into the national parliament.

I served with Neville Bonner between 1974 and 1983. I found him, without exception, to be a person who took his representative obligations to the whole of the people of Queensland very seriously. He would always defend and promote an indigenous point of view. He would always remind us, who were less conscious of the experience of the indigenous people, of what was expected of us, but he would never seek to set the indigenous people of Australia apart from the rest of their fellow Australians.

He argued long and hard with many other indigenous leaders. They often criticised him; they often questioned his loyalty to his chosen political party. He always managed, I think quite remarkably, to achieve a balance. It was a source of disappointment to me, and I know to many other people, that he did not secure a winnable position on the Liberal Party Senate ticket for the 1983 election. But it was not the first time, nor will it be the last time, that a political organisation has made an error in relation to preselection. The Liberal Party is no exception, nor is it the only offender.

He ran as an Independent in the 1983 election but did not secure re-election; over the years he put that behind him. One of the more emotional moments I have had as Prime Minister was to confer upon him at the national convention of the Liberal Party in Queensland last year life membership of the Queensland division of the Liberal Party, an honour that he accepted very warmly. I know from the reaction of those present at that gathering that it was seen very much as a public reconciliation between our party and Neville Bonner.

Neville had a great sense of humour and he had tremendous courage. I was very privileged to visit him at the Ipswich hospice just over a week ago and to spend an hour with him, his wife, Heather, and a number of members of their family. We talked about the politics we had shared together. We talked about current issues. He gave me some lively, humorous advice about politics. He did not seek to hector; he did not seek to indulge in any recriminations. He was happy to see me as a friend and former colleague. He was very appreciative of all the people from all political persuasions who had been to see him in the time he had been ill.

He was diagnosed with cancer more than a year ago, and those of us who attended the constitutional convention will remember the passion of his address. We marvelled at the strength that he displayed, despite his great illness. He, along with George Mai, demonstrated the diversity of views in all sections of the Australian community on the issue of our constitutional future. He opted very passionately for a rejection of an Australian republic.

Neville was, I think, very deeply loved and respected throughout the entire Australian community. I do not want anybody to misunderstand how I put this, but I think he made a lot of Australians, whatever their views are in relation to indigenous issues, whatever stance they may take and whatever response they might want to give in relation to the undoubted disadvantage of indigenous people within our community, feel that something had been achieved when he became elected in his own right as a senator for all of the people of Queensland.

He conducted himself with immense dignity. Perhaps his greatest and most dignified achievement was that he did not seek, to my knowledge, to in any way exaggerate the reasons behind his not being placed in such an advantaged position on his party's Senate ticket in 1983. The way in which he was willing to retain an association with so many of his colleagues and proudly proclaim to the rest of the world that he was a Liberal, I think, brought great credit upon him.

I want to say that I was very touched by his courage. He suffered a great deal of family sadness in his later years. His wife, Heather, was a magnificent support to him throughout their 27 years of married life. She displayed wonderful spirit, compas sion and understanding in the final moments of his life.

He was a very special Australian to have overcome those difficulties. Today we have spoken of the difficult early life of somebody like Jim Cope, and that was undoubted. On both sides of parliament some of us are born in more fortunate circumstances; some of us are born in less fortunate circumstances. I do not think there is any doubt that, if you are an indigenous person of Neville Bonner's age, you were born in very difficult circumstances. Of that there can be no argument. He overcame those difficult circumstances. He progressed to what I still regard, and I believe all of us regard, as a very wonderful thing, and that is to be a representative of the people of Australia in the national parliament. He did it in a way that brought great credit to his Aboriginal origins. He did it in a way that brought great credit to him as a man and as a contributor to the Australian community.

I want to quote one thing that he said in his maiden speech. It summed up his attitude towards indigenous issues and what he saw as his role as the first indigenous person to sit as an elected person in the Australian parliament. He said:

Aborigines of Australia are most certainly not looking for handouts. They have suffered enough from the stigma of paternalism however well-intentioned it may have been. I am sure that they will respond to efforts being made to enhance their self-esteem, particularly through the programs of social development and vocational and general education.

Those words were spoken in 1971. They have a timeless relevance and a timeless quality about them. I think they speak volumes for somebody who spoke as an Aborigine for the Aboriginal people of Australia and also as a member of the great Australian family which he distinguished.

On behalf of the government, the Liberal Party and the wider Liberal Party organisation, I thank Neville Bonner for what he represented. I thank him for his contribution to Australian public life. He lived a very full life. He displayed character, he displayed courage and he displayed immense personal decency. As I said earlier, I felt it a privilege to have spent time with him so shortly before his death. To Heather and their children, I extend our love and our sympathy. As I have already announced, Neville Bonner will be honoured with a state funeral, which I think will be taking place in Ipswich on Friday of this week.

talk.start.para: —Again I rise to support the remarks of the Prime Minister, on this occasion on a motion of condolence in honour of Neville Bonner, Jagera elder, former Liberal senator, who died on Friday, 5 February.

speech.para: Along with the Prime Minister and I think many other members of this House, we were deeply moved last year by the contribution that Neville Bonner made to the Constitutional Convention. If ever there was any doubt about the deep spirituality of the man, his deep conception of the land and his relationship to it and his feeling for the life of the nation, you would have had all those doubts removed, even if you did not necessarily agree with the conclusion, in listening to his remarks at that convention. You could have heard a pin drop as he spoke, because everybody really understood where he came from, what sort of person he represented and the sort of trial and tribulation in the record of his people he represented and had infused in his own personality.

There is no person who has come to this chamber who has lived as hard a youth as Neville Bonner—none. Not a single member of parliament since 1901 has had the tough life, the tough experiences of Neville Bonner prior to entering this place. He has that status basically because of the fact that he has been the only Aboriginal member of this parliament. Therefore, he carried through his life the events that have scoured the soul of our indigenous inhabitants in often the most appalling of ways, as we have from time to time come to learn by reports which have been made to this chamber.

The circumstances of his birth began that life—the exclusion from the boundaries of the town so that he was obliged to be born under a tree. There is no Australian who has experienced that start to life who has ever served in this chamber. He experienced all the deprivation and discrimination of an Aboriginal person growing up in Australia in the 1920s and 1930s. His early jobs were those of a dairy hand, stockman and carpenter. He joined the Liberal Party in Queensland in 1967. He was appointed to fill a Senate vacancy and served for the next 12 years. The Prime Minister has already referred to the circumstances of his dropping to an unwinnable position on the Liberal Party Senate ticket. He darn near got back here in the subsequent election. He just missed out when he ran as an Independent. That emphasises the fact that he had found his way into the hearts of a lot of his fellow Queenslanders, probably precisely because of the sorts of attributes of his personality that the Prime Minister described. He had an inclusive view of all of us.

It also ought to be said that one of the reasons why he experienced that level of political difficulty is that, despite the fact that criticism was offered of him by some of his fellow Aboriginals at the time he stood in the Liberal interests back in 1971, he did not take a backward step in his defence of the needs and concerns of the Aboriginal community in Australia. He did not take a backward step, be it in land rights, be it in the concerns in the community for Aboriginal health and education, be it in the need for the Aboriginal community to find opportunities to advance themselves politically. Not an excuse, not a backward step. He expressed himself vigorously and repeatedly on those matters in the Senate and attached to that vigour his vote from time to time when those were issues in the Senate. He was true to everything in the way in which he conducted himself in his public life.

His public life did not end with his defeat in the Senate election. He was appointed by the Hawke government in 1983 to the board of the ABC, and he served until 1991. He served on the council of Griffith University from 1992 to 1996 and was the senior official visitor to Queensland prisons from 1990 to 1997. He never let go of that requirement he saw upon himself to look after and to advance the cause of the needy, underprivileged and oppressed in our community. He lived a full public life until his final days.

Last year, in an historic first he was invited by the Premier of Queensland, Peter Beattie, to address the opening of the state parliament as a Jagera elder, because the Jagera people are the traditional owners of the land on which Brisbane's Parliament House is built. Just a few weeks ago, the Queensland state government honoured him by having a government building named after him.

If you look at the record of his public life from 1967 onwards, you can see that he did, in a bipartisan way, find his way into the hearts of all of us in Australian political life. He had a view that all Australians needed to be advanced as a people. He had a the view that the Aboriginal community was part of a broader Australian community. Having said that, I add that he never lost his aboriginality, and he never lost the respect of or concern for his tribal circumstances. He never lost the sense of obligation that he had a first and prior duty to deal with the sorts of problems which gave him such an exceptionally hard life in his youth. We in the opposition join the Prime Minister and the members of the government in extending our sincerest condolences to his family.

talk.start.para: —As Leader of the National Party, I am honoured to speak on this condolence motion about a truly great Australian. Neville Bonner was a trailblazer whose contribution to Australian political life was unique and extraordinary.

speech.para: The former stockman and carpenter became Australia's first Aboriginal senator in 1971, as the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition pointed out. He served through a change of government in 1975 with people like Cleaver Bunton from Albury, whom we will honour shortly and who also passed away during the summer recess. He went on to serve and help bridge division, often in the face of criticism even from his own people. He was an Australian who was fiercely proud of his aboriginality. We did see that during the Constitutional Convention held in the Old Parliament House about this time last year.

I would like to add to the comments of the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition by quoting a brief part from that remarkable and humbling address to delegates, which concluded with his singing an Aboriginal chant. In that address, he said:

From the bottom of my heart, I pray to you: stop this senseless division. Let us work together on the real issues. Let us solve those problems which haunt my people—the problems of land, of health, of unemployment, of the despair and hopelessness which leads even to suicide. Let us unite this country, not divide it ever—that toy of those who already have too much: mere symbolism.
That was followed by another delegate well known in this House, Sir James Killen, who described himself as `a former jackaroo from the outer Barcoo'. In response, Jim Killen said of Neville Bonner:
He said he was not a rich man. For myself, I take the view it is not what a man or woman has in his or her house that counts; it is what the man or woman has in his or her heart that counts.

Indeed, that giant-hearted Neville Bonner contributed so much to the richness of the Australian way of life and the Australian democracy with its diversity of participants. Long may that diversity be maintained. I extend sympathy to his wife Heather and to members of the Bonner family.

I will close by reflecting that the work of Neville Bonner has not been in vain. A manifestation of that work is in Warburton in the centre of Western Australia. In the second week of January, Minister John Herron and Parliamentary Secretary Grant Tambling and I visited Warburton, which is one of those very isolated communities west of Ayers Rock, just across the Western Australian border. Warburton is an Aboriginal community which has elected to be a dry community. It is an Aboriginal community which has elected to proceed with a particular dental and health program, which is making real progress. It is an Aboriginal community which has, by its own effort, provided a swimming pool that helps to bind that community together. More recently, with some assistance, it has provided a set of sealed roads. It has developed a commercial Aboriginal art product—through its glass work—which I am sure former speaker Jim Cope would have been proud of. It is one of the most extraordinary, attractive and valuable products I have ever seen in my rounds of outback Australia. In the community of Warburton—wonderful Warburton which works so well—there is so much that Neville Bonner and his descendants can be very, very proud of, because that is what he was striving for and that, bit by bit, is what is being achieved.

It has been a privilege to know Neville Bonner, albeit only briefly. To have been in Brisbane to see him receive life membership of the Liberal Party was a very moving moment. He can walk tall. All of us who knew him have been enhanced by knowing that great former senator and great Australian.

talk.start.para: —Neville Bonner was a distinguished and dignified Australian. He was as much a representative in the Australian parliament of the Aboriginal people as he was of the Liberal Party. He was a person who sought bipartisan support in addressing the problems of Aboriginal people. He was a person who did much to lay the basis for a just reconciliation with them.

speech.para: It has been mentioned that he was the first Aboriginal to sit in the federal parliament. I think it is worth while reflecting the disappointment that more have not followed in his footsteps. But he did know and he did understand the myriad of challenges that had to be surmounted by the Aboriginal people in the modern Australian context, and he devoted much of his time to facing those challenges. He was also a dedicated senator for his home state of Queensland. He said, `As a senator, my responsibility was to the people of Queensland . . . Interwoven with that was my love of my race and my all-consuming desire to help my own people . . . But my responsibility was for the whole of Queensland.'

He was a statesman in the fullest sense of the word—both for Queensland and for Aboriginal people. He experienced first-hand the discrimination faced by Aborigines across Australia every day, but he rose above it, becoming a champion for them and showing many non-indigenous people that to hold fast to your convictions, to advocate your beliefs with passion and to stare injustice down are the only ways to fight for a cause.

Neville Bonner was a leader in the quest for equality amongst indigenous and non-indigenous Australians. It is the duty of this parliament, and of all the people we represent, to ensure that Neville Bonner's name is long remembered as that quest continues.
Debate (on motion by Mr Reith) adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: His Majesty King Hussein bin Talal of Jordan

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That this House records its deep regret at the death on Sunday, 7 February 1999 of His Majesty King Hussein bin Talal of Jordan, and expresses its deep sympathy to Queen Noor and their family and to the people of Jordan in their bereavement and requests that this motion be conveyed by the Speaker on behalf of the Australian Parliament to the Government of Jordan.

The death yesterday of King Hussein came after a very long struggle against cancer. Although there is a vast distance between Jordan and Australia, and although our bilateral relations with a number of other countries in the Middle East are perhaps deeper and more intricate, that does not diminish the very considerable respect that all of us who have studied the affairs of the Middle East feel towards the late king and the regard in which he is rightly held throughout the world for the contribution he has made to the peace process involving Israel and the Arab states.

I have sent a message expressing condolence on behalf of the people and the government. Many Australians will remember King Hussein's visit to Australia in 1976. He led his country for almost half a century, during particularly turbulent times. When he was a teenager he witnessed the assassination of his grandfather, and he himself subsequently survived many challenges, including coup and assassination attempts. In a volatile region with many Arab leaders resenting his pro-Western policies, and faced with complex pressures created by a large refugee population, he worked very hard to put his poor and new state on a more secure and prosperous footing.

I think it is fair to say that he enjoyed very widespread and genuine support from the people of Jordan. He certainly played a role in the governance of that country not normally assumed by monarchs in the modern world. The fact that he was able to do it with growing public support and public esteem was a demonstration of his innate understanding of the needs of his people.

In 1994, King Hussein became only the second Arab leader to formalise a peace treaty with Israel. After that, he dedicated himself to the Middle East peace process which had grown out of the 1991 conference in Madrid. All of us will remember the great courage he demonstrated last year when, despite the obvious ravages of cancer, he responded to calls from President Clinton to help hasten the effective conclusion of the peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians at the Wye River summit. The images of his involvement in that are some of the most evocative of recent years.

His death is a significant loss to his own country and to the region, and anyone who has been closely following the events of the Middle East will recognise that. His successor, his son King Abdullah, inherits a very proud and substantial legacy. I convey to him the best wishes of the Australian people and a profound expression of hope that he will continue his father's good efforts to maintain and promote a greater level of peace and understanding in the Middle East.

The late King Hussein led his country through an extraordinary period in the history of the Middle East. Unlike others who have led governments in the Middle East, he leaves behind a positive legacy. He took risks for peace, he was willing to reconcile old enemies, he was willing to put old hatreds behind him, and he deserves our credit and our respect for that.

talk.start.para: —I join the Prime Minister in extending condolences to the family of King Hussein and the people of Jordan on the death of King Hussein.

speech.para: None of us who have watched television news services over the last couple of days can fail to be impressed with the genuine expres sions of grief and sorrow from the subjects of King Hussein that have been evident on the streets of Amman and elsewhere in Jordan. There has been an extraordinary outpouring of love and affection for their dying monarch from all elements of the Jordanian community. Nor can we fail to be impressed by the remarks that have come from a multiplicity of world leaders about the stands that he has taken in international affairs and how critical he was in dealing with one of the most—if not the most—substantial international problems of our times.

There is no question at all that the passing of King Hussein leaves a critical hole in the diplomacy of Middle East peace. So genuinely trusted did King Hussein become that the supporters of the Palestinian cause, the broader Arab community, the people of Israel and external powers like the United States are interlocutors from time to time with the peace process in that part of the Middle East.

In the capitals concerned with a decent and long-lasting outcome, there will be more than a little fear over the consequences of the passing of the king. We should not underestimate the significance of this man. You cannot underestimate it when you see the role he played only a few months ago, off his sickbed, to keep the peace process going. There is a profound view in the United States and elsewhere that without his intervention it will be very difficult to keep this difficult process on track. That King Hussein should have reached this position is really quite extraordinary. When you look at his background and at what he has had to fight against, you form an impression of what an extraordinary man he must have been.

As the Prime Minister said, he came to power after the assassination of his grandfather and the abdication of his father. Few gave much chance to an 18-year-old monarch of a tiny kingdom—then known as Trans-Jordan—which was the arbitrary creation of imperial cartographers, wedged between Israel on one side and powerful Arab neighbours on the other side. He came to know a great deal of adversity as he cemented his authority. His reign was punctuated by war and political turmoil. He survived numerous assassination and coup attempts. He survived repeated loss of territory during conflicts which occurred in the course of his reign and, after the events of the Six-Day War, he only narrowly prevailed in a bloody struggle with the PLO for control of his own capital.

As folk now look at the role that he played, with forces that not only were hostile to him but were seeking his reign and his life in the course of his history, they will get the impression of what an extraordinary survivor he was and what an extraordinary contributor he has been both to his own country and to the wider interests of peace in the Middle East.

He was a passionate nationalist. Despite the situation in which he found himself with very shaky rule, at a very young age he insisted upon the standing down of his senior British military adviser, Sir John Glubb—a move which at the time appeared to put at risk the relationship of one of the protectors of Trans-Jordan in the Middle East at that point. He took risks for his authority. Then he took risks for peace. In 1988 he opened up secret negotiations with the Israelis, and he forswore any claims on the West Bank in 1989. Largely because of the way in which he conducted himself, his country has always been perceived as something of a linchpin for an ultimate settlement, an ultimate peace, in the region.

There is now an enormous challenge before King Abdullah. It will be an extraordinarily difficult challenge for him to meet. But, largely as a result of the way in which his father conducted his affairs both domestically and internationally, he takes office with the best of goodwill—not only from this country but from countries around the region and around the globe. We join the government in extending our deepest condolences to his family and our prayers and good wishes for King Abdullah as he takes up his mantle.

talk.start.para: —It is a privilege to add to the remarks of the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition, because King Hussein of Jordan served in that position for nearly half a century during one of the most turbulent and difficult periods in the history of the Middle East and in the history of Jordan.

speech.para: It is a privilege to visit the modern, magnificent city of Amman. It is, in itself, a salute to the modernity of King Hussein, to his leadership of Jordan and to the opening up of its economy. Australia enjoys rather modest trade—around $100 million—with Jordan, but it is a relationship that is growing, and I salute the further links being made almost every month between Australia and Jordan.

First and foremost, however, King Hussein will be remembered as the architect and protector of his nation and as an open leader whose priority was always the welfare of his people. He visited Australia in 1976, and his interest in a bilateral relationship has continued to grow and strengthen from that time.

It has been often enough said in this last fortnight that he made a massive contribution to peace in the Middle East. What has not been stressed is the particularity of his contribution to peace in the Middle East. It was not just the signing of instruments between Jordan and Israel; it was something a whole lot more than that. It was cutting right through to build trade, investment, tourism between Jordan and Israel, to provide a glue—an onward momentum—rather than just the formality of peace, and so build confidence in the linkages.

Today you can travel direct from Masada in Israel to Petra in Jordan whereas, until the leadership provided by the King of Jordan and his opposite numbers at the time in Israel, you often had to backtrack as far as Athens or even London, to cross over and come back through, to make that linkage—which is almost within sight—between Masada and Petra.

I especially salute the warm peace that he created and the efforts he made to see that peace in the Middle East and peace between Jordan and Israel had real momentum attaching to it—a momentum which created benefits and betterment for the people of the Middle East.

I wish the new King of Jordan, King Abdullah, every success for a smooth transition to power, and with his workload as he takes up the cudgels filling the big footsteps of his father. I particularly join with the Minister for Foreign Affairs in extending sympathy on this very sad occasion to the people of Jordan. I am very confident that the links between Australia and Jordan will continue to expand and build at the start of the new millennium.

talk.start.para: —There are not too many real heroes in international politics. In King Hussein of Jordan, we have lost such a hero. The king, of course, was a soldier, a monarch who emerged through war and conflict to stand as a world statesman and as a peacemaker. He was a reformer who brought parliamentary democracy to his country in a region where respect for human rights and democratic freedoms are, sadly, often abused. Like Yitzhak Rabin, he came to recognise that war brings no joy and no solutions, and he pursued the course of peace with immense determination and very great courage.

speech.para: Only last October we watched in awe as, in circumstances of great difficulty, he broke off from his cancer treatment and brought all his commitment, all his persuasion, to help stave off the collapse of the Wye River accord. All members will recall his immense dignity and his good humour at the press conference following the conclusion of that agreement.

We have all seen the grief of the Jordanian people at the loss of a revered monarch, a monarch who led his nation for more than 45 years. I experienced that enormous respect and affection for the king when I visited Jordan last year. Other speakers have today spoken of King Hussein's career and achievements, but I do not think any of us can speak as eloquently as many of the ordinary Jordanians we have seen and heard in the past 48 hours. Today all our sympathy and support goes out to Queen Noor, to his family—especially his son King Abdullah, who has taken on a most onerous burden—and of course to the Jordanian people.

King Hussein's great task, the task of finding peace and security in the Middle East, remains unfinished. The Wye River agreement is in a state of suspended animation, and we await the outcome of Israel's election campaign. It is to be hoped that all sides—Israel, Palestine, the Arab states—will take inspiration from King Hussein's life and press on to cover the last few hard yards to an enduring peace, with security, with dignity. Nothing would be a more fitting memorial for the king than the early conclusion of a just and lasting Middle East peace settlement. All members of the international community should lend every effort to secure such an outcome.
Debate (on motion by Mr Reith) adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Bunton, Mr Cleaver Ernest, AO, OBE

talk.start.para: —I inform the House of the death on Wednesday, 20 January 1999 of Cleaver Ernest Bunton AO, OBE, a former senator. Cleaver Bunton represented the State of New South Wales from 27 February to 11 November 1975. As a mark of respect to the memory of Cleaver Bunton, I invite honourable members to rise in their places.

para.inline: Honourable members having stood in their places—

talk.start.para: —I thank the House.
—I inform the House of the death on Saturday, 6 February 1999 of the Hon. Donald Allan Dunstan AC, a former Premier of South Australia.
—Mr Speaker, could I have the indulgence of the House to say just a few words about the late Premier of South Australia?
—Indulgence is granted.

—Don Dunstan, by any measure, made a major impact on the politics of South Australia. He was a very polished, articulate advocate for the causes in which he believed. His public presentation skills were amongst the finest that I have seen in any politician on either side of politics. It will be no secret that I did not agree with everything that Mr Dunstan did in his long premiership of South Australia, but I do recognise that he made a major impact with many of the reforms that he introduced.

speech.para: He succeeded Frank Walsh as Premier of South Australia, who in turn had ended the very long period of Liberal government largely presided over by Sir Thomas Playford. Dunstan was responsible for many changes in the social area—equal opportunity, electoral reform, consumer protection. He was also a very conspicuous and successful patron of the arts in South Australia. The construction of the Adelaide Festival Centre complex and the creation of the State Theatre Company are impressive monuments to his contribution in that particular area.

He resigned as Premier of South Australia in 1979. He endured a great number of illnesses, and he had a great degree of ill-health over the last year in particular. He contributed a great deal to his community, particularly through Community Aid Abroad and Freedom from Hunger. He was a fairly prolific writer, and in later years he involved himself in a number of business ventures. I want to extend to those left behind by him—his family and his close friends—the sympathy of the government, and I want to record the respect that I have for the passion with which he held his views and the contribution he made to his side of politics.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I wonder whether I can have indulgence to speak on the same matter.
—Yes, of course.

—I thank the House, and I thank the Prime Minister for the generous remarks that he made about Don Dunstan. Don Dunstan is one of the people who made me enormously proud to join the Labor Party back in the mid-1960s. He was, by any measure, a great Australian. It is appropriate that, though he has never served in this chamber, we should recognise here in this chamber the passing of a genuinely great Australian political figure. He was one of those—if I may speak in an internal partisan way—who defined the modern Labor Party, on this occasion from the perspective of how one ought to conduct a state government, what one ought to do with the powers and authorities that the constitution provides for state administrations. That task at the federal level, of course, was performed by Gough Whitlam, but at the state level it was performed by Don Dunstan. They were allies in many of the changes that were made in the structure of the Labor Party in the 1960s and in the 1970s.

speech.para: But, of course, it is not in that regard that he achieved his fame; it is in regard to the way in which he ran the state of South Australia and the possibilities that he opened up—some of which from time to time have been taken up by other state governments elsewhere—for genuinely new and innovative ways for state governments to operate. The list of his social reforms is truly extraordinary—starting with Aboriginal land rights and the first Aboriginal land right agreements arrived at by his government. He made changes in parliamentary processes by virtue of his long struggle and the long struggle of the Labor Party to achieve democratic reforms in the structure of the South Australian parliament. That was the electoral reform.

There was equal opportunity legislation—the most advanced equal opportunity legislation by any state government to that time. There was consumer protection legislation and law and education reform. There was virtually no area of society in South Australia where he did not see an opportunity to provide an advance in reforming terms and an openness. He was not one who sneered at an interest on the part of political leadership in support for the arts community and for culture. He saw a direct state government role there and he advanced the interests of his state as he did so.

It is no exaggeration to say that, by the end of the 1970s, most state governments—certainly most state Labor parties—looked to what was in South Australia as an indication of best practice in state government, as an indication of what you could achieve in public office in advancing a democratic interest, in advancing a reforming interest and in advancing opportunities for people via the processes of state government. Up to that time, in many ways state government had been seen to be effectively subsumed in many of these matters by federal parliaments and to be something of a backwater in the structure of the Australian political system. He changed that in relation to South Australia.

Of course, since that time he has not had an inactive public life. He decided that he would try to do for Victoria what he had done to make South Australia so attractive, and he served with the Victorian Tourism Commission from 1982 until 1986. He was National President of Australian Freedom From Hunger and a national chair of Community Aid Abroad at different points of time. He became a restaurateur and an author in his later years and broadened his reputation as a genuine political Renaissance man.

We in the Labor Party feel enormously keenly his loss—72 is not a particularly old age these days. We feel very much that he still had a contribution to make were it not for the fact illness took him. So we on this side of the House are very much in mourning and will be this week until we have the opportunity to pay our final regards to Don Dunstan at a commemoration occasion which will be held on Friday. It is our South Australian colleagues who feel the loss the most, but this was a man known to us all.

talk.start.para: —As a mark of respect to the memory of Don Dunstan, I invite honourable members to rise in their places.

para.inline: Honourable members having stood in their places—

talk.start.para: —I thank the House.

—I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon the Hon. Senator Sergio Bitar, former Minister of Mining and Leader of the Party for Democracy in Chile. On behalf of the House I extend to him a very warm welcome.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is to the Prime Minister. Does the Prime Minister stand by his statement on 5 August last year that, under the tax package, `I don't believe anybody, when you look at the generality of the package, will be worse off except tax cheats'? If so, how does the Prime Minister explain the evidence of his modeller of choice, Chris Murphy, that it will cause long-term net job losses in Queensland and Tasmania, it will result in people living in smaller, poorer quality housing and it will have a significant negative impact on surf lifesaving and the work of St John's Ambulance and the Royal Lifesaving Society of Australia?

—I have not read all the evidence that has been presented to the Senate. But I do know this, and the Australian people know this: the man who has just asked me that question is somebody who is trying to deny to the Australian people $13 billion worth of personal tax cuts. The Labor Party and those parties in the Senate who are opposed to our tax package are saying to the Australian people, `Although you voted so that 81 per cent of Australian taxpayers would have a top marginal rate of 30 cents in the dollar, we are going to do our damnedest to stop the Australian people getting it.'

answer.para: Let me say to the Leader of the Opposition: now that the parliament has resumed, our commitment to giving personal tax relief to the battlers of Australia, the family men and women of Australia, remains undiminished. Our commitment to reforming the Australian taxation system is as strong now as it has ever been and your attempts to sabotage long-term reform of the Australian taxation system will do you immense political damage.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to the recent report of his youth homelessness task force titled Putting families in the picture . Could the Prime Minister advise the House of the government's response to the report?

—In answer to the honourable member for Bradfield, that report grew out of the establishment of a task force which took place within two or three weeks of the election of the coalition government in March 1996. Because the report of the task force was tabled after the parliament had risen in December of last year, I want to record my thanks in particular to the chairman of that task force, a very remarkable man, Captain David Eldridge of the Salvation Army.

answer.para: The task force tested and evaluated the early intervention strategies of 26 pilot projects right around Australia. When I launched the report at St John's in Darlinghurst in Sydney in December, the groups that had been visited by the task force and the groups that had been touched by the various pilots represented a very wide spectrum of the Australian community. When I launched the task force report, I was very pleased to announce that the government would immediately implement its principal recommendation, and that was continuation of the early intervention strategies which had been proved to be so successful and which had been the subject of the pilot schemes that had been conducted as a result of the initiative in March 1996.

We are going to provide a new $60 million, four-year program. The new program will provide 100 services of the type piloted, and this will assist 12,000 cases a year involving about 7,000 young people and 7,000 parents. I have asked officials to advise me by mid-1999 on options for implementing other key task force recommendations. I do take this opportunity to thank the members of the task force and to remind the House that they have piloted and trialled methods of early intervention which, on the basis of those pilots, have encouraged the government to invest further resources in what I believe will be an extremely successful approach.

The report of the task force shows that young people and their parents are keen to get help before problems become crises. One third of young people living away from home before intervention, as a result of the experience of the task force's work, returned to live with one or both of their parents. This emphasis on early intervention is not only useful in relation to strategies combating youth homelessness but, of course, is also undeniably useful in relation to strategies combating drug abuse.

I take the opportunity to say again how much the government appreciates the work in so many of these areas of the great welfare sector organisations like the Salvation Army, whose practical hands-on, real life experience is superior to that of any people involved in this area anywhere in Australia. It will be, with appropriate help, the continuing policy of my government to involve them even more in giving advice and making judgments on the adequate delivery of welfare services in Australia.

talk.start.para: —I direct my question to the Treasurer. Does the Treasurer recall being asked on Radio 4QR last September:

question.para: Is it possible. . . in the next six years to have an unemployment rate of 5 per cent?
Does he recall his answer? It was:
Of course not.
