speech.para: Members who are new to this place come into a much enlightened chamber compared with that operated by Paul Keating. Question time was limited. Members of his own party received only limited opportunity to ask questions. Members of the opposition were not encouraged to ask questions of the Prime Minister or other ministers because they mostly deigned not to come into this place. If the Prime Minister came near the place, it was often for one day a week only.

Are the Australian Labor Party members—because they seem to be in agreement on this—proposing that they want to return to that control of this House by the executive as Keating ran it? Limited hours? Shorter hours? If you shorten the hours of the parliament and not sit additional days, you immediately put the control of the parliament into the hands of the executive. You need to think that through.

If you are proposing setting additional hours, you are proposing that many members spend more time away from their families, because their families have school commit ments and their children need a continuity of ability to attend school. Surely we are not thinking that members and their families are going to spend part of their time as a total family in Canberra and then part of their time in an electorate somewhere else, because—in reality and in practicality—if the children of members' families attend a primary school, they need continuity and that means that they are usually in the electorate. If the members of a family attend a high school, it is more important that there be continuity and they are more likely to be in the electorate.

Does that mean that somehow or other we arrange babysitters to look after our youngsters while our spouses or partners come to Canberra? That is not realistic either, so it is a matter of trying to find a balance between the competing features while doing the work that we must do, and that means sitting an appropriate number of days. The parliament is now sitting more days than it did under Paul Keating. That is because there is more work and more debate is needed. There is more need for us to apply ourselves to the matters of state and to the reasons why we were elected. On the other hand, we have the problems of our families being elsewhere.

We need to strike that balance—there is no doubt about it—but the proposal that Neal Blewett came up with, which people like Kathy Sullivan and Paul Filing from our side disagreed with, does not really meet the proposals that this House would like to see. The member for Fairfax, in his comments to me, said, `Extended hours at the end of the session are the biggest bane in a member's life. You sit for long hours, often through the night.' All political parties are guilty of that process. That is the gut crunching stuff that wears you down and makes it extremely difficult to perform well in the electorate or here.

But to raise occupational health and safety factors is just incredible when you consider that you are going to encourage people, including staff, to work at their desk without a break from 9.30 in the morning to 8 o'clock or from 2 o'clock in the afternoon to eight. The honourable member shakes her head, but there is no provision for a break time. It is a matter of agreement between a member and his staff or between the member and the whip if you can get away for a meal. That is not a realistic approach either. What Keating and the Labor Party did with those changes in standing orders in 1994 was in fact to rule out meal breaks, and that was a great loss to the staff and to us. It was an opportunity to sit down. I have got here amongst a collection of speeches a speech made by the current Chief Government Whip, Michael Ronaldson, who said that the introduction of these changed sitting hours had produced a barrenness in the parliamentary dining room. Nobody was going there, following the change, to meet and talk about the day's work. At 8 o'clock people left this building and went out to Canberra or went home after working solidly. They went out and had a dinner they really did not need, a large dinner at 8 o'clock at night. It would be far better for them to have a light meal at 6.30 and then go back to work at 8 o'clock than have a large meal late in the evening. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Order! The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
—I move:

speech.para: That this House:
(1) places on record concern about the lack of awareness in the community of prostate cancer;
(2) notes that the number of deaths per year ascribed to prostate cancer has nearly doubled, rising from 1355 in 1982 to 2660 in 1996; and
(3) calls on the Government to support the designation of one day or week per year as National Prostate Cancer Day/Week as a means of heightening awareness.

At the outset, I would just like to give a bit of an understanding of what prostate cancer is. I guess it is not something that had bothered me as a young man, and I still consider myself very young. However, a good friend of mind is a welfare officer in a voluntary position with the RSL. Part of his job is an unfortunate one in that he oversees the burial of many of his RSL members and looks after the welfare of the families. It started to occur to him just how many of them had been diagnosed and subsequently had died from prostate cancer. He subsequently had a test himself and, much to his horror, found that he also had this disease. He said to me that there is very little information available. There is so much on breast cancer and on so many other illnesses, but he could find nothing on this disease. He encouraged me to try and do something about it. That is the reason I am standing here today.

It has prompted me to learn a little bit more about it and has perhaps given me an insight into what this disease means to us. The prostate is the golf ball sized gland situated below a man's bladder and surrounding the urethra. The primary function of the prostate is the manufacture of semen. Prostate cancer is a malignant enlargement of the prostate gland. Until the ages of 45 to 50 years, the prostate remains fairly constant in size. After this age, the gland can enlarge and affect the normal process of passing urine. In most cases this enlargement is not cancerous, but in some cases it is malignant. Prostate cancer is relatively slow growing. Prostate cancer is the second most common cause of death amongst Australian men after lung cancer. In 1994 some 2,590 Australian men died of prostate cancer.

That is what the disease is all about. Unfortunately, the medical profession cannot agree as to the best way in which to deal with it. There has been a lot of talk about testing and whether or not any one particular style of screening is better than any other or whether screening itself has any benefit at all. We all know the successes that have come from breast cancer screening and how that has saved many women's lives in Australia. From my reading and understanding of this particular subject, it is not as simple as that for prostate cancer. It is not a case of identifying this particular cancer and then curing it. Some of the medical profession tend to believe that screening is beneficial and others do not hold that view.

The big difference, and what I wanted to point out as part of my motion today, is that, whilst the medical profession are still divided on the issue, the one thing they do agree on is that there is a lack of information and a lack of awareness. If we can heighten awareness, we can in fact make the situation so much better for those unfortunate people who do find themselves afflicted with this disease.

National health campaigns such as that run by this government on immunisation were incredibly successful. It involved of course the electronic media, a lot of public comment and support from community groups and health professionals. It ensured that immunisation levels in this country were elevated to world's best. I have already mentioned breast cancer and the awareness campaigns that go on there. The thing that both these campaigns have in common is that annually there is a time set aside in which everybody then concentrates on those particular ailments. That means that the electronic media can for a time focus the nation's attention on these issues. Hence, the third part of my motion calls on the government to support the designation of one day or one week per year as National Prostate Cancer Day or Week as a means of heightening this awareness. I am not advocating telling doctors how we should or should not screen and what is right or what is wrong but simply providing factual information which is so critical to the men that suffer from this, their families and also the health professionals.

The information that is required at the moment will go a long way to putting at rest the minds of not only those afflicted with the disease but also those who believe they are at risk. The choice on whether to take any remedial action once you have been diagnosed with this disease is not an easy one. In some cases the patient is just as well not to undergo treatment. As I said earlier, this is a slow growing malignant cancer and the life expectancy might not be decreased that much, particularly as about 40 per cent of cases of prostate cancer in fact occur in men aged over 80. So it is not an easy choice for the families of particularly those in earlier life who find themselves with prostate cancer. However, if they have available to them worthwhile information which is authoritative and balanced and allows them to make a choice for their own life, it makes that unfortunate condition that they have that much easier to bear.

I would like to bring to the parliament's attention the recommendations set out by the Australian Health Technology Advisory Committee when discussing this. They recommend the introduction of a comprehensive education program on the risks and benefits of testing for prostate cancer. They said this education program should: (1) have three components addressing the needs of the individual patient, the medical profession and the community at large; (2) be managed under the umbrella of the Commonwealth Department of Health and Aged Care and should include the key stakeholders, with the NHMRC playing a pivotal role; (3) be funded in a way that ensures an effective and consistent national approach; (4) include a mechanism to ensure an ongoing review of its appropriateness and effectiveness; and (5) have management and funding viewed in the context of a potential long-term series of such programs.

I believe this can and should be pulled together by this government in the form of a national day—a day of awareness—so that we can take a national approach to this problem and so that those people who find themselves in this situation can easily gain access to information which is balanced and accurate so that they can put their own minds at rest as to where to go. If we were able to achieve this, we may not necessarily reduce or increase the life expectancy of these people but we could ensure that their quality of life and the decisions they made were the best possible.

A very important point in relation to this is that, as we all know, breast cancer kills a lot of women. Some 2,602 females died of breast cancer in 1997; some 17 males also died of breast cancer. At the same time, 2,448 men died of prostate cancer. But the incidence of these diseases is quite startling. There are 101 cases of breast cancer per 100,000 head of population whereas there are 158 cases of prostate cancer incidences per 100,000. That is an increase of over 60 per cent.

Those figures indicate that there is an overwhelming need in the community for people to be able to access information and to be aware of what this disease can do. Awareness and knowledge are power. Empowering a person who has an unfortunate disease is something that this government and the wider community should be mindful of. We should work together with community groups, health professionals and those who are at risk of one day actually getting prostate cancer to ensure that they have the information available to them and that it is provided in a timely manner and in an ongoing fashion—not just once but continually so that progression in the understanding of this disease comes about and is put forward to the public. I commend this motion to this House and I encourage this government to institute a National Prostate Cancer Day.

talk.start.para: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—I rise to speak on this motion put forward by the member for Longman regarding the issue of prostate cancer. I note there are three points to his motion with regard to this issue: (1) placing on record concern about the lack of awareness in the community about prostate cancer; (2) noting that the number of deaths per year ascribed to prostate cancer has nearly doubled, rising from 1,355 in 1982 to 2,669 in 1996; and (3) calling on the government to support the designation of one day or week per year as national prostate cancer day/week as a means of heightening awareness.

speech.para: This is a fairly complex issue and in some respects a confusing one, as I think the previous speaker mentioned. There is a range of information around the issue of prostate cancer, but there is also a range of information that is not around. That in itself creates difficulties in terms of any proper or reasoned consideration of what to do. We find ourselves, in a matter such as this, in a situation where there are a number of things that could be done around the question of prostate cancer, but there are real concerns as to the efficacy of what might be done.

I think all of us would support increased community awareness in relation to what is a major health problem for men today. But, when we look at the history of this issue, we can say that it has probably been a major health risk for a long time. Part of the problem has been that it has only been in recent years that there has been more awareness from the medical profession's point of view about the actual details of prostate cancer. In fact, with the increased incidence of recognition of prostate cancer, it has been shown that most people who have prostate cancer do not actually die from it. I think the term that has been used is that people often live with prostate cancer rather than die from prostate cancer. Nonetheless, it is still a very serious issue and it is still a situation which is of major concern, particularly to men over the age of 60, although there has also been some incidence in people of a younger age.

One of the problems is that lack of awareness within the medical profession in terms of research. There are a number of research projects on at the moment that are looking at the detail around prostate cancer—for example, risk factors. The question of age appears to be a pretty clear risk factor, that is true, but there are also issues of diet, location, exercise, et cetera. Those sorts of issues are being looked at where it is thought that they may require some consideration with regard to the likelihood of developing prostate cancer. At this stage, the studies still are not firm.

Another problem is one we often find with medical research issues. Proper studies using proper samples that allow for the consideration of the issue in some detail and that give you results that are clinically capable of being utilised can sometimes take a long time, and it can be number of years before those results are known. There are at least two studies on prostate cancer being conducted overseas at the moment from which results are yet to come. It may take several years more before they give us those results.

That raises questions about what you then do. For example, there is the question of the types of treatment. With prostate cancer there are three principal treatments that are talked about: surgery or radical prostatectomy, which is the actual removal of the prostate gland; radiation therapy; and also one called watchful waiting (expectant management).

There is real argument and debate within the medical community about the best way to go if diagnosed with prostate cancer. Some surgeons will argue that removal is the best means to tackle the issue. That can have some bad side-effects for the individuals involved, in the form of incontinence and impotence. It is not the result for everybody, but we are still waiting for clinical tests to be done to give us a firm view. Some specialists swear by that approach, but we still do not know for sure what is the best way to go. Radiation therapy has similar problems. The watchful waiting approach is to monitor over time—once the cancer is diagnosed—look for evidence that there is an inflammation or a development into a further stage of the cancer and then act, although there is an argument that on occasions that can be too late.

On the question of awareness and of promoting awareness in the community, one of the key aspects that needs to be addressed is that of ensuring that patients, particularly people over the age of 50 who may be in danger of getting prostate cancer, are aware of the dangers involved and are aware of the circumstances around what they might do. A number of articles and reports that I have read in recent days on this issue suggest that a lot of doctors have not really informed their patients properly about whether the right treatment for them is screening for prostate cancer. Although it is only one part of the awareness campaign, obviously if you work on an awareness campaign to make people aware of the symptoms and of the dangers associated with prostate cancer, you then come to the issue of screening, because that is an obvious logical next step. And when there are concerns about screening and how it would operate, I think we have to think about it very carefully. I would like to quote from article in the Sydney Morning Herald on this issue headed `Warning on Prostate Test Harm':
Doctors are testing healthy men for prostate cancer without explaining the possible harmful consequences, experts warned.
There are also reports of the prostate cancer screening test being performed without men's knowledge or as part of a series of blood tests during check-ups.
The warnings accompany new research suggesting hundreds of thousands of men have been screened for the cancer, though it has never been proven to be of benefit.

It also has the potential to do ill as it could lead to men having treatments with high rates of complications—such as impotence and incontinence—for cancers which may not have caused harm if left untreated.

From 1995 to 1996, one-third of Australian men age 60-69 had at least one prostate-specific antigen (PSA) blood test, which is used both to diagnose and monitor prostate cancer, as did 27 per cent of men over 50.
NSW Cancer Council researchers said some of these tests would have been done as part of cancer management, but that most were probably done to screen healthy men.

That in itself is not a problem, but when there are concerns about the reliability of the PSA tests initially and also the alternative test, which is the DRE—digital rectum examination, as the two main tests, that can raise concerns about symptoms which, following further testing, are found not to be indicative of cancer. If we go down this track, it is important—and on the awareness point that the member for Longman has raised—that patients are very clearly made to understand that the tests can have some implications for them in terms of what might result and that, if diagnosed, there are issues to be addressed about what you do about the cancer that has been spotted.

Several studies have included surveys which have shown that people who have been tested may not have had a great awareness of the reasons why. I suppose it gets back to that issue of men's health—that it is well known that men have an a aversion to going to doctors and are more likely than not to not seek a remedy to a health problem as it develops until it is too late. I suppose this is just part of a widening circle of these sorts of issues.

Awareness needs to be part of an overall program of awareness in relation to men's health. I would certainly encourage the government to look at the national men's health strategy which the previous government had in place and to look at developing an approach right across the issues of men's health.

Certainly, if anyone finds themselves in a situation where they are showing symptoms of prostate cancer, they should seek medical attention, get tested to see whether it is the case, and move forward to try to deal with the disease. It is important to put in context that the overall majority of men who have prostate cancer in fact live with it, live long lives with it, and in most cases it does not affect their longevity. I would also note that in recent years we have all heard of people who have died of prostate cancer. It is a major men's health issue. On the question of awareness I support the thrust of the motion. I am not sure about having a day or a week of action, but I think it is something that ought to be explored. What we need is more research and more involvement in getting evidence to decide on what the correct sort of treatment is, what the best form of testing is, how we can identify what form of cancer is more likely to be malignant in the context of people who have prostate cancer, and in that way try and target what is done to ensure that people get the help they need for what is a serious health risk. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I congratulate the honourable member for Longman on introducing this motion on prostate cancer. It follows closely on the motion I brought before this House on 27 February 1995, which called for more research and money to be allocated for a major education program. So we are on the same track. The only thing I would say is that it should be not a day, not a week, not a year, but a continuing campaign.

speech.para: We have to realise that every male in this parliament, every male listening to this broadcast or reading it in Hansard, will have a prostate problem if they live long enough. Fifty per cent of all males aged 50 have a prostate problem. Sixty per cent of all males in their 60s have a prostate problem—not cancer but a problem. And so it goes. Men in their 80s: 80 per cent have a prostate problem—not necessarily cancer. This is the significance of it, and it is not understood. The ignorance is abysmal. Most men do not even know they have a prostate, let alone where it is. This is true. And this is a very important factor for women as well, because it affects the whole quality of life of couples and families.

In my speech in February 1995, one of the things I said was, `Australian males have a one in 23 chance of developing prostate cancer in their lifetime.' That has changed: it is now one in eight. This emphasises the need to take some spirited action on this. In my

1995 speech, I said that there was a one in 70 chance of dying from it before the age of 75. There is now a one in 66 chance. It is worth noting that in the publication National Trends in Cancer: Incidence in Mortality there are two graphs which I seek leave to incorporate.
Leave granted.
The graphs read as follows—

talk.start.para: —These graphs compare cancer of the prostate and cancer of the breast. Without going into the detail, what becomes very clear is that the incidence of prostate cancer for males is far higher than the incidence of breast cancer in women. The mortality rate for males from prostate cancer is greater than the mortality rate for women with breast cancer. This is not to denigrate the problem associated with breast cancer, but it is to accentuate the need for equality of expenditure, research and education on prostate cancer.

speech.para: I note the publication National Health Priority Areas Report: Cancer Control 1997 says, `More than $10 million was spent on PSA and prostate acid phosphatase tests in 1996 through Medicare alone.' To put that in perspective, between 1991-92 and 1994 we spent $322 million on breast cancer screening. Again, I do not begrudge one cent of that money, but I am seeking equality for males in this particular area because it is something that is going to affect almost every male. It is interesting that the member for Longman mentioned that diet is a possible factor. In the World Health Organisation's 1995 World Health Statistics Annual, published in 1997, the age-standardised death rate—per 100,000 males—from prostate cancer in Australia was 27.1, in Japan it was 6.3, in Hong Kong it was 4.8 and in Korea it was two. At the other end of the scale, Norway was 35.1, Switzerland was 33.8 and New Zealand was 29.6. So diet is certainly one thing we should be looking at a little more closely.

I would like to remind everybody that if you are an Australian male and you live long enough you will get a prostate problem. In a normal healthy male, the prostate is the size of a walnut which grows and enlarges with age to the size of a lemon. This has very dramatic effects on the urinary problems of males. Therefore, I totally support the motion and I call for more funding on education and more research and screening.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to add my support to the issues which have already been raised by the member for Longman in relation to the private member's bill and to add some further comments. As the member for Bruce has already noted, we are supportive of the concept of an awareness campaign. In fact, it is part of Labor's platform to implement a national policy on men's health, recognising specific men's health problems such as prostate cancer and the generally poorer health outcomes of Australian men. The high incidence of prostate cancer and the relatively low incidence of detection are mainly due to the reluctance of many men to seek medical attention.

speech.para: This attitude also leads to the development of other diseases and conditions in men, most notably lung cancer which remains the number one killer of males in Australia. However, before an awareness campaign can commence, further research into this illness must be undertaken. I will briefly add to the comments already made. In Australia, one in every 18 men will be found to have prostate cancer. Of all the men with prostate cancer, two-thirds will not die from it. Generally, prostate cancer occurs in men over the age of 65. The majority of prostate cancers are not life threatening. Beyond these established facts, as the member for Bruce has already touched upon, there appears to be a substantial gulf between the conflicting beliefs about the many issues surrounding the cancer.

It would therefore be quite difficult to begin an awareness campaign without first establishing what basic facts and recommendations should be reinforced during the campaign. Some of these issues concern controversy over the treatment. There is a range of unpleasant side effects from prostate surgery—which my male counterparts can appreciate more than I—which need to be weighed up carefully before a man consents to the procedure. It is also acknowledged that there is no conclusive evidence in relation to whether or not early detection and treatment will improve a person's chance of survival.

A man may have high levels of PSA, yet he may not have prostate cancer. The PSA blood test cannot detect the difference between a slow-growing cancer which rarely kills and those that may prove fatal. All these outstanding issues make an awareness campaign a worthwhile initiative, but first there is a need to further commit resources to research the causes and alternative treatments of the illness. This may involve a study that examines the general health of men who have undergone prostate removal surgery compared to those with their prostate still intact.

Research should also ensure doctors are constantly updated on the evolving nature of prostate cancer and on how to advise their patients on the best approach to the problem. Of course it goes without saying that research needs to be undertaken to assist those who have prostate problems and investigate the most effective techniques of treating the cancer and relieving the symptoms.

Any awareness campaign should focus on men's health problems in a holistic manner with special reference to prostate cancer. This will help overcome one of the critical problems in the treatment of men's illnesses, most notably men's aversion to seeing a doctor. Accordingly, we should not lose sight of the need to promote a broad health message among men.

The recent ABC series on men's health, hosted by John Clarke, clearly articulated the problem: most men fail to take care of their wellbeing and most would rather visit their mother-in-law than see a doctor. Men need to be encouraged to take better care of their health, to be aware of dangerous changes occurring in their bodies and to consult doctors when problems or irregularities arise. Allied to this is the crucial need to promote the merits of a healthy lifestyle, beginning with a balanced diet and exercise. As lung cancer kills more men than any other cancer, it is important to reinforce the benefits of giving up smoking and, for the other health problems, reducing alcohol intake.

A soon to be published Victorian Department of Human Services report into awareness campaigns targeting prostate cancer has suggested that there needs to be an investigation into alternative ways of communication. The present campaigns for breast and lung cancer would not translate for prostate cancer. Before an awareness campaign is launched, the Victorian Department of Human Services report encourages debate on how to deliver the message rather than simply reinforce existing beliefs in health communication. It is therefore clear that not only the substance of the message but also the style of presenting that information requires research.

The motion to establish a prostate cancer awareness week should be welcomed. However, there must be research into both the nature of the illness and available treatments, and this should occur in tandem with assessing the best way to communicate the campaign before it can begin. In conclusion, I believe that any campaign should target a broad health message to men that will hopefully assist in not only reducing the spread of prostate cancer but also improving the general health of Australian men.

talk.start.para: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

debate.para: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

talk.start.para: —I raise today the government's failure to commission a comprehensive and independent health and mortality study of Australians who participated in the British atomic tests and associated clean-up operations.

speech.para: With the connivance of the Menzies government, the British government conducted 12 major, and hundreds of minor, atomic tests at Maralinga, Emu, and the Monte Bellos Islands between 1952 and 1963. The full extent of these tests was not revealed to the Australian public until the election of the Hawke Labor government, and the scandalous nature of their conduct was not properly examined until the McClelland royal commission, which commenced in July 1984 and reported in November the following year.

On the day on which the parliament paused to remember the life of the late Jim McClelland, it is appropriate to recall the work of the royal commission that he chaired, and particularly its recommendations that:
. Britain should fund a major clean up at Maralinga and Emu,
. the traditional Aboriginal owners should be compensated for the loss of the use and enjoyment of their lands, and
. a national register should be compiled of people exposed to radiation from the tests.

In response to the royal commission, the former Labor government initiated a $104 million clean-up of the Maralinga site and a $13.5 million compensation package for the traditional Aboriginal owners encompassing new outstations, improved health services, roads, water supplies and employment programs. Britain has contributed £20 million towards these two measures.

Some 15,000 Australian military and, I stress, civilian personnel were involved in some way in the British tests, and the local Aboriginal population was also severely affected. It is the situation of these personnel and local Aboriginals that I wish to highlight today. It is notable that Australia has devoted less attention to monitoring the health of its nuclear personnel than the British and has been less generous in providing compensation than the United States or New Zealand, who both provide repatriation benefits to defence personnel who were involved in nuclear tests.

A mortality study of 22,000 British nuclear veterans was first examined by the National Radiological Protection Board and reported in the British Medical Journal. More recently there has been a further study for the British Nuclear Test Veterans Association by the Australian researcher Sue Rabbitt Roff of Dundee University in Scotland. By contrast, the only Australian study ever made of nuclear personnel was the Donovan report by the Commonwealth Department of Health, which was conducted some 16 years ago. It was severely criticised by the McClelland royal commission which stated:
. . . the conclusions of the survey—
that is, the Donovan survey—
should have been more balanced . . . accepting that it was not possible to say that there was no radiation-induced illness or mortality.
The royal commission further concluded:
. . . because of the paucity of relevant information on which it is based, the Donovan Report cannot be regarded as an adequate epidemiological study.

The official UK study, published in 1988, found little difference between the overall death or cancer rates of nuclear veterans compared with a control group of veterans who were not involved in the tests. When specific cancers were considered, however, the atomic test participants had higher death and incidence rates of leukaemia—other than chronic lymphatic leukaemia—and multiple myeloma. This finding was consistent with earlier scientific work linking these cancers to radiation exposure.

In December 1993 the results of a follow-up investigation of the 1988 UK study were published. In the follow-up period there was no apparent difference in the death rate for nuclear participants compared with the control group. Mortality from leukaemia in the follow-up period was actually less in the participant group than for the control group. The study team concluded that the 1988 results were most likely the result of chance but that `the possibility that participation in the tests may have caused a small risk of leukaemia cannot be ruled out'. Following this study, both the UK, and later Australia, decided to no longer accept compensation claims for multiple myeloma as being linked to participation in the nuclear tests.

An Australian researcher, Sue Rabbitt Roff, was subsequently commissioned to study the mortality and morbidity of members of the British Nuclear Tests Veterans Association. This study was funded by the late Dame Catherine Cookson under the auspices of the Centre for Medical Education at Dundee University. Ms Rabbitt Roff's study involved a sample of approximately 12 per cent of all British nuclear veterans. To date the main output of the Dundee study has been a retrospective analysis of deaths reported to the BNTVA between 1983 and 1997. Whilst there is some dispute about the methodology employed, this study appears to show that these BNTVA members had double the expected death rate compared with the control group of working men.
The New Scientist of 4 April last year also reported her claim that up to 40 per cent of British nuclear veterans suffer from a rare and debilitating skin and bone syndrome called SAPHO.

More recently, in a media release issued on 13 December 1998, Ms Rabbitt Roff drew attention to an apparent anomaly in the number of cases of multiple myeloma reported in the official UK studies. Her data revealed twice as many cases as had been reported by the National Radiological Protection Board. She found evidence of 45 cases of multiple myeloma amongst British nuclear veterans, 32 of whom had died, whereas the NRPB had reported only 22 cases up to December 1990, nine of whom had died. Two-thirds of the cases among members of the organisation appeared to have been diag nosed after the December 1990 cut-off date for the NRPB follow-up study.

The British Ministry of Defence announced on 10 January this year that the NRPB had been commissioned to investigate these findings regarding multiple myeloma. A spokesman for the Ministry of Defence was quoted as saying, `The investigation would be carried out to reassure people that the disease is not linked to the tests.' I think most people would express concern about such rigid riding instructions to the investigation. Within a few hours of the British announcement, the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, Mr Scott, promised that an Australian researcher would be appointed to:

. . . examine Dundee University researcher Sue Rabbitt Roff's methodology, the scientific standard of her report, its relevance to Australian servicemen exposed to the same blasts and whether there is need for further investigation.

That is a quote from the AAP report of 11 January. I am critical of the government's response on two main grounds. Firstly, whilst there may be some value in commissioning an expert review of the Dundee findings about British veterans, this still does not give us any factual data on the health and mortality of Australian personnel and their families. To do this, we need to commission a rigorous and objective study of our own personnel. This is something that I have been advocating for over a year—with the endorsement of the ALP National Conference and as promised in Labor's defence policy statement at the last federal election. The specifics of the ALP National Conference resolution of January 1998 were as follows:
1. the establishment of a nominal roll of ADF personnel—
and, I would add, civilians and local Aborigines—
who had a demonstrable role in the conduct of the British tests and associated clean-up operations and were exposed to radiation as a result;
2. the conduct of a rigorous health and mortality study of all veterans included on the nominal roll and of their children and grandchildren. Independent researchers—
and I stress `independent'—
and representatives of the ex-service community must be extensively involved in the design and the conduct of the study; and
3. the establishment of a suitable mechanism to assist veterans to access government records on the atomic testing program and on their personal military service and associated medical treatment.
It further said that:

. . . on the basis of the outcome of the health and mortality study, Labor will examine whether the current schemes of Comcare, military compensation, special administrative scheme and act of grace are satisfactory mechanisms to solve their problems.

Secondly, there is no reason to be confident that the coalition proposes to actually do anything about the issue. On numerous occasions over the past 14 months, we have heard sympathetic noises from the coalition on the issue, but absolutely nothing has been done.

We first had the Deputy Prime Minister reported in the Australian of 29 December 1997 as promising that the government would closely consider Ms Roff's report. A spokesman for the then defence minister made a similar commitment in the Courier-Mail of 30 December—that is, way back in 1997—in relation to Dundee findings regarding veterans' children. Further, on 5 March 1998—almost a year ago now—the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Scott, wrote to the Australian Veterans and Defence Services Council stating:

. . . the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel . . . will be co-ordinating the Government's examination of the Dundee study once it is completed. I can assure you that the Government will give this matter careful consideration.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise this afternoon to speak about a growing social problem in this country, reported on in recent times by a number of our newspapers, in particular in an article in last Saturday's Advertiser by Nadine Williams. I refer to the phenomenon by which many single people are taking longer to find their partners in life and, in particular, men who are unemployed or in low-skilled occupations are remaining single well into their 30s and beyond.

speech.para: This phenomenon would appear to reflect the fact that these young men, with diminished job opportunities and an uncertain future, are finding themselves financially unable to marry and plan for their future. It is not hard to see why this has happened. It has generally been the case that men and women have tended to want to establish themselves in life before making a commitment to each other. In previous generations, this might have been expected to have happened when they were in their early 20s. Now, people well into their 30s have often still not established themselves in a career path, let alone life plans that employment would facilitate.

The economic roots of the problem are clear enough. There have unquestionably been marked changes in the labour market over the past few generations not only here in Australia but also elsewhere in the developed world. People are much more likely to move between jobs than they were a generation ago. Education and training are central to job prospects and tend to delay entry into the job market. Rapid technological change has meant that modern labour markets must be more flexible to keep pace with changes in the marketplace.

We have seen the results of the previous government's failure to embrace greater labour market flexibility. Thankfully, unemployment is now trending downwards from the disastrously high levels to which Labor led us in the past. Unfortunately, Labor has not learned from its mistakes and continues to oppose the kinds of reforms which today's experiences tell us are sorely needed. Lest anyone should say that seven or eight per cent unemployment is only to be expected in a modern market, there are countries which point the way to much lower levels, most notably the United States of America. Commentators have argued over the importance of the various factors that have contributed to America's success, but most agree that two factors in particular have made a substantial contribution: firstly, a high degree of labour market flexibility; and, secondly, the embrace of information technology based industries and the job creation that these industries have generated.

There are lessons for Australia to learn in both these factors, but I want to speak briefly on the subject of labour market flexibility. I do not wish to enter into the debate about the desirability or otherwise of downward flexibility of wages which has been one contributor to the success of the United States. There is a trade-off between this kind of flexibility and low living standards and their attendant social problems.

Australia has chosen wisely in opting for a reasonably generous system of wage maintenance and social security. However, there is another area of labour market reform in which Australia has clearly, and to its detriment, lagged behind comparable countries, including America. I speak here about the failure so far of this parliament to reform the infamous unfair dismissal laws brought in by the member for Kingsford-Smith and the Labor Party.

The government has stated very clearly what needs to be done. We presented legislation to the Senate and, when the Senate failed to pass this legislation, we made provision for the necessary changes by regulation. Sadly, the threats by some senators to disallow these regulations have not given business the certainty it needs to proceed. Members in this place will know that I am passionate in my belief in the need for reform to our unfair dismissal laws. By comparison with other OECD countries, our laws in this regard are arcane and anachronistic. At a time when most countries saw the error of unnecessarily restrictive unfair dismissal laws and began to liberalise them, the Australian Labor Party, in its dubious wisdom, made our laws even more restrictive, leading to a plethora of patently ridiculous outcomes which even representatives of the then government were forced to acknowledge.

These problems were foretold by those who knew something about the operation of modern labour markets. In a nutshell, overly restrictive unfair dismissal laws will lead to higher unemployment. The reason for this can be illustrated very simply. If a business faces the possibility of fines or court proceedings after terminating an employee for unsatisfactory performance, this expectation is built into the cost of hiring employees in the first place. This is a cost that the business must take into account, one way or another. For example, a business may have to build in an expectation that its proprietor or senior manager will have to spend some time in court dealing with unfair dismissal suits brought against the business. To avoid this, the business may have to spend money on out-of-court settlements with disgruntled former employees or, alternatively, invest in more rigorous employment selection procedures than would otherwise be necessary in order to avoid vexatious law suits in the future. It may simply manifest itself in the cost of retaining an unsatisfactory employee in an effort to avoid one of the above situations.

However an employee chooses to account for these costs, the bottom line is that if it costs more to hire employees as a result of these unnecessary restrictions, then unemployment will be higher than would otherwise be necessary. While the roots of this phenomenon would appear to be firmly economic, it is a problem which has potentially profound social consequences. The most vulnerable to such restrictions are those who are already unemployed and, amongst those, the relatively low skilled. These are the people who are now finding that their very lives are being put on hold. The uncertainty of their economic future means that they cannot look forward to having children, taking on a mortgage or doing any of the things that previous generations at their age were able to do.

It must be a singular source of frustration or perhaps bewilderment to many of these people that, in a climate of low interest rates and relatively easy affordability of housing, they remain locked out of such opportunities by their still uncertain prospects. These are the people who would benefit most from a more flexible labour market and more liberal unfair dismissal laws in particular. Once given an initial opportunity, most people are able to go on from strength to strength. We would acknowledge from our own working lives that one opportunity, however meagre, so often leads to other more fruitful ones.

How frustrating then that the initial opportunity remains elusive for many people in their twenties and even beyond because employers have not been given the freedom and confidence that they need to hire new employees. Those who might be tempted to disallow the government's regulations should first spare a thought for these young people who remain locked out—not just out of employment but of marriage, home ownership and a future—because of an inflexible system that has unnecessarily excluded them.

talk.start.para: —In rising on the grievance debate, I want to refer to the following famous statement:

speech.para: Ask not what your country can do for you; ask what you can do for your country.

John F. Kennedy uttered those famous words more than one-quarter of a century ago. In the early 1960s, in an era of low unemployment and booming economies, those words inspired a generation. In the late 1990s, the debate about what exactly are the obligations of nations to citizens and citizens to nations continues, but, quite rightly, there are new formulations being suggested in response to a different era.

It is the first day of the new parliamentary year—a day that we all look forward to. It is therefore opportune today to begin a discussion about the obligations of the nation to its citizens and the obligations of our citizens to the nation. I do not propose in this short time to give a definitive answer. I am more interested in kick-starting a real debate.

In recent weeks we have seen some rather cheap rhetoric on this issue. Personally, I am a great believer in reciprocal obligation—to my way of thinking, it is not only the way I was brought up; it is the Labor way. The Australian Labor Party and the trade union movement have never been about freeloading. They have always been about the concept of a fair day's work for a fair day's pay. The Australian working people have always pulled their weight.

It is in that vein—dare I say it—that the concept of the obligations of nation to citizen and citizen to nation should perhaps be enshrined in the preamble to a constitution. What is the relationship between the nation and its citizens? What should citizens expect as a right from the nation? What should the nation expect as of right from its citizens?

We have just celebrated 50 years of the Australian Citizenship Act. As part of this debate about reciprocal obligations, is there something special we should expect of our new citizens? Should that be in the preamble? The preamble defining reciprocal obligation should, I am convinced, include mention of our special obligations to the first peoples of our nation: the Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders. I personally believe that is a must, and I also believe very clearly that is the view of the majority of Australians as we move towards a new century. It is something that we as a nation are going to have to consider as a matter of urgency because it is about our nation's responsibility to our citizens.

I suggest that we seriously consider a preamble which talks honestly about the reciprocal obligations between government and citizens, government and the first peoples and government and our newest citizens. In the preamble we need to define reciprocal obligation using words that can inspire the many generations to come, in the same way John F. Kennedy in the 1960s inspired the American nation—and citizens of many nations throughout the world—when he said:
Ask not what your country can do for you; ask what you can do for your country.

As a modern democratic socialist, I believe that the nation—especially as represented by governments in this House—should be burdened with more responsibilities and obligations to its citizens than the citizens are burdened with obligations to help out the nation. John F. Kennedy's words were inspiring, but they were written for a particular people and a particular nation—America. America is a nation of different social and political traditions, especially in the roles and obligations government has in the lives of its citizenry.

Australia's history and political traditions put on our government a hell of a lot more obligations towards its citizenry. So, in any discussion about reciprocal obligation, we should look towards our own political history and traditions to define these obligations. We should look to our own traditions to find inspiring words to define reciprocal obligation for the 21st century. Unfortunately, the Howard government looks to the American tradition of the obligation of citizen to nation, and he reinterprets that tradition in a measly, miserly and mealy-mouthed manner. There is nothing inspiring in the way John Howard, with his idea of reciprocal obligation, wants to use the stick to bash the unemployed. He may want to break with Australian tradition and adopt American values about the role of government, but he does it without any sense of inspiration.

I am open to a debate on reciprocal obligation in 1999 because that is the Labor way, and that is what modern Labor has always been about. That is what we took into government and acted on during the period 1983 to 1996. Let us do it in a manner that will inspire our people, especially the young who are so turned off by the current political language.

I raise these issues this evening because I believe that the Australian community understands and accepts the concept of reciprocal obligation—the obligation of nation to citizen and citizen to nation. That is far from the approach that has been adopted by the Prime Minister since his election in 1996 and that was most recently evidenced by his latest political stunt, which goes to the question of citizenry and the obligations of the unemployed to accept a reasonable offer of training in literacy.

The problem with the Prime Minister's approach to reciprocal obligation is that he is all too often concerned with skipping on his government's obligation whilst pointing the finger at the most disadvantaged in the community. If he were actually concerned about assisting the unemployed who have difficulties with reading and writing, then the statement of last week would have been less about reciprocal obligation and the need for the young unemployed to accept their side of the bargain and more on how the government is going to fulfil its side of the bargain. I would have thought the Prime Minister would have spoken about the ongoing weaknesses in the Job Network, which is supposedly about getting the unemployed back to work. With respect to the most disadvantaged in the Job Network, there is no accountability on network providers to spend money on training, including literacy programs for the young unemployed and the long-term unemployed.

In the context of literacy—which is a major barrier to employment, and the whole Australian community accepts that—I would have thought that the Prime Minister would refer to the need for governments at state and federal levels to do more to provide decent, quality programs. Unfortunately, there was a lot of rhetoric but not much substance.

I conclude that the Prime Minister wants a debate on reciprocal obligation, on his narrow terms. The Australian Labor Party welcomes a debate on reciprocal obligation, but it is a two-way street. It is about the obligation of citizen to nation and, importantly, nation to citizen. It is about the obligation of the Prime Minister to engage in a comprehensive debate which produces results and opportunities for the disadvantaged in the community. It is about suggesting to the Prime Minister that if he wants that debate, let us ensure that it is a debate about substance; not a debate about political point scoring and rhetoric and not an effort to blame the unemployed for a difficult job market, which governments contribute to.
Bring on the debate, but let us ensure it is not about political stunts. Let us ensure it is a real debate about the obligations of nation to citizen and citizen to nation.

talk.start.para: —I rise this evening to speak on a matter that is of great importance to all Australians—their health system. Over the past few months, honourable members have heard the opposition argue that the funds the government is putting into the 30 per cent private health insurance rebate scheme would be better spent on the public health system. As most battling Australians recognise, this is just pure nonsense.

speech.para: I want to highlight just how bankrupt this proposition is. As Hansard will show, in late November last year I spoke about the track record of the Labor Party in health administration. As I pointed out to honourable members, Labor's policy position is so stricken by blind adherence to ideology that it jeopardises the health of average Australians. Recent evidence has emerged from my home state and my own electorate to prove this.

It was with great sadness that I read last week that waiting times for surgery have increased at Redcliffe Hospital over the last year. Even more saddening was the fact that any person familiar with the Labor Party's track record on health administration would have anticipated this. It is a tragedy of modern Australian governance—and you do not need a degree in public health administration to know this—that waiting lists always get longer under a Labor government, and that is what they have been doing. After five months in office, the state Labor health minister in Queensland publicly admits that waiting lists are going to lengthen. I think it is fair to say that Labor is again distinguishing itself by ruining a vital social service.

But fancy the indignation felt by the community when it became public knowledge last week that Labor and the unions are doing a sweetheart deal which will effectively give the unions the run of Queensland's public health system. The Queensland Labor government and the unions have put forward a proposed workplace agreement that will absolutely decimate the Queensland health system.

Let us look at what this agreement is going to do. Take, for instance, the issue of contracting out for services. The member for Jagajaga might be interested to know this. If she had the time to be here she would hear that the fine art of blowing out a health budget can be learned very easily from her Labor mates in Queensland. This is what this agreement is proposing to do, and I would like to quote section 3.3 of the government's proposed enterprise bargaining agreement which begins with the following statement:
It is the clear policy of the employer not to contract out.

However, in instances where it is necessary for the public system to contract out, this can only be done with agreement from the union. This is, of course, after the union has had every chance to put the mockers on the use of the private contractor's services. Nevertheless, if contracting out is to take place, it is up to the health department to try to get union members jobs with the private firm. So much for the private firm's employees, their families and their sustenance! So much for the role of small business as the engine of jobs growth in this country!

The effect of this agreement on the Queensland public health system will be diabolical. This agreement not only creates a closed shop—a thing of the industrial dark ages—but also gives Queenslanders longer waiting lists, bad management and budget blow-outs. What this agreement will do is hand control of the operation of Queensland's hospitals to Beattie and his union mates. Resources that should be going to patients and doctors will be diverted to inefficient ancillary services like cleaning and laundry services. These services will not be subjected to competitive pressures. The cost of providing these services will therefore increase and they will eat into the real aim of the health budget, which is to cure the ill and look after the infirm. That is what it is all about. But Labor's track record shows that they are not interested in this at all. Money will not be going into beds for patients or into more procedures. It will be going into services that can be better provided by outside operators at a lower cost. It is no wonder that, despite the Beattie government's claim to record spending in the health budget, waiting lists continue to rise.

Labor cannot run the public health system responsibly. All they are interested in is more jobs for the boys. But the irony of the situation is that unions have sold their members short on pay increases. Workers in these protected services will get a 3.3 per cent per annum increase under this agreement. The previous coalition government was offering 4.25 per cent per annum. So they are selling them short as well. But, unlike Labor's offer, ours was made on the basis of productivity improvements, not backroom deals to stitch up union control of the public health system.

This is just more evidence of the flawed logic that is used to formulate Labor's health policy: throw more money into inefficient ancillary services and ignore the patients; throw more money into inefficient ancillary services so that their union mates can protect their patch but deny battling Australians the opportunity to save on their private health insurance; discriminate against small businesses and stop them from putting people into work. What a perverse situation.

I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker: does the Labor Party have the interests of battling Australians at heart or are they more interested in featherbedding for their union mates? On the basis of this agreement and the federal party's opposition to the government's 30 per cent private health insurance rebate scheme, it would seem the latter applies. To my mind, it shows just how contemptuous the modern Labor Party is of average Australians who are battling to stay in private health insurance.

I am sure the people of Redcliffe and the people of Brisbane's north will realise this as they continue to wait for surgery while their state health dollar is being eaten up by union deals. To give you an idea of these increased waiting lists, the figures released by Queensland Health show that 2,168 people were waiting for surgery at the hospital on 1 January compared with 2,034 people on 1 January last year. And so it goes on, increasing and increasing. The people of Redcliffe are being short-changed. In fact, I am sure that the people in the Petrie electorate already have a whiff of what is going on in the hospital system and what it is going to mean for them. My office has been inundated with support for and requests about the government's 30 per cent rebate scheme. The message for Labor in Queensland is a simple one and it is this: it is about time they listened to the concerns of battling Australians instead of their union mates.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, a week ago if you had asked me to predict one political certainty for 1999 I would have said it would be the announcement by the federal government of its intention to proceed or not to proceed with the construction of Sydney's second international airport at Badgerys Creek. That was until I read last weekend's news. The Sydney Morning Herald of Saturday, 6 February stated:

speech.para: Sydney electors will vote on March 27 without knowing the fate of the proposal to build a second airport at Badgerys Creek.
It was revealed yesterday that the long-awaited environmental impact statement into the controversial proposal had been delayed by at least six months.

The government is now saying that the people should have an answer by May—if we are lucky. Didn't the previous Minister for Transport and Regional Development, the member for Lyne, say we would have a result by Christmas of 1998? Obviously a non-core promise?

I must admit I found the weekend's press took a decidedly city-centric angle in reporting this story. They said the delay would be felt keenly by the people of the inner city and inner western suburbs. If the outer western suburbs were mentioned at all, it was to cynically describe the pleasure that anti-Badgerys Creek groups in the region must have been feeling after being given another `stay of execution'. What rubbish! The people of Western Sydney also want to see this issue resolved as soon as possible. They have had it up to the back teeth living with the prospect of having a 24-hour, giant international airport built on their doorstep.

Seldom has an EIS report been so eagerly anticipated and its contents so feared. On this document hangs the quality of life of 1.4 million Western Sydney residents. Many are living in limbo in regard to selling or buying a house or choosing an area to raise their families or even to send their kids to school—decisions that in no small way depend on whether or not the government decides to go ahead with the airport.

When that decision comes—and, believe me, like most other Sydneysiders, we would like it to be sooner rather than later—Western Sydney residents know what it should be. Plans for Sydney's second airport at Badgerys Creek should be thrown out once and for all. But how much better would the people of Western Sydney cope with this additional delay if they actually had confidence in the processes and research behind the EIS—which, of course, they don't have?

The weaknesses in the Badgerys Creek EIS process have been well documented. The New South Wales government's Environment Protection Agency's report into Badgerys Creek has found that Badgerys Creek will have `a disproportionate impact on photochemical smog' in our area and would be a major source of the air pollutant nitrogen dioxide. It also said that the noise levels generated by the airport would expose many people to significant noise levels which would `exceed Australian standards'. The Independent Auditor's report on the EIS confirmed the EPA's reservations, and it said the EIS was very `deficient', `limited' and `ambiguous'. The Independent Auditor's report is an indictment of the EIS process. The report further states:

As a result of . . . time and cost constraints imposed by the Department of Transport and Regional Development, the draft EIS generally does not go into the degree of detail that could reasonably be expected for such a major proposal.

The report said the EIS had failed to examine the environmental effect of not building a new airport; failed to provide an adequate economic analysis of the development; failed to build community confidence in the EIS; failed to identify how Kingsford Smith airport and a new airport at Badgerys Creek would operate together; and failed to satisfactorily examine the impact that noise generated by the airport would have on Sydney's population, especially those living in Sydney's west. Knowing the inconsistencies and the weaknesses in the EIS, Western Sydney residents are therefore not confident about the Howard government making the right decision on Badgerys Creek.

They are even less confident now that the member for Lindsay has suddenly cooled in her opposition to the airport following her elevation to the ministry. Like almost all of Western Sydney's MPs at both state and federal levels, the member for Lindsay had come out in opposition to an airport at Badgerys Creek. For some members, this position was arrived at after years of supporting the airport—and that's fine by me; it is better late than never. However, what we are now seeing with the Minister for Sport and Tourism is a reversal of that phenomenon. The member, formerly against the planned airport, is now moving towards giving the project her implicit approval. She is certainly not vocalising her opposition to it any more in this House. As a backbencher, the member for Lindsay made numerous statements opposing Badgerys Creek and campaigned heavily against the development during the last election. In March 1998 she said:
Badgerys Creek should be kicked into touch as an option for an airport.

The member for Lindsay signed a statement during the election campaign that she would `cross the floor' to vote against Badgerys Creek airport. She also claimed at a candidate's forum on 29 September last year that she `had the numbers in cabinet' to stop Badgerys Creek airport from ever going ahead—all admirable stuff, I can tell you.

Then there was the member for Lindsay's plan for building an offshore `mega' airport on pylons outside of Botany Bay. This is the project for which she, in her own words, has `actively campaigned'. She said in this House in March 1998 in relation to this proposal:
. . . it is a concept which I have researched quite thoroughly. I am quite convinced it can be built. The engineering technology is there today.

With her position on the Badgerys Creek airport proposal on the public record, I looked forward to receiving the new minister's answer to my question on notice on the same subject late last year. What a shock when the answer I received offered nothing in the way of opposition to Badgerys Creek I had expected. If anything, it gave tacit support for the project if and when the government decided to proceed with it. I had asked point blank if she supported Badgerys Creek. I expected a direct answer—`No'. This is the answer I received:
No decisions about the second airport will be made until the EIS process has been completed. As a Minister of the Government, I support this position.

Without even a hint of her previous objection! It seems that the member has now decided that she likes the feel of that ministerial leather too much to start rocking the boat. As for whether she still believed in building an offshore mega airport, the member for Lindsay appeared to have gone soft on that proposal as well. Again in answer to my question, she stated:
The construction of an offshore airport would need to be considered in light of detailed feasibility studies which consider the engineering, environmental and commercial viability of such a proposal.
So much for the member's conviction that the project could begin construction today. So much for the member who said in one of her election pamphlets:

When it comes right down to actually doing something constructive about the airport, I . . . proudly follow in the tradition of western Sydney women Liberals who did not change their views when it was expedient to do so, but dealt simply with the facts.

I am very disappointed that the member for Lindsay appears to have started to go soft on opposing Badgerys Creek airport, breaking ranks with virtually every other state and federal MP and local council in Western Sydney in the process. If anything, now that she is a minister she should take her colleague the Minister for Finance and Administration's example and come out even more strongly against Badgerys Creek airport and not give wishy-washy `bob each way' answers to questions that seek a direct, unambiguous response.

Following the delay over the EIS announced on the weekend, the people of Western Sydney have enough uncertainties to live with regarding Badgerys Creek airport without the member for Lindsay adding to their problems. She cannot tell her constituents one thing and try to get away with saying another thing in this House. After her answers to my questions on notice, the member for Lindsay only has herself to blame for any criticism that she has changed her mind on Badgerys Creek airport. The onus is now on her to stand up and unequivocally state her opposition to Badgerys Creek airport not only as a Western Sydney MP but also as a minister of the Howard government, and I call upon her to do so.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: —Last week's announcement by the Prime Minister extending the mutual obligation principle, that is, requiring illiterate and innumerate young unemployed to under take remedial courses, has brought some interesting responses. The reaction has been varied, but generally fitted into two groups. Firstly, there are those with an open mind who support the need to try to do whatever we can to remove the barriers to unemployment. Secondly, and unfortunately, there are those on the other side, the knee-jerk negatives, motivated by naivety, political headline grabbing or vested interests.

speech.para: This issue really has two parts to it. The first is this: how can we best help the unemployed? Unemployment, as we all recognise, is a multidimensional problem requiring a range of policy measures. Tackling literacy and numeracy barriers is one such measure—an appropriate and very necessary measure. Many studies over recent years have shown the essential links between levels of literacy and numeracy problems and unemployment outcomes.

A study by the Australian Council for Educational Research released in 1997 showed that males with poor literacy and numeracy levels were twice as likely to be unemployed in their late teens as those with average skills or better. A study by Miller and Chiswell for the ABS in 1996 showed, firstly, that the work force participation rate for those tested with poor literacy skills was less than 40 per cent, whereas for those with good or better literacy skills the participation rate was actually over 85 per cent. Secondly, it showed that unemployment levels were 3.6 per cent for those with excellent literacy skills, five per cent for those with good skill levels and close to 18 per cent for those with poor literacy skills. Thirdly, the same study showed that the length of time spent unemployed is considerably greater for those with poor literacy and numeracy skills than for those with adequate skills.

A third study, the national study on adult literacy classes—called quite appropriately `Skilling me softly'—found, according to Patrick Griffin of the University of Melbourne's Assessment Research Centre, that between 23 per cent and 26 per cent of participants in literacy courses became employed within a year of commencing training—more than double the success rate of the long-term unemployed under the old CES Special Intervention program.

The studies reinforce what our commonsense tells us—that it is appropriate and necessary for governments to tackle literacy and numeracy barriers as one essential weapon in the assault on unemployment. The federal government is determined to do this. This government has led the way in developing a national literacy plan in the country's schools, aimed at ensuring that all children can read and write by the time they leave primary school. The plan included significantly increased funding for early intervention programs, with $176 million of Commonwealth money in this year alone and $680 million over four years.

But there are many people who, through one reason or another, have missed out in their years of schooling, who leave school still partly illiterate and partly innumerate and therefore suffering severe disadvantage when it comes to the employment market. The government is determined to try to assist these people. Last year the government committed $143 million to a national program to help the unemployed lift their literacy and numeracy levels. Some 69 educational and community organisations across the country have been contracted to provide basic literacy and numeracy training for 36,000 young people over the next three years. Admittedly, the take-up rate for these courses has been low. Thus, the need to increase the incentive—precisely the aim of last week's announcement.

A very interesting article appeared in Sunday's Daily Telegraph—the story of a 22 year-old who left school at the age of 14 and has never held a full-time job. This young lady says this of the government's approach to requiring literacy for young unemployed:
I think the new literacy policy is good for everyone. It makes you do something for yourself.
She had actually involved herself in one of the voluntary programs. She said this:
I was really scared about coming in for the assessment, but I know a lot of my friends in the same situation have just given up and I did not want to do that.

This is the point: motivation, assistance, incentive, encouragement and, in some cases, even a degree of compulsion can be positive in bringing unemployed and illiterate young people into literacy and remedial courses.

The negative responses from the doomsaying minority about these proposals are as ill-founded as they were when this government introduced the Work for the Dole program. The Work for the Dole program has been a great boost to the motivation, self-confidence and employability of many young people. One of the Work for the Dole programs in my electorate, run by Hawkesbury Skills, has helped a large number of young people over the past two years. At this Work for the Dole program they have a board called the `victory board'. On that victory board they list the names of unemployed Work for the Dole people who came in, became motivated, became skilled and went on to further training or real employment. They not only filled one of those victory boards but filled two and have almost filled the third board with names of young people who have gone on to employment and training as a result of the Work for the Dole program. This sort of motivation is essential, is positive and is productive.

The second issue associated with requiring unemployed people to do literacy programs is the broader one of reciprocal or mutual obligation. It is right to expect that part of accepting the privileges, protection and assistance offered by society is a commitment to contributing in whatever way we can. It is right in this context that those who receive unemployment benefits do what they can to find employment. Most fair-minded Australians would agree with this. Equally, most fair-minded Australians would have been appalled, as I was, to read these comments by Senator Stott Despoja in last Monday's Sydney Morning Herald. The senator said this:
The whole concept of mutual or reciprocal obligation should be rejected.

How appalling! Apart from the dishonest and misleading statements in some of the article, how appalling to suggest that there ought not be mutual obligation from those benefiting from society. How appalling to suggest that responsibility is not a two-way street, for suggesting that those who expect to receive should also not be expected to contribute where possible. How appalling to suggest that recipients of welfare should have no obligation to strive to overcome the cause of their dependency, that they should bear no responsibility for their own futures.

This is akin to the same muddle-headed, muddle-minded thinking that over much of the past 25 years has created a debilitating and destructive welfare dependency in Australia. This denial of mutual obligation and the obsessive elevation of rights over responsibilities, combined with an unrealistic faith in the omniscience and infallibility of government welfare programs funded by fiscal extravagance, has created a number of problems from which we are just beginning to emerge.

It has created a tragic loss of motivation and an attitude of dependence rather than a desire for independence. It has created an alienation and a loss of self-esteem which come with welfare dependence, and it has at least been a contributing factor to a range of social and personal problems that come with it. This mentality has created in fact a mood of resentment amongst hardworking, tax paying citizens. It is not a resentment of assistance to the genuinely needy but a resentment of those willing to take but not willing to have a go, not willing to strive for self-sufficiency—a resentment that was, I suspect, one of the seeds that led to the rise of Hansonism.

This muddle-headed thinking has contributed to the economic problems created by a growing number of welfare dependants and a shrinking number of taxpayers. This has brought higher dependency ratios and, with them, higher tax rates, a growing squeeze on middle Australia, reduced incentives, lower productivity growth, growing budget deficits and government debt. Sadly, the genuinely disadvantaged and low income earners have often suffered as a result because the welfare dollar has been spread further than it ought to have been or because taxation levels were higher than they ought to have been.
