Last week's announcements are practical, sensible, appropriate measures to remove one of the barriers to employment and they provide the young with the opportunity and the motivation to take a significant step on the path to independence.

talk.start.para: —There can be no sector of manufacturing industry that has suffered such overwhelming change as the textile, clothing and footwear sector has faced over several decades. The challenges that have confronted that industry have only been confronted and beaten by the cooperation between the trade unions involved and the employers as individual companies and their representative bodies. Therefore, it saddens me that today we actually saw the finish of a dispute that lasted some 67 days in the northern suburbs of Melbourne. Workers, members of the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Union of Australia, were locked out from their place of employment, the Australian Dyeing Company, on 1 December. They were locked out of their place of work in Clifton Hill.

speech.para: My interest in this dispute is at two levels. One is that it exemplifies the type of industrial relations hostilities that have been encouraged by Minister Reith's policies. My second level of interest in the dispute is, of course, that most of the workers at ADC lived in the northern suburbs of Melbourne. Many of them were constituents of mine. They are predominantly migrants. They are people that have come to Australia in each of the waves of migration. The 80 workers that were taking industrial action come from about a dozen different ethnicities. They are a diverse and varied lot, but they were solid in their support of each other and in the action that they were taking.

One of the elements of this dispute, whether it was a direct element of the dispute or not, was that an employer was trying to crush the ability of workers to come together as a collective and have their union act on their behalf. Therefore, early in the dispute it was important that those workers had an understanding that there were others outside of their own workplace that were taking an interest in what was happening. Theirs was an important struggle on behalf of the wider, organised labour movement and for the migrants that came from typically southern European countries of the postwar migration—migrants from Greece, migrants from Macedonia, including a migrant that had worked in one case for 37 years for this one firm. Many had worked more than 20 or 30 years for this firm. The firm's very existence to this date, as it confronted the challenges that confront all companies in the TCF industry, was based on the hard work and toil of this work force.

Of course there are other elements that a company uses to ensure that it continues to be able to trade in the last few years of this century, whether they be technological change, better work methods or whatever. But at the end of the day, without the cooperation of the work force, these things cannot be achieved. It is interesting to note that this company, the Australian Dyeing Company, was a recipient of funding under the TCF Best Practice Program. As part of this program, it sat down with its work force to try to get a better understanding of how the work force viewed management. One of the owners—the Managing Director, Ian Fayman—is quoted on an Internet site of the AusIndustry TCF Best Practice Program as saying:

We committed ourselves early in 1998 to a best practice project aimed at improving how we operate and increasing our chances of surviving and growing into the next century. The main aim is to extend business planning to involve staff on the factory floor.

Why then did it go so tragically wrong on 1 December last year when this work force was locked out? They were locked out and not back at work for 67 days until an agreement was reached last Friday. Why was it that the workers were not in a position to be able to go back to work, as they have done today with their heads held high, with their preparedness to cooperate to ensure that their employer, the Australian Dyeing Company, does have a future? Why has this group of workers been subjected to all sorts of com ments that in fact all they were doing was trying to demonstrate the power of unions? Why can't people who make those comments try to put themselves in the position of those workers who found themselves out of their workplace for that 67 days? Why can't those critics try to imagine what it was like for those workers and their families? Why do they belittle the sincerity of those workers in taking action? This was one of those proud struggles that we see and have heard about in the history of the organised labour movement in Australia. It was something that perhaps in the late 1990s we thought we had gone past. But, sadly, as I grieve today, I grieve because of the actions of Minister Reith and the Howard government in causing this type of hostility.

I was proud to visit the picket. I am not ashamed to say that I visited it, for those people who were taking a courageous stance in defence of their pay and conditions deserve the support they can be given by the wider public. The processes that the company, the Australian Dyeing Company, use involve the use of chemicals, some very dangerous and potent. The workers therefore got great support from the local community. Clifton Hill is a traditional Labor working-class suburb. At one stage, when James Henry Scullin was a member of the House of Representatives, Clifton Hill and the suburbs alongside it were the outer urban fringe of Melbourne. Of course, that seems now quite a long time ago, as the outer urban fringe is in electorates like Scullin, some 15 kilometres further out. But those people who live in areas like Clifton Hill know what it is like to ensure that a skilled work force is in place in factories like ADC's. They know that when these workers were locked out on 1 December and in the run-up to Christmas replaced for that three to four weeks by university students, an untrained work force, they were in some form of danger. Therefore, they showed not only their support because they believed in the industrial action that was being taken but also their belief in the work force, because they understood that it was basically a skilled work force.

There we have a group of 80 workers from diverse and varied backgrounds, a group of workers that have migrated here from Europe, from Asia and some more recently even from the African continent, who came together and were able to stand tall, to stand solid as a collective for 67 days so that this morning representatives of that work force as the first shift were able to hold their heads high and return to work. This work force will cooperate with their employers and management, notwithstanding the two months of the struggle that they have had, because they know that through this cooperation ADC, like other companies in the textile, clothing and footwear industry in Australia, will survive because of the types of skills and processes we are able to see in Australia that will enable those companies to compete against their competitors from overseas.

talk.start.para: —I rise today not only to wish everyone a happy and prosperous year but also to raise a subject that is dear to my heart. Coming as I do from the beautiful New England region of New South Wales, I take every opportunity, as I am sure all my National Party colleagues do, of driving extensively about my electorate listening to and speaking with my constituents wherever they may be. In doing so I continue to have drawn to my attention the fact that our rural and regional road network is steadily but surely declining in its level of maintenance.

speech.para: I know that road funding for local government, particularly local government in rural and regional areas, does not always receive the importance that it should. I know that the demands being placed on the bucket of money for roads are well and truly outstripping the funds available. I am also aware that the demands being placed on the total bucket as a nation are far in excess of what we have. However, we must address this issue before the road assets that the nation has built up return us to a Third World status. It is vital that, as our Australian manufacturers and producers become more and more competitive on the world market, they are able to actually get their products to the markets. They must be able to get those export dollar earning products to those markets efficiently, effectively and at the lowest cost. Equally, those who live in country Australia should have a road network that is able to enhance their quality of life.

Within the national debate on issues generally, funding for country roads seems to have been lost in the paperwork; left in the too hard basket. Every member in this place whose electorate covers regional and remote Australia knows that the road assets within their shires are deteriorating and, if allowed to continue to do so, will affect the very viability of not only country Australia but the nation as a whole.

In the past, local government has received much of its local road funding direct from the federal government, and this funding was identifiable as part of the financial assistance grants made to local government. I believe that it is the role of this federal government to show some leadership and to work with all levels of government to ensure that our local road network will be able to meet the needs of regional and country Australia well into the 21st century. It may be that we have to look outside of the square, so to speak, to find a solution that will deliver real increases in the funding and, therefore, the level of maintenance of these valuable assets.

The problem of funding national assets is a global problem, and there are some countries and regions that are addressing the problems in a very positive but certainly different way. I would like to give you an example, as follows:
The extensive road networks of Latin America and the Caribbean, valued at over 350 billion US$, show alarming signs of neglect and decay . . .
Sounds familiar. It continues:

More than 16 billion US $ are being wasted annually due to the absence of adequate road maintenance. Individual countries in the region are losing between 1% and 3% of their annual GNP due to an unnecessary increase in vehicle operating costs and loss of road asset value alone. This devastating situation is not only true for Latin American countries, but can be found in other developing countries and some developed nations as well—
including, of course, Australia. It continues:

The prevailing financial and institution system of road maintenance has been clearly identified to be at the root of the problem. In most of these countries an adequate flow of funds cannot be secured by the general budgeting financing procedure. In addition, the rules and regulations of the public administrative system do not allow for an effective and efficient management of road maintenance. As it is unlikely that under the prevailing system substantial and sustainable improvements can be made a new approach is necessary to eradicate this problem.

A new public-private partnership in financing and managing road maintenance can provide an adequate solution. The two basic principles of such an approach are to put road maintenance on a fee-for-service basis and to transfer road maintenance management from a `government ministry environment' to a `company environment'.
The article provides a guideline for such a reform—
radical as it may be. It continues:

Various alternatives are being discussed for securing sufficient and stable flow of funds for road conservation, for providing an adequate institutional framework to manage road maintenance on a national, state and local level, and for physically managing whole road networks in an effective and efficient manner.

Interesting. In New England one local government closer to home, Guyra Shire Council, together with the University of New England, has been developing a research proposal to investigate ways in which road funding priorities can be better identified and serviced within that region and obviously for other regions. The project is worthy of being pursued because the sort of integrated strategic approach that is being proposed is absolutely critical to the future development of that region and, I am sure, other regions in country Australia.

This research will address the issue of declining roads and road infrastructure as a problem of particular relevance to not only the New England region but others. It will consider the degree to which the overall sustainability of the road network might be improved through strategic coordination at the local and regional levels and through improving the coordination of road funding arrangements across all levels of government.

The research will combine state-of-the-art analysis and participative planning methods to identify, document and assess alternative management and policy options to influence an overall improvement in the standard of local and regional road networks. It will also examine the most strategic opportunities for improving that network to best service the sustainable development of the region's environmental, human and cultural resources. The project will proceed on the basis of active participation by stakeholders representing community, local government and all other relevant empowered agencies. It is very much about the development of effective working partnerships that will remain to support the implementation of ensuing initiatives.

These are just two examples of almost desperation in looking at new ways to maintain and improve our local networks. Forget about building new roads in country Australia; let us concentrate on maintaining the roads assets that we already have. Local government, and particularly local government in country Australia, desperately needs a dramatic increase in local road funding. It is important that there is funding for all of the other things that we have in our communities, such as schools, child-care centres, hospitals and all of those sorts of things. But if we do not look after the road network, no-one will be able to use them.

talk.start.para: —The question is:

speech.para: That grievances be noted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —I have received advice from the Prime Minister nominating members to be members of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation.

speech.para: Motion (by Miss Jackie Kelly—by leave—agreed to:

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act 1979, Mr Jull, Mr McArthur, Mr Nehl and Mr McLeay be appointed members of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation.

talk.start.para: —I have received advice from the Chief Government Whip nominating members to be members of the Joint Select Committee on the Retailing Sector.

speech.para: Motion (by Miss Jackie Kelly)—by leave—agreed to.
That Mr Baird, Mrs Elson, and Mr Nairn be appointed members of the Joint Select Committee on the Retailing Sector.

talk.start.para: —I have great sorrow tonight in standing here to speak on the condolence motion for Jim Cope, who was a person who represented an electorate called Watson for many years, as I have for a few years. Jim served as the member for Watson from 1955 until 1968 when that seat was abolished in that form and became the electorate of Sydney. He then served from 1968 to 1975 as the member for Sydney. The electorate of Watson that was served so ably by Jim Cope was a very different electorate from the electorate of Watson that I represent today. There is an interesting parallel in that Jim was the member for Watson and became the Speaker of the House, and I was the Speaker of the House when I became the member for Watson, having been the member for Grayndler prior to a redistribution. So there are some similarities.

speech.para: Jim Cope was a very decent man whom I had known as a young man in the Labor Party. When I became the Speaker of this parliament his were the first congratulations I got. From time to time he would ring up with a bit of advice, but mainly he would ring after there had been a rather hectic day. You would have gone back to your office—as I am sure you will, Mr Speaker—and thought, `It can't get much worse than that,' and Copey would ring up and say, `I listened to question time today, and you didn't do too badly. At least they haven't done to you what they did to me.' He would have a laugh about that. Sometimes when you had had those bad days Jim would give you a ring, and it made you feel a bit better. I think Jim Cope learnt what a lot of people learn being Speaker of the House of Representatives, which is that it is really a pretty lonely position, as you have no doubt thought from time to time, Mr Speaker, and I certainly thought from time to time.

The electorate that Jim represented was a lot different from the electorate that I represent now. The seat of Watson in those days covered the suburbs of Alexandria, Banksmeadow, Daceyville, Kensington West, Mascot, Pagewood, Rosebery, St Peters, Tempe and Waterloo. And of course the centre of it, as far as Jim Cope was concerned, was Redfern, because Jim Cope was a person from Redfern and of Redfern, and he really was one of those great Labor characters that that suburb has thrown up. He lived in the same street in Redfern throughout his parliamentary career, which is something that probably not too many of us here can say.

I said originally that there were some parallels between his career and mine. All of us think that issues here move on, but some issues never move on. Another parallel between Jim Cope and me was that in 1968, 31 years ago, he served on the Select Committee on Aircraft Noise, and he was concerned for his constituents who were then being subjected to noise from Sydney airport. So the member for Watson in 1968 was pretty concerned about aircraft noise in the same way that the member for Watson in 1999 is concerned about aircraft noise. I have no doubt that whoever represents Watson in another 30 years will probably still be concerned about aircraft noise. So I have often found that there were interesting little parallels in my life and that of Jim Cope.

Another parallel is that Jim Cope was a tradesman. Jim was a glassworker, the honorary treasurer of the New South Wales branch of the Glassworkers Union and the federal treasurer of that union. He came into the parliament as a glassworker. I came into the parliament as a telephone technician. In those days there were a lot of tradesmen representing the Labor Party; nowadays there are not too many tradesmen—or there are not enough tradesmen, in my view—representing the Labor Party.

He had a long career in both the industrial and political movement before he got into parliament. He was an alderman on Redfern council in 1947 and 1948. He joined the Labor Party in 1930. He was a secretary of his local branch and a president of the Cook Electorate Council. He served the people of Redfern, the people of Watson and subsequently Sydney very well.

Unfortunately, I think people will remember Jim Cope more for what happened on 27 February 1975 rather than for what he brought to the role of Speaker. Those who remember Jim well—like Gordon Scholes, who was his deputy at the time, Kim Beazley's father, who served with him, and Frank Stewart, who was my predecessor as the member for Grayndler and had told me from time to time about Jim—know that he was the sort of person who had a great number of friends in the parliamentary Labor Party, including the father of the current member for Barton. Part of his round of friendship was that he was very good at the game of billiards. From what is left of the memorabilia from the old billiard room in the Old Parliament House you will see that Jim Cope was a very prolific billiard player. Those who served with him at the time recall that he was also a very generous host as a Speaker and that people used to call by his office in the Old Parliament House of an evening for a drink and a reminisce.

He was well liked by his colleagues and that is the reason he was elected to the position of Speaker. He put a lot of effort into understanding the standing orders. He had a very good sense of humour, which is necessary in your job, Mr Speaker, as it was for him. Unfortunately, the events of that one day—27 February 1975—overrode a lot of the other things that people will think about Jim Cope. But a measure of Cope was that, even on that day, Peter Nixon, who was one of the people who brought him down—the troika of Sinclair, Nixon and Anthony were orchestrating the upheaval in the House in 1975—said of him that Jim Cope was a man. Nowadays, in these gender neutral times, that is not the most terrific compliment to throw around but, for a person of Jim Cope's generation, to be called a man by your opponent was a great compliment. Cope was that sort of person. He was a very honourable person.

When he lost the vote for the suspension of Clyde Cameron, he took it on the chin. There were plenty of precedents that he could have grabbed hold of and still held the job. Archie Cameron, when he was the Speaker, I think probably lost more votes in the House against his decisions than he won. Cope could always have found something in Cameron's history that would have allowed him to say, `The Prime Minister might have decided that he didn't want to uphold the Speaker's ruling, but that is not going to break my heart.' But, because Cope was an honourable person, he resigned. For him, that was a terribly sad thing to have to do because he was part of the generation of Labor people who had spent all their life in opposition.

He came to parliament in 1955 and it was not until 1972 that his party got into government. So he had only a couple of years in the job of Speaker, which meant so much to him. He was not brought down so much by the opposition but by what was, to put it at its most generous, just pent-up passion on both sides of the parliament which blew up that day and caused something to happen which has not happened since and I doubt ever will again.

So in some ways what Jim Cope did was to be a great help to Speakers in the future because, after that event of hubris which overtook the government that day, I think all other governments have been always a little bit careful not to put a Speaker into such a position. So what happened to Jim probably saved me and some of my predecessors and maybe you, Mr Speaker, and may save some of your successors. I think that Cope was a person whom we could all look up to. He had very much a sense of humour.

In those days, there was a predominance of Catholics representing the Labor Party in this parliament from New South Wales. In 1955, there were not many Catholics who represented the Labor Party from some of the other states because many of them had been purged from the party. On 11 September 1975, Cope said in a explanation:

I claim to have been misreported in a booklet entitled `A Biographical Register of Commonwealth Parliament 1901-1972' by Joan Ryden. The booklet states that I am an RC. I am not an RC. I am an unfinancial Anglican.

That was the sort of joke that Cope would have had with people. Tomorrow we will farewell him from Christ Church Saint Lawrence in Sydney, which is where most unfinancial Anglicans should properly be farewelled from. What we have seen with the passing of Jim Cope is the passing of another link with the past of the Labor Party, another link with those people who went through a lot of the trauma that there was in the Labor Party in the mid-1950s. More particularly, what we have seen with the death of Jim Cope is the death of a very decent, honourable man who put his party's interests above his own interests. Not only will he be sorely missed by Myrtle and his daughter Bonnie, but he will be sorely missed by all of us.

Tomorrow, I think we should celebrate the life of Jim Cope, celebrate the life of a person who was a great member for Watson and subsequently Sydney, the life of a fellow who was a great trade unionist and the life of a man who did what his constituents wanted him to do and was a person who truly represented the ethos of Redfern and of the Labor Party.

talk.start.para: —Over the past few days, many people have spoken and written about the Hon. James Francis Cope, who was my predecessor as the member for Sydney. They have called him a modest man. He and his wife Myrtle lived in their Redfern terrace for 44 years. Even after many years in parliament, Mr Cope continued to record his occupation as `glassblower'. He was a staunch unionist and an ALP member for about 70 years and also an alderman on the former Redfern Council. He was a particularly proud resident of Redfern, which is a suburb at the heart of my electorate of Sydney.

speech.para: After author Don Whitington had declared that Redfern was `almost a dirty word in Sydney' and peopled by `thugs and thieves, pimps and prostitutes, gunmen and gangsters and decent hardworking artisans and unskilled labourers too poor to live anywhere else,' Mr Cope replied that he would not claim that every person in Redfern was the perfect citizen. He said:

In some ways they may seem rough and ready, but I am proud to be one of them and would hazard a guess that people in many of the more affluent areas would like to have such friends and neighbours in times of stress.

He told one newspaper, `We're no angels, but you've got to stick up for a place that has produced one Governor-General—Bill McKell—and three state Premiers,' and, indeed, a Speaker of the House of Representatives.
Upon election to the federal parliament, Mr Cope's first speech called upon the Menzies government to increase pensions by £1 per week rather than the 10s per week that was proposed. He said:

Instead of their having to depend on charitable organisations for left-off clothing and a bowl of soup, some money could be taken out of the defence vote and used to assist them, because my policy is not one of guns before butter . . . Let me emphasise that what I say about the pensioners I mean. I have been through the mill. I know what it is to go without a meal. In the 1930s I was unemployed. I had a wife and a young baby and I was on the dole. But I doubt very much whether the Prime Minister or the Treasurer would know what it is to go without a meal.
He told a newspaper on his ascension to the speakership:

I was out of work for three years—I was on the dole and I got precisely 14 shillings and tuppence a week. Six shillings of that went on rent for a little room in Redfern where I lived with my wife, Myrtle, and baby daughter Bonnie. I remember how we looked for work—50 or 60 men lined up outside this place in Camperdown each day, like a line of cattle, waiting for a job. And the boss would come out and say `you, you and you'. You couldn't afford fruit and vegies—yet you could go out to Sydney Heads and see them dumping the fruit and vegetables they couldn't sell into the sea. I thought there was something terribly wrong with this sort of system, and that's when I got interested in politics.

Mr Cope was a proud Australian who believed that the Governor-General should be an Australian, not a member of the British aristocracy. His arguments resonate with the current arguments for a republic and an Australian head of state. He said:

The present policy of the Government of appointing a member of the British nobility as Governor-General gives to people of other countries the impression that we are still in the antiquated days of traditional colonialism. It also creates the thought that Australians are an inferior race—that none of them possess the capacity, intellect and dignity required for the office of Governor-General.

Having been made a Companion of the Order of St Michael and St George under the imperial honours system, Jim Cope later wanted to convert his honour to an Officer of the Order of Australia. Unfortunately, that was not possible.

As the honourable member for Watson has said, Jim Cope warned many years ago of the problems of aircraft noise. In 1966 Mr Cope wrote to the Australian warning that the `proposed supersonic airliners of the near future' would place a further burden on residents living near the airport. So, over 30 years ago, Jim Cope said:
We have now reached the stage when we must consider which is the most important, the speed and comfort of air travellers, or the health and welfare of residents living near major airports.
I believe residents in the electorate of Sydney would still find a lot to agree with in those words.

I have a particular reason to be grateful to the late Jim Cope. It is a reason that I share with colleagues such as the member for Swan, the member for Isaacs and the member for McMillan, amongst others. Mr Cope was an advocate throughout his parliamentary career of non-alphabetical listing of candidates on ballot papers for the House of Representatives. The donkey vote, he believed, accounted for up to four per cent of the vote in any seat.

He gave many examples to prove this, with many complicated calculations about the vote of the Democratic Labor Party and the Communist Party, but one particular example he gave related to a candidate who stood in a Queensland election. The candidate stood in order to make sure that the ALP candidate was not at the head of the ballot paper and immediately withdrew from the election. Despite withdrawing and despite newspaper reports at the time that this man was no longer a candidate, he still received 150 votes. Despite this move away from alphabetical listing first being proposed in relation to the Senate ballot paper in 1939, it was not until 1983 that this anomaly was finally rectified.

Mr Cope was a witty interjector and many people have spoken today about some of his more famous quips, including his suggestion for a fourth site for the new parliament and his comments to Sir Robert Menzies, the then Prime Minister, about the truck driver. But he is probably best known for his role as Speaker and the way that he left that position. As Mungo MacCallum describes it:

Coalition members saw their transition to Opposition as an aberration to be remedied as soon as possible and by any means possible. To achieve this they were prepared to push the parliamentary process to its limits and beyond.

On one day Mr Cope, as Speaker, was forced to suspend three former Liberal ministers, including former Prime Minister Gorton. Today, and during the last few days, the story of Mr Cope's resignation has frequently been retold, but I have it on good authority, indeed from one of the members of the Paddington branch of the ALP who was Prime Minister at the time, that the story really begins much earlier than the day of the resignation.

Former Prime Minister Whitlam's refusal to allow the Leader of the House to move Mr Clyde Cameron's suspension followed a similar scenario several years earlier when Prime Minister Menzies refused to support Speaker Archie Cameron in similar circumstances, according to Mr Whitlam. There was a chance that the situation might have been defused, except that Ian Sinclair, in what the Deputy Prime Minister today described as a `brilliant move' and a `class act', jumped to his feet to move Mr Cameron's suspension. Nevertheless, Mr Cameron was quoted in the Australian as saying that Mr Cope was `an honest and decent bloke' who had been absolutely right to name him. `Jim Forbes,' he said, `made me too angry to be sane, and when Cope asked me to apologise and withdraw, I was just temporarily insane with anger.'

Whatever the historical reasons for the events of that day, it seems that Mr Cope never bore a grudge, always putting party unity before any personal disappointments he may have felt about the events leading to his resignation. He made his peace with Clyde Cameron and former Prime Minister Whitlam, who helped with the arrangement for Mr Cope's state funeral. I join with other honourable members in offering my condolences to Mr Cope's wife, Myrtle, their daughter and other family members.

talk.start.para: —It is with honour, but with some considerable sadness, of course, that I rise in memory of my friend Jim Cope. Jim was a member of my electorate for some 20 years. Indeed, until the last three years, he was an active member of the Ramsgate branch of the Labor Party, which is my branch and my father's. For quite a while, that branch was honoured with a former Speaker of the House of Representatives and the former President of the Senate, so very few members got away with anything on the rules. Jim always added that same colour and that same sense of professional interjection for which he was famous at those meetings. Whereas all political meetings, I suppose, on both sides of the fence, can be pretty dull affairs, ones attended by Jim were really a pleasure.

speech.para: Until the last three years, Jim kept pretty good health and an active life. In the last three years, bad problems he had with his legs and his vision were such that it was impossible for him to be cared for at home, and hence he went into a nursing home, which was actually in the electorate of the member for Watson. I visited him on a number of occasions there. Indeed, the last occasion I visited him was last Monday evening—a week ago today. He was clearly in a bad way and in a lot of discomfort, but even then he was more concerned with asking me how my wife was and how my children were and was clearly interested in them. He was able to account for the friends who had visited him. He mentioned that Joe Riordan, Les McMahon and Les Johnson, all former members, had all frequently visited him. Indeed, my father took great pleasure in going to visit Jim to go through some of the old stories.

Right up until the end he was very fortunate indeed and, if we can have that blessing, we will all be grateful to keep our faculties to the end. Jim once told me that, after retiring from parliament, he had made a practice of reciting to himself the American states in alphabetical order just for the mental agility. Apparently he did that on a daily basis. So if that is a recipe for keeping alertness, it is perhaps not a bad one. I have to say that I would fail the test today. But that is an interesting insight into him.

He kept an interest in affairs outside the parliament. We have heard of his interest in snooker. He was a life member of City Tattersalls where he was, I understand, highly respected as a snooker player until his vision started to deteriorate. He was a very active and keen member of the St George Leagues Club. He was a participant in all kinds of activities. I only knew Jim as a man of a small frame, but he would frequently boast to me of his cricketing achievements. In particular, he mentioned some famous bowler—whose name escapes me—who he hit a century against. He was proud of that, and I understand he was a New South Wales schoolboy cricketer.

Fundamentally, he was a real gentleman. People have said repeatedly that he was a very decent man, and that was something that came across in his manner. For instance, he persisted in telling me last Monday night what an asset I had in my wife Michelle and my family, which is true, but he was taking an interest in circumstances where he quite clearly knew that he was in a bad way.

It is with sadness—and is very much heartfelt—that we convey our sympathy to his wife of 67 years, Myrtle; his only daughter, Bonnie; his grandchildren, Leanne and James; and his great grandson, about whom he spoke with great fondness, Cameron Price. So it is with great honour but sadness that we pass on our condolences, but praise the memory of Jim Cope.

talk.start.para: —I will keep my remarks relatively brief, given the number of comments that have already been made by members on both sides of the House earlier today and this evening.

speech.para: I first heard Jim Cope when I was a young whippersnapper out there listening to the parliamentary debates on ABC radio in the days when ABC broadcasts used to interrupt the mainstream ABC metropolitan radio networks and parliament had one or two more listeners. Jim Cope was, I suppose, the first Speaker I remember listening to in parliament. He had a very tough job during the days of the Whitlam government. It was, I suppose, part of the nature of a reforming government such as that headed by Gough Whitlam that there was a lot of controversy about decisions that were taken by the government. The then opposition used every mechanism at its disposal to take the debate up to the government of the day, and that made Jim Cope's job very difficult during the time that he had the honour of being Speaker of the Australian House of Representatives.

I first met Jim Cope a number of years later after he had retired from the Australian parliament. I got to know two Labor Party members who lived at The Entrance, Joyce Buckley and her husband, Ken, who passed away in recent years. Jim Cope was Joyce Buckley's brother-in-law. I first met Jim Cope when Ken and Joyce were kind enough to invite me around for afternoon tea one day. Mr Speaker, I can tell you, you have not seen an afternoon tea until you have seen an afternoon tea put on at the home of Joyce and Ken Buckley—scones and jam and cream and biscuits and cakes.

It was a real honour to meet Jim Cope. He was a real gentleman, very quietly spoken and a very generous person. As others have mentioned, he was very proud of his origins—very proud of having been a long-term resident of Redfern, and very proud of the cohesion and the tough community support that exists in a community such as Redfern.

Gordon Scholes once said to me that if you go to Old Parliament House and visit what used to be the snooker room—I think perhaps even in the new snooker room—there is a plaque that lists the Australian parliamentary snooker champions. There was a competition that used to be run each year, and Gordon Scholes said to me that the reason the competition stopped was that Jim Cope kept winning year after year after year, and there was no competition at all because he was such a good snooker player.

His electorate of Sydney also covered Lord Howe Island and included a few of my relatives. I know that he was very keen to raise issues that affected that small group of constituents, who lived quite a long distance away from Redfern. He was a member who represented his community with great distinction.

I know that he was very proud of his family. As my colleague the member for Barton has already mentioned, his wife of 67 years, Myrtle, is very proud of not only Jim's achievements but the contribution that her family has made over many years. I am sure that all members would like to place on record the great distinction with which Jim Cope performed his duties over many years. His daughter Bonnie, her two children, Leanne and James and his great-grandson, Cameron, are very proud of the great things that he did during the time that he had the honour of repre senting his electorate in the Australian House of Representatives and the time that he represented the House of Representatives during his two years as Speaker of the Australian parliament.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable members standing in their places.

subdebate.1.para: Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable members standing in their places.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to join in the condolence motion for former Senator Neville Bonner. Neville Bonner hailed from the Ipswich area, a city whose north-western suburbs I represent. I intend to keep my remarks short because I am not of the political generation of former Senator Bonner, and I did not know him very well. But I did have some knowledge of him, and many people whom I associate with in my Liberal Party branch, the Bremer branch of the Liberal Party, knew and associated with Mr Bonner when he was a senator and also when he was chairman of the Liberal Party's Oxley area between 1969 and 1970.

speech.para: Neville Bonner was most proud of his aboriginality. He was an elder of the Jagera people. In 1983, in the last year that Mr Bonner was a senator representing the people of Queensland, I remember witnessing him in King George Square speaking to a large crowd. He did so in a very dignified and uplifting manner, I thought. At the time, being a young ABC reporter, I thought it was quite a moving experience to see the senator make his point. It was an occasion when there was quite some heated debate going on, and I thought he put his point very well. I think people always respected the very refined way in which the former senator made his point and went about it on behalf of the people he was speaking for.

The main feature of the former Senator Bonner's performance was his strong adherence to his culture. I remind the House that Neville Bonner, apart from being the first Aboriginal member of parliament, was also the first Aboriginal member to put into practice through the House the Aboriginal Development Commission Bill 1979. I think I should read the first and last things that the senator said at that time, because I think it reflected something of his view:

The government, in introducing the Aboriginal Development Commission Bill, is taking steps to put into effect what I have been saying for a number of years—the placing into Aboriginal hands of the control of Aboriginal affairs. I have said on many occasions in the past that the Aboriginal people have come of age. It has now been accepted by the government that this proposition is undeniably true, and this bill confirms their belief in that view.
In closing, in the same debate he said:

It is not too many years ago that I was degraded by being obliged to have a permit in order to leave the Palm Island Aboriginal Reserve. As a contrast, it is a source of great pride to me as an Aboriginal senator to stand here today and be able to commend to honourable senators this bill, which represents a significant step forward for my people—a step which I am absolutely confident they will unhesitatingly take. I commend the bill to honourable senators.

After making that point, I also want to recall a couple of recent tributes to Neville Bonner. I was present recently on Australia Day when Neville Bonner was awarded the Ipswich Citizen of the Year award—in his absence, unfortunately. The former senator was in the Ipswich Hospice at the time. He was very ill at the time, and his wife, Heather, appeared. There was a very strong reaction on that occasion to his receiving the Citizen of the Year award because, apart from his aboriginality, the former senator was very proud of his background in the Ipswich area and of the people that he came to know and love in that area. His wife spoke on his behalf and accepted the award, and she spoke with the same quiet dignity that we have seen over the years from Neville Bonner.

I was also present on another occasion, which the Prime Minister referred to this morning, when the Prime Minister awarded Neville Bonner life membership of the Liberal Party. That was at the National Convention of the Liberal Party in Brisbane early last year. It was fantastic because Neville Bonner was present in person for the award. It was a very emotional experience and there was a standing ovation from the entire room. It was a political reconciliation which was, I suspect, long overdue. Many members remarked on it afterwards, and it was something that made a special mark on the whole convention.
Neville Bonner is survived by his wife of 27 years, Heather, five sons, three stepsons and 28 grandchildren. On behalf of all Blair residents, I express my condolences to them.

In closing, I would like members to note that Mr Bonner spent his last couple of weeks in the care of staff and volunteers at the Ipswich Hospice. The hospice is a unique facility. Only in Ipswich, I suspect, could you have this standard of community care being delivered by volunteers. The volunteers provide a unique service—one that is appreciated by the families and by the people who go there for palliative care in the last days of their lives.

It is a very sad occasion. There is to be a state funeral. The Prime Minister announced this morning that it will be on Friday at 1 o'clock. I know that all Ipswichians will be marking that occasion with great solemnity. They will be sad and very sorry to mark his passing.

talk.start.para: —I rise on this occasion to mark the passing of former Senator Bonner. I cannot claim to have known him, nor can I claim to have served in this parliament when he served. He was an outstanding Australian and has made an outstanding contribution.

speech.para: Mention has been made of the fact that he was a Liberal senator from Queensland and the first Aboriginal member of either house. I find it ironic that the Labor Party, which unhesitatingly champions the causes of Aboriginals, has yet to have an Aboriginal member of this parliament. That is not to say that there have not been outstanding conservative ministers for Aboriginal affairs. I note that in the new Senate to be formed in July this year, the Democrats will have an Aboriginal senator from my state, New South Wales.

For those like me who did not personally know former Senator Bonner, there was a documentary about his life that screened last year. I must say that, having watched it, you could not but warm to the senator and all that he achieved in his lifetime. I should also say that we have a Chifley reconciliation committee in my electorate, and I have been saddled with the position of secretary. I know I can speak on behalf of all members of that committee in wanting to express our sadness at the passing of former Senator Bonner.

As we come to grapple with reconciliation and what it means for the people of Australia and for this parliament, perhaps we can be inspired by the contribution former Senator Bonner made to all Australians in his lifetime.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr RUDDOCK
talker.role: Immigration and Multicultural Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —I wish to be associated with this condolence motion. I had the great privilege of serving in the parliament with Neville Bonner from the time I was elected—he was elected in 1971 and I was elected in 1973—until he left the parliament in 1983. In that time I regarded Neville Bonner as one of my friends. He was a person whom I came to know well, whom I had in my home and with whom I travelled abroad. He was a member of the parliamentary delegation to Pakistan and India in 1981, which I had the great privilege of leading.

speech.para: He served with me as a member of the Joint Select Committee on Aboriginal Land Rights in the Northern Territory, a committee that I had the opportunity of chairing for a time. Of course, when you travel in committee service you have unique opportunities to know people well, to know their personalities and to pick up some of their foibles in one way or another. You would find few foibles with Neville Bonner. He was a very modest man, a very unassuming man and a person with great personal dignity and pride in his Aboriginality.

It is funny, when you look back. I remember when we were with the delegation to Pakistan we were being ushered to catch an aircraft and, as is often the case, we were being swept off into a VIP room to be appropriately looked after. As we were being ushered through, the officials—the very officious officials—wanted to exclude Neville Bonner from joining us. They made all sorts of assumptions about the nature of a delegation from Australia. I do not think our multicultural character or the proud place that our indigenous people have was well known abroad.

I know that in the context of my own family it was brought home to me that race is something that perhaps sometimes is learned. I can remember somebody asking my youngest daughter, after we had met Neville Bonner in the King's Hall at Old Parliament House, whether she could distinguish him from others. They asked young Caitlin whether she saw anything different in Neville Bonner and she said, `Oh, yes, he's got a stash.' I thought that it said something at least about her mother's training at home.

talk.start.para: —How old was she?

—I think she was about three at the time. With all of that—which, in part, shows the frailty of human nature—Neville Bonner was still a very kind, gracious and understanding person. He contributed very significantly to the development within the coalition of a far broader understanding of Aboriginal issues than I think is sometimes given credit within the coalition. His role was mentioned earlier today, in pushing the early resolutions that were carried in the Senate and later, as I recall, in this place which acknowledged the very special place of our indigenous people.

speech.para: He was not a radical in terms of pushing at the margins, but I think he was nevertheless very proudly ensuring that the very special place of his race—of his people, the indigenous people of Australia—was appropriately recognised in Australia. He was, in a sense, a man before his time and always courageous. Those of us who serve in a party room know what it is to have to stand out sometimes to put a point of view. Neville Bonner was never afraid to do that.

I can remember that he was proud of some of the involvements that he had after politics. One that I remember, in particular, was the leadership role that he was playing in the support of the World Vision organisation. It was a measure of Neville Bonner that not only here within Australia where they undertake important work but internationally he was at the forefront of ensuring that their work was well progressed.

I do not wish to detain the House. I regret very much that because other commitments will keep me in Melbourne on Friday that I will not be able to be at the state funeral for Neville; I would very much have liked to have been there. But I hope, in speaking in this condolence motion and extending to his wife, Heather, and family, my family's personal commiserations, we can be associated with them in this special way and to say of Neville: `Thank you—for a job well done, a life well lived by a courageous man.'

talk.start.para: —I too would like to be associated with this motion, because tonight we pay tribute to a very great man. I first met Neville Bonner in the mid-1960s as a young television reporter. I interviewed him at a time when he had just taken over as the head of the One People for Australia League, OPAL, which I suppose in many respects was the emergence of Neville Bonner into public life. Following that, I interviewed him on several other occasions in terms of his relationship with the Liberal Party and his endorsement for the Senate.

speech.para: But it was not really until I first stood for election in the seat of Bowman in 1974 that the friendship between myself and Neville Bonner really developed. Neville Bonner was a tremendous help. The seat of Bowman in those days had been held by the Labor Party for two or three terms. I think they had a majority in excess of 6,000—it may have been 8,000—and there were very few people who gave us very much hope of winning the seat. As people on both sides of this House will know, when you have not got a marginal seat, the heavies of the party do not necessarily come near you to give you much of a hand, although I must say that in the 1974 election Billy Snedden, Andrew Peacock and Don Chipp made appearances. But one of the great stalwarts along with Sir James Killen in that campaign was Senator Neville Bonner. He worked very hard, and I suppose to a degree the rest is history. We missed out in 1974 by about 600 votes. The seat became very marginal and we campaigned for about 15 months leading up to the 1975 election, with Neville Bonner very much at the fore.

Reference was made this afternoon in this motion to the humour of Neville Bonner. I do not think that that has been emphasised enough. He really did have an incredible sense of humour; his sparkling eyes and that great grin that he had were really very comforting. I will never forget one occasion which he thought was hilarious. At the time I do not know if I was very much impressed. Because it is the House, I will clean up the story but, if you want to read the actual transcript, perhaps you could check it out in Barry Cohen's book.

In those days, around south-east Queensland, the way of campaigning was usually on the back of a truck, with speakers that had been butchered up to give you about a kilometre radius, belting out I don't know how many kilowatts out of each channel and generally deafening the neighbours. It was part of the ritual on Saturdays to go around shopping centres. All the parties were there and it was always a race between the Liberal Party and the Labor Party as to who got the best street corner.

I will never forget at the Big Top, Mount Gravatt, on this particular Saturday morning, we had arrived first and we had set up our truck with the speakers on the back. Len Keogh, who was then the sitting member for Bowman, arrived in the car park and was parked down at the other gate with his speakers ready to go as soon as I was finished. With Neville Bonner as my guest, I got up and made a great and powerful speech and Neville Bonner got up and made a great and powerful speech. There was a gentleman standing over on the wall of this shopping centre and he was getting quite excited about it all. When the speeches were finished, he literally came sprinting across the car park. I thought, `Here is a vote that I have got,' and held out my hand to shake his. I will clean up what he said to me but, loosely translated, it was: Buzz off, you Tory so-and-so. Gidday Neville, how are you? You are a good bloke. I am going to vote for you. Bonner thought this was absolutely hilarious.

Another occasion was at a time when we were all sharing the parliamentary offices at 295 Ann Street. I had employed a young graduate by the name of Greg Goebel as my research officer. More recently, he was the state director of the Liberal Party in Queensland. It was rather good, because all the parties were represented on that floor and there was a great deal of interaction not only between the members but between the staff.

Neville Bonner came around one day and Greg Goebel was making a cup of coffee, and he said to Neville, `Senator, would you like a cup of coffee,' to which Neville replied, `I would love one.' He looked up and said, `Senator, are you white or black?' Greg realised what he said and sort of collapsed through the floor. I think I looked very embarrassed. Neville Bonner rolled around laughing; he thought it was the funniest thing he had ever heard. I guess that was fairly typical of him.

In those days there was a great sense of camaraderie between the Queensland members, and the camaraderie I think really developed in the back room of the airlines when we were waiting to get those dreadful early morning flights to Canberra. The gang was usually Sir James Killen, the then Senator Martin and now member for Moncrieff, me and sometimes John Hodges, who was the member for Petrie. I think that if anybody had the television rights to some of the conversations that went on in the back room of Ansett in those days they would made a fortune because the interaction, particularly between Sir James Killen and Neville Bonner, was really quite legendary and very funny. But it was a great sense of camaraderie, and I think it translated very well to Canberra.

I was very pleased that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs mentioned the strength of Neville Bonner and some of the things he did in the party room. As a young member after the 1975 election, finding my way around this place and really trying to learn how the place worked, I was terribly impressed when the government decided they were going to get rid of a subsidy on funerals for pensioners and Neville Bonner and then Senator Martin, I think, led the fight. Malcolm Fraser as Prime Minister was a fairly impressive sight, and to see Neville Bonner stand up to Malcolm Fraser was really quite magnificent. He was a man of very great strength, and it is true that some of the issues that he took up and led in the party room showed him to have great strength of character.

There have been literally hundreds of column inches written about the history of Neville Bonner, and there have been some magnificent tributes to him on television and radio. I do not want to go into that any further, but can I just say that in a personal sense he was a very great friend. While he did help me out in election campaigns and really did show me the ropes around this place, I think it was probably at the time of the death of my father that Neville Bonner really came home to me as a very true friend.

My late father was a clergyman, and not long before he died he was awarded the Order of the British Empire. I did not know exactly why he had received this, but the citation that he received stated that it was for his contribution to Aboriginal reform and the reform of the penal system in Queensland. My father never spoke much about these things. Neville Bonner came up to me and he knew the whole history. Apparently, my father had been a bit of a firebrand at the Cherbourg Aboriginal settlement—he had never mentioned it to me; my father very rarely spoke about it—and he told the history of what my father had done. He was very comforting, and I really did appreciate that.

In those days, in my early days in the parliament, Neville Bonner was always there to help. He was always there to advise. He was a very good friend. He was a great Australian. He did serve his state with great distinction. He did serve his own people. But, most importantly, he served all of Queensland. I think it is fair to say that Neville Bonner served this country with neither fear nor favour.

talk.start.para: —I wish to associate myself with the motion moved by the Prime Minister. I cannot pretend to have known the late Neville Bonner as well as my colleagues the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs or the member for Fadden, but as a young person growing up in Ipswich I did get to know Neville Bonner and I understood fully the very great respect our local community had for him.

speech.para: He was someone who managed to forge a sense of reconciliation between black and white Australians before it became popular, before it became fashionable. He is someone who today was referred to by the Leader of the Opposition as a person who may have had the hardest upbringing of any person in the parliament.

When I planned to say a few words in this condolence motion I went to some of the obituaries which have been published and which outline the sterling service that Neville Bonner has given to this nation. While I felt I knew a lot about the former senator, I was shocked when I saw that his first home was a shanty built by his grandfather out of kerosene tins on the banks of the Richmond River near Lismore.

I was also surprised to read that Aborigines at that time had to attend segregated schools. It is incredible in 1999 to think that ever in Australia there would have been segregated schools. He achieved only a grade 3 standard, but worked very hard and developed a passion for reading.

In the Second World War Australians of all races sought to make a contribution to their nation. I was shocked to read that former Senator Bonner and his Aboriginal friends sought to enlist in the Australian army but were rejected apparently on the grounds that the European climate would be unsuitable for them.

Despite the fact that life dealt to Neville Bonner very many disadvantages, despite the fact that he came from circumstances which were very difficult, he was a person who rose to greatness, a person who sought to and succeeded in serving his community, in serving his state and in serving his nation, acting as he did so as a focus of unity. I would like to express my condolences to his wife, Heather, and to his family and to place on record my respect for his very many achievements and, indeed, for what he stood for.

talk.start.para: —I will speak only very briefly on this condolence motion, but I am very pleased to have the opportunity to do so. I, like virtually everybody in this parliament at the present time, over the years have heard and learned a great deal about Neville Bonner. I did not know him well. I had the opportunity of meeting him on only three occasions, but each one was memorable. I just wanted to say that Australia is a poorer place for his passing, that the Aboriginal people of Australia and, indeed, all Australians are the richer for having had him in this parliament. Listening to the debate since it started this afternoon, I think there is one theme that runs right through it, and that is the dignity, the warmth and the sense of humour of the man. I would also like to extend my condolences to his family.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable members standing in their places.

subdebateinfo.title: His Majesty King Hussein bin Talal of Jordan

talk.start.para: —It is with sadness that tonight I join in the condolences for the late King Hussein of Jordan. I have been interested in Middle East politics since before I joined this House. Over the years the peace process in the Middle East has been tortuous, to say the least. It would have appeared to all of us who were watching it to be two steps forward and one-and-a-half steps backwards. But in that process in the Middle East—since just after the Second World War and the creation of the state of Israel—there has always been one constant, King Hussein of Jordan, who has worked constantly for peace. He represented the people, and he was the embodiment of the people of Jordan.

speech.para: Jordan was a country that was at the cutting edge of what was happening in the conflict between Israel and her Arab neighbours. It was always seen that the only way the Arab forces could beat Israel was to catch Israel in a pincer movement with Egypt on one side and the Syrians and the Jordanians on the other. In all these conflicts, Jordan was the middle of the sandwich.

Jordan, unlike some of the other countries in the Middle East, was a country that had few natural resources. Indeed its only natural resource is its people. King Hussein was very conscious of that. The winds that blew through Arab politics were winds that often caused Jordan to trim her sails in one direction or another, which often may not have been something that he may have wanted to do because he always had the best interests of his country uppermost in his mind. However, he never forgot the hundreds of thousands of Palestinians who had fled to Jordan during the many wars with Israel and in the face of Israeli aggression.

I was touched, as I am sure we were all touched, to witness his `finest hour' just a few months ago when he was pivotal in getting the Israeli Prime Minister to get down to business and negotiate with the Palestinian leader—Yasser Arafat—to finalise the Wye River accord. He came out of hospital, where he was dying, to add his prestige and to put on the line all his years of negotiation in that area. He achieved what others had not been able to achieve up until that time.

King Hussein is tonight being buried in Amman surrounded by his family—the people of Jordan—who, as we have seen on the television, regarded him as a father. They have lost a father and a person whom they have identified with for most of their lives. There is no greater accolade for a man than it be said that he was an instrument of peace. King Hussein was certainly that. The finalisation of the process of engagement between Israel and all her neighbours will be harder to achieve in his absence. I think the world has lost someone who has added a great deal and I am sure that we all mourn his passing.

talk.start.para: —I also wish to add my condolences in relation to the death of King Hussein. I think it is an index of the man that so many world leaders are going to Jordan for his funeral. This is extraordinary for a small country like Jordan. But, as the member for Watson has said, it is a very important tribute to him and his wonderful—one might say magnificent—role in the Middle East peace process.

speech.para: His role was not one of trying to be up-front and to tout himself in this process. His role was more trying to ensure that whenever difficulties occurred—even when they seemed insurmountable—his country and his own personal prestige were used to keep going, to keep pushing for peace.

Years ago I led a delegation to the Middle East. We went to Jordan. This was at a time when it was not clear whether the peace process would go forward or not. In Jordan we found that there was tremendous activity involving the other nations of the Arab world—especially Egypt, but the other countries as well—in trying to get past a problem that had occurred in terms of the recognition of Mr Arafat and the Palestinian Liberation Organisation. At that time, rather than condemnatory statements from King Hussein, we had statements which suggested that with patience things could be done.

We then went from Jordan to Israel and we met a number of representatives of both parties in Israel—Labor and Likud—and they had a very high opinion of the role of Jordan and what King Hussein had been doing. He persisted and continued with that right through for many years, even until the last days.

It is only a few months ago that we had the agreement that had to be carried out with the presence of President Clinton. But who was there to push it along, to overcome bottlenecks and to try to ensure that the two peoples, the Palestinian people and the Israeli people, could come together in some sort of peace agreement? It was again King Hussein. His role in history, in terms of the Middle East and indeed more broadly, will be recorded as a tremendous one.

I am the Deputy Chairman of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. The chairman is in the Senate. But I am sure that I speak on behalf of all the members of the House and the Senate when I say that we express our condolences to his family and to the people of Jordan on the loss of their much beloved king. We are sure that his spirit will continue in the future with the commitment of his son to the peace process. I am sure that Jordan will continue to play a critical role in that process.

talk.start.para: —Very briefly, I would like to join in the sentiments expressed by the members for Watson and Calwell. Obviously, as he was the Middle East's longest serving leader of 46 years—I think that is how long it was from recollection—it is entirely appropriate that this parliament pays tribute to a man of extraordinary strength and to his endeavours for peace in the Middle East, which really translated to world peace.

speech.para: In finalising these short comments, I think it is also entirely appropriate that this parliament and the members of this parliament pass on to the new King Abdullah our best wishes as well for the trials, tribulations and challenges that lie ahead. He is a young man who until recently, one presumes, was not set on a course of being king. His arrival was a late and a recent one. From what we have seen so far, this young man has proved that he has the stuff that his father had. I know that all members would join me in wishing the new king our very best. He has a difficult path ahead of him but I believe, from what I have seen and heard, that he is a young man who will be able to do that. He certainly has the best wishes of the members of this Australian parliament.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable members standing in their places.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 3 December, on motion by Mr Williams:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I am replying to the second reading speech on the Judiciary Amendment Bill 1998 on behalf of the opposition. The bill reintroduces a bill that was previously before the House before it was prorogued.

speech.para: The position of the opposition is continuing concern with the bill. In particular, my review of the previous debate has firmly formed in my mind the view that the government has failed to sufficiently justify the course of action that it is taking. It is a course of action to, if you like, disarm to a degree one of our armoury of government—that is, the Australian Government Solicitor, which represents the legal interests of the Commonwealth. It is not an insignificant act that the government is taking, and one would think that before it takes that act it would justify the reasons for it.

My reading of the previous speeches has failed to identify any revelation as to where there will be a costs benefit to the Commonwealth or indeed where there will be enhancement or improvement in the quality of legal services provided by the Australian Government Solicitor. Indeed, to the contrary, the indications are that costs will go up and the already respected Australian Government Solicitor will be under considerable pressure. So these things have to be put before us before we are prepared to accept such a significant disarming of the resources available to government.

There was an endeavour to portray our opposition as some sort of a throwback to a previous philosophy on the part of Labor. It is not that at all. It is simply a case of the government failing to justify its actions.

The government will say that its reasons are that it is implementing the recommendations of the Logan committee. The government will also say that this action is necessary because we need to change the employing base of the Australian Government Solicitor; it needs a mechanism to attract top quality lawyers and to pay them commercial rates. This formation of a statutory corporation, as the bill intends to do with the Australian Government Solicitor, is a means of freeing up the AGS—the Australian Government Solicitor—from the regimes of public sector employment.

But if you look at those justifications and at the terms of reference of the Logan committee, you see that they were specifically requested to consider the privatisation of the AGS. Indeed, it is somewhat reassuring when you look at the recommendations because the Logan committee itself, with the terms of reference skewed heavily to privatisation, came back and recommended against privatisation because of `the strong and necessary public interest in maintaining a central legal service for government'.

We are firmly of that view. There is indeed a very solid public interest in maintaining a competent, accessible, professional and objective legal service for government. The Logan committee effectively put forward this option which the government has taken as an alternative to privatisation of the AGS, but it is a gross overstatement to say that the Logan committee actually recommended this particular course of action.

In terms of the other rationale of the government, that is, to free up its ability to negotiate higher salaries and better terms and conditions of employment to retain its existing employees, to prevent them being poached by private firms, the way the government has elected to go is this formation of the statutory corporation. But there were other mechanisms involved, whether it be a schedule to the Public Service provisions dealing with the AGS or other forms of negotiation. There were certainly alternatives to this action that they have taken.

Even the rationale that higher salaries is the be-all and end-all from the point of view of lawyers currently employed by the Australian Government Solicitor is a bit presumptuous. Many whom I know and whom I have dealt with have chosen to go to the AGS because of the wide variety of work that they are able to undertake in moving through the various elements of the office, whether it is advice work to government, litigation work or whatever it might be. That has been a great source of attraction. Indeed, the fact that they are giving a valuable public service is another motivating factor. So to say that these lawyers are motivated purely by money is presumptuous in the extreme.

Assuming that the rationale is correct, that you are going to be in a position to attract more experienced lawyers or to retain experienced lawyers, is that rationale a valid basis for taking the particular action which the government has taken? Again, you have got a fallacy here. There is talk of paying salaries on commercial partner rates, whether it is $250,000, $200,000 or $300,000, to engage someone who has had experience as a partner of a substantial private firm. The fallacy in reasoning is that quite often those partners of those private firms are paid the salaries they are paid not necessarily from any great legal expertise but because of their ability to attract work, to attract clientele, as a result of their commercial contacts or as a result simply of their public relations skills or skills as hosts. While these people might be on substantial salary packages as a result of those qualities or indeed their marketing qualities, those qualities may be quite irrelevant to working with the Australian Government Solicitor. There is obviously a limited clientele that the Australian Government Solicitor can attract—essentially government agencies. So those qualities that are often sought from high income earning partners in private firms may not necessarily be the desirable qualities that enhance the service of the Australian Government Solicitor.

The extent to which the ability to pay these large salaries will enhance the quality of the AGS is questionable, particularly in circumstances where already the solicitors at the AGS are quite free to obtain the advice of experienced council if they have a complex legal issue or if they need to engage council to represent them in court. So the extent to which there is justification in paying these big salaries is questionable.

What have we got? The ability to pay higher salaries, potentially enabling the AGS to attract more experienced lawyers, is one point of questionable benefit to the AGS. What is the downside, as against that one and only possible benefit, as I can see it? The downside is significant. As a result of the imposition of the competitive neutrality principle on the AGS, the government's litigation services have been opened up to commercial tendering.

This competitive neutrality principle has brought about a situation where the government will impose on this new statutory corporation, the AGS, the same taxation regime as applies to private firms, and other costs that are part of the on-costs of those private firms. That is estimated, on my research, to be in the vicinity of $5 million. Also, the government has the ability to impose a dividend equivalent to a private sector profit that otherwise would go to the partners of the private legal firms. That too is in the vicinity of $5 million.

Those costs will be, if you like, artificially imposed on the AGS because those costs are deemed costs that the AGS will face. Those deemed costs become actual costs because they will come out of the AGS budget. In addition to that cost burden, there will be a $20 million to $29 million fee for this transition to the statutory corporation arrangement and the redundancy payments that will be necessary, together with some other restructuring costs. So there is a significant cost involved in the action that the government is taking. Who will be paying for these costs? It will be government departments and agencies that will be paying for these costs. But the government has not seen fit to give any additional allowance or subsidy to the departments to enable them to meet these additional legal costs.

Faced with that scenario, the departments are going to have three options. With regard to the first two, either they could pay more for legal fees by decreasing other areas of activity or they could reduce the services that they obtain from the Australian Government Solicitor. But who benefits from our departments not being able to access appropriate advice when they so require it? Ultimately, any errors that they make are errors that affect Australian people, whether they be individuals or businesses. So if there is reduced ability to access legal services, that is going to have a detrimental effect on the operations of government in general.

The third option they will have will be to engage their own in-house lawyers. This is a scenario that is happening in many private companies now, whether they be BHP or other moderate size companies. They are actually engaging their own in-house lawyers rather than meeting the cost of private practice. Increasingly, the rules differentiating solicitors and barristers are becoming blurred and more flexible, so quite often these in-house lawyers will brief counsel directly, bypassing any firms of solicitors at all. It is quite possible that government departments, faced with the greater cost burden, may take that particular course of action.

Who benefits from that course instead of advice being given to the departments from a central pool—a highly qualified and experienced pool—in matters affecting the government, with an extensive library and extensive corporate knowledge? Who benefits from taking that resource away from departments? Who benefits from the fact that departments will be getting advice from in-house lawyers rather than objective advice from another government instrumentality and an independent source—the Australian Government Solicitor?

The government has not examined the possibility of government departments engaging in-house lawyers as a result of opening up this competition and taking away from the services provided by the Australian Government Solicitor. But that is one scenario that is quite possible and, I would go so far as to say, is quite likely to occur. It is quite astounding indeed that the government has not thought of that potential.

What is going to happen as a result of these increased charges? In many ways the proof of the pie is in the eating, or in what has already happened. In a Senate estimates hearing today, the government admitted that in September last year the AGS increased its fees by five per cent, partly in anticipation of this corporatised structure and the imposition of the competitive neutrality principle. The government was unable to provide an undertaking that the fees would not further increase as this system was implemented. So it is quite false to suggest that this competition—and I will address the fallacy of competition shortly—is going to decrease fees. In fact the evidence is—and the facts speak for themselves—that fees charged by the AGS have already gone up in anticipation. Commonsense suggests that they will go up further when these actual artificial burdens are imposed on the AGS.

What has happened to this supposed competition that is going to be generated by what the government has done? The first thing to note is that the baseline of the competitors has already been increased by five per cent and is likely to go higher. Who benefits from that?
