subdebateinfo.title: World Conference on Higher Education: Australian Participation
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 45)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 11 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Was the conference of Arab universities held in Beirut from 2 to 5 March 1998 the last in a series of regional meetings to prepare the groundwork for the World Conference on Higher Education on the theme "Higher Education in the Twenty-First Century" which was to be held in Paris in October 1998.
(2) When and where have the regional conferences been held since the conference which was held in Tokyo from 8 to 10 July 1997.
(3) Did Australia participate in any regional conferences other than the Tokyo conference.
(4) Who represented Australia at the world conference in Paris.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Education, Training and Youth Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Arab Regional Conference on Higher Education held in Beirut from 2—5 March 1998 was the final regional conference of five which were intended as a preparation for the World Conference on Higher Education, Higher Education in the 21st Century: Vision and Action, held in Paris from 5—9 October 1998.

(2) There were two regional conferences after the Asia—Pacific Regional Conference held in Tokyo from 8—10 July 1997. The first was the Regional Conference on Higher Education in Europe held in Palermo, Italy, from 24—27 September 1997. The second was the Arab Regional Conference in Beirut.

(3) There was no official Australian representation at any regional conference apart from the Tokyo conference. However, it is possible individual Australians attended these conferences independently.
(4) The official Delegation representing Australia at the World Conference on Higher Education in Paris from 5—9 October 1998 was as follows:
. Ms Jennifer Ledgar, Assistant Secretary, National Office of Skills Recognition, Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Canberra—Head of Delegation
. Ms Shelagh Whittleston, Education Counsellor, Australian Embassy, Paris—Deputy Head of Delegation
. Professor David Robinson, Vice-Chancellor, Monash University
. Professor Lachlan Chipman, Vice-Chancellor, University of Central Queensland
. Professor Zbys Klich, Pro-Vice-Chancellor, Southern Cross University
. Professor Chris Duke, Deputy Vice-Chancellor, University of Western Sydney, Nepean
. Dr Marion Myhill, University of Tasmania representing the Australian Federation of University Women
. Mr Peter Shannon, Permanent Delegate of Australia to UNESCO, Paris
. Ms Anne Siwicki, Attache, Australian Permanent Delegation to UNESCO, Paris

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 11 November 1998:

question.para: (1) For each Australian university, what proportion of students is drawn from the bottom 25 per cent of suburbs or towns, as measured by socioeconomic status.
(2) What data other than that referred to in part (1) does his Department record for measuring the equity performance of universities and what are the details.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Education, Training and Youth Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Students from socio-economically disadvantaged backgrounds are defined as those whose postcodes of home location fall within the lowest 25 per cent of a given catchment region (that is, Australia, State/Territory and major urban areas within each State) determined by the Australian Bureau of Statistics Index of Education and Occupation.
The following table shows the proportion of students at each university who come from:
. the lowest 25 per cent of postcodes in major urban areas within the relevant State or Territory;
. the lowest 25 per cent of postcodes in the relevant State or Territory; and
. the lowest 25 per cent of postcodes in Australia.

entry.para: James Cook University of North Queensland

answer.para: (2) Other than the data referred to in part (1), the Department collects the following information:
. access, participation, success and retention rates for students from low socio-economic status backgrounds. Information is collected for students aged under 25 and aged 25 or more;

. access, participation, success and retention rates for Indigenous people, women in non-traditional fields of study or in higher degree courses, people from non-English speaking backgrounds, people with disabilities, people from rural areas and people from isolated areas.
Access is measured as a proportion of the numbers of commencing students from the equity target group to the numbers of students in the commencing student population as a whole.

Participation is measured as the ratio of the percentage of each equity target group's total enrolment to the equity target group's percentage of the 15 to 64 year old population. This measure applies to all equity target groups except for:
. participation of women in non-traditional fields of study which is measured as a percentage of total enrolments;

. participation of women in higher degree research and coursework programmes which is measured as the ratio of the percentage of women in higher degree research and coursework programmes to the percentage of women in undergraduate programmes; and

. participation of students from low SES backgrounds which is measured as a ratio of the number of students from low SES backgrounds to the number of students from high SES backgrounds (for these purposes the general population is considered to consist of 25 per cent high SES, 50 per cent medium SES and 25 per cent low SES).

Success is defined as student progress rate, that is, the proportion of load passed within a year compared with the total certified load for that year. It is measured as the ratio of the student progress rate for each equity group to the student progress rate for all other students.

Retention is defined as the number of students who re-enrol at an institution in a given year, as a proportion of the students who were enrolled in the previous year, less those who completed their course. It does not count as retained those students who defer or transfer successfully to another university, and is therefore a measure of apparent, rather than actual retention. It is measured as the ratio of each equity group's apparent retention rate to the apparent retention rate for all other students.
The attached tables provide the information requested.

para.inline: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER STUDENTS 1997 BY ACCESS, PARTICIPATION, SUCCESS (1996) AND RETENTION*

entry.para: James Cook University of North Queensland
Reference Values (proportion of equity group in population

answer.para: * Access is the proportion of commencing students belonging to the equity group.
Participation is the proportion of equity group members in the student population relative to the representation of the group in the relevant State or Territory population.
Success is the proportion of units passed by members of the equity group compared with the proportion passed by other students.
Retention is the proportion of equity group students retained from one year to the next compared with the proportion of other students retained.
The reference value for participation, success and retention is 1.

** Batchelor College is not included in the national figures as it is an Indigenous institution with Indigenous students only, and therefore has no comparative data. If Batchelor College figures were added to the other statistical data, the national averages would be: Access—1.7 per cent; Participation—0.73; Success—0.79; Retention—0.78.

** No figure is available.

entry.para: James Cook University of North Queensland

answer.para: * Figures show female enrolments as a percentage of total enrolments in each field of study. A blank denotes that the area of study is not offered at that university.

para.inline: WOMEN IN HIGHER DEGREE RESEARCH AND COURSEWORK RELATIVE TO UNDERGRADUATE ENROLMENT, BY INSTITUTION, 1997*

entry.para: James Cook University of North Queensland

answer.para: * The participation of women in higher degree research and coursework programmes is measured as the ratio of the percentage of women in higher degree research and coursework programmes to the percentage of women in undergraduate programmes.

para.inline: STUDENTS WITH A DISABILITY 1997 BY ACCESS, PARTICIPATION, SUCCESS(1996) AND RETENTION*

entry.para: James Cook University of North Queensland

answer.para: * Access is the proportion of commencing students belonging to the equity group.
Participation is the proportion of equity group members in the student population relative to the representation of the group in the relevant State or Territory population.
Success is the proportion of units passed by members of the equity group compared with the proportion passed by other students.
Retention is the proportion of equity group students retained from one year to the next compared with the proportion of other students retained.
The reference value for participation, success and retention is 1.

For the purposes of this table, people with a disability were defined as those who answered in the affirmative the question, "Do you have a disability, impairment or long-term medical condition which may affect your studies?" on student enrolment forms. The reference value for access is 4 per cent. The reference value for participation, success and retention is 1.
A blank denotes that figures were not supplied by the institution.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, upon notice, on 11 November 1998:

question.para: Has the Government entered negotiations with the Ford Motor Company concerning the establishment of four-wheel drive manufacturing in Melbourne; if so, what are the details.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: The Government has not entered negotiations with the Ford Motor Company concerning the establishment of four-wheel drive manufacturing in Melbourne. In the normal course of contact with the industry, the Government has received advice and representations both from Ford and other motor vehicle assemblers about the possible impact of

current and future policy instruments on vehicle manufacturing in Australia. The Government would welcome any new developments in vehicle manufacturing in Australia and will consider the views of any company proposing such developments.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation, upon notice, on 11 November 1998 :

question.para: Did he attend (a) the recent Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA) awards in Sydney or (b) an event associated with the recent Pacific Circle Music Convention in Sydney; if not, (i) did the Minister send a representative, (ii) why did the Minister not attend and (iii) did the Minister receive an invitation to attend.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Arts and the Centenary of Federation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a) Neither I nor a representative attended the Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA) awards nor the Pacific Circle Music Convention.
(B) Neither I, nor any of my staff, received an invitation to either the ARIA Awards nor the Pacific Circle Music Convention.

(i)—(iii) The Pacific Circle Music Convention took place on 15—18 October 1998 before the Prime Minister had announced portfolio responsibilities on 18 October 1998. The ARIA Awards ceremony took place on 20 October 1998. This was the day prior to which I was sworn in by the Governor General.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 November 1998:

question.para: (1) How many applications for the Australian Active Service Medal 1945-75 had been received at (a) 31 December 1997, (b) 31 March 1998, (c) 30 June 1998 and (d) 30 September 1998.
(2) How many veterans had (a) been granted and (b) received the medal at (i) 31 December 1997, (ii) 31 March 1998, (iii) 30 June 1998 and (iv) 30 September 1998.
(3) How many medals have been awarded for each war or conflict to the date of answering this question.
(4) What is the average time taken to finalise an application.

(5) When the medal was announced in September 1997, did his Department purchase sufficient medals to satisfy the number of eligible applicants; if not, (a) when were further medals ordered and (b) at what cost.

(6) How many (a) civilian and (b) military staff were involved in processing medal applications by serving and former Defence personnel at (i) 31 December 1995, (ii) 31 December 1996 and (iii) 31 December 1997.
(7) Is there a delay in processing applications for medals; if so, what action will be taken to address the delays.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Veterans' Affairs; Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Accurate numbers of applications specifically for the Australian Active Service Medal 1945-75 have not been recorded, as many applicants request a number of medals on their application and others do not specify a medal on their application. However, an estimate of the number of applications for the Australian Active Service Medal 1945-75 received is:
(3) As at 12 November 1998, the following medals have been issued to veterans:
(a) Korean War—3303, (b)Malayan Emergency—1965, (c)Indonesian Confrontation—2965, and (d)Vietnam War—18097.

(4) It is not possible to establish an average time for an application. Many applications involve the award of more than one medal, which are placed on separate schedules for the Governor-General's approval. The completed schedules are presented to the Governor-General for approval at different times. This time varies according to the number of applications received for a particular medal. Other applications are a mix of Imperial Honours System medals, which do not require the approval of the Governor-General, and Australian Honours System medals which do require approval. Most records are contained in paper form requiring lengthy manual searches, while records for Army personnel who have served since mid-1980s are contained on a computer data base.
(5) Government House is responsible for the procurement of medals which are issued to Defence as they are approved for issue to applicants.
(6) (a) and (b) (i) 27 civilian, 1 military, (ii) 29 civilian, 1 military, and (iii) 30 civilian, 1 military.

(7) Yes. All processes involved in issuing medals have been reviewed and streamlined as far as possible. Staff of the Medals Sections are working overtime to satisfy the demand. In addition, one temporary staff is employed in the Medals Section Navy and four temporary staff are employed in the Medals Section Army. I have asked Defence for additional options to meet the extra workload in processing the large number of new applications.

At this time, payments for 1998 to individual schools are only known for non-systemic, non-government schools of which there are three in the total schools listed. Inclusion of the 1998 payment figures for these schools would misrepresent the funding situation and therefore have not been included.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 23 November 1998:

question.para: (1) How many staff were employed at the (a) Preston and (b) Northcote offices of the Department of Social Security on 2 March 1996.

(2) How many staff were employed at the (a) Preston and (b) Northcote offices of the Department of Social Security (i) immediately before and (ii) following the restructuring of the offices into the Centrelink network.
(3) How many staff were employed at the Preston office of Centrelink on 6 November 1998.
(4) What changes to staffing numbers at the Preston Office of Centrelink will occur as a result of the Centrelink staffing announcement on 9 November 1998.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) On 2 March 1996 the Preston Office had 71 staff and the Northcote Office had 44 staff.

(2) The Preston and Northcote Offices were amalgamated in November 1996 to create the Darebin Office. In April 1997, before the Centrelink network, the Darebin Office had 108 staff and after the Centrelink network was created, in May 1997, Centrelink Darebin had 125 staff.
(3) On 6 November 1998 Centrelink Darebin had 116 staff.

(4) None immediately, but on current finding estimates it may be necessary to reduce staffing levels by up to eight immediately prior to or just after the commencement of the 1999-2000 financial year.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 23 November 1998:

question.para: (1) When did the (a) Government and (b) Federal Office of Road Safety become aware that (i) many Hyundai Excels in Australia have a fault in the forward right-side wheel assembly which potentially threatens safety and (ii) Hyundai Excels with the same fault were recalled in the USA in 1996 because they were considered a safety risk.
(2) What action did the (a) Government and (b) Federal Office of Road Safety take after learning of the fault's existence to ensure that the safety of Australian road users was protected.
(3) What mechanisms does the Government employ to ensure that information about faults in vehicles detected in other countries is immediately available to relevant Australian authorities.
(4) Did the Government order an immediate recall of Hyundai Excels upon learning of the fault's existence and the previous action of the US Government; if not, why not.
(5) Did he or a Government representative ask Hyundai why they did not act on the matter as soon as the cars had been recalled in the USA; if so, (a) when and (b) what was the response.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) and (2) I am advised by the Federal Office of Road Safety (FORS) that a facsimile was received on 26 August 1998 regarding three Hyundai Excel vehicles that had an alleged problem with the front right hand sub-assembly that attaches the lower control arm to the vehicle. The Royal Automobile Club of Queensland provided this advice through the Australian Automobile Association (AAA).
FORS was advised by Hyundai of the recall in Puerto Rico on 20 October 1998.

The information provided by the AAA was forwarded to Hyundai Automotive Distributors Australia on the same day it was received, 26 August 1998, asking the company to investigate and advise any proposed rectification action. FORS contacted the Office of Defects Investigation at the US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) by electronic mail asking whether the vehicle was marketed in the USA and whether they had any reports of the failure of the spot welds at the front lower control arm mountings. FORS received no response to this first request and this was repeated on 22 September 1998. On 20 October 1998, a FORS officer on other business in Korea met with Hyundai officials in Seoul to discuss the issue. Hyundai provided a presentation that indicated that the front sub-assembly could not fail suddenly. The problem manifests itself gradually and results in progressively heavier steering and excessive front tyre wear. Audible warnings are evident prior to failure. FORS was subsequently able to contact NHTSA by telephone and was advised that a recall was conducted on the Hyundai Accent (the US model name) in Puerto Rico. The vehicle was not subject to a recall in mainland USA.

(3) FORS has in place a recall information exchange program with its counterparts in Japan, United Kingdom, Canada and the USA. Because marketing names can be different in various countries, it can be difficult to ascertain whether any particular model is involved.
(4) Discussions with NHTSA in the US indicated that the vehicle was recalled only in Puerto Rico because the abnormal road and driving conditions there contributed to the problem.

NHTSA conducted investigations between November 1996 and October 1997 to determine whether the recall should be extended to mainland USA. The investigations included NHTSA personnel driving vehicles with the problem which were deemed to be controllable. NHTSA cited "a lack of a reasonable safety risk" for the closure of the investigation.

(5) Discussions between FORS and Hyundai focused on resolving whether there was an inherent problem with Excels sold in Australia and how this might be resolved in the interests of owners and other road users. The experience in Puerto Rico was discussed at the meeting on 12 November 1998. On 18 November 1998, FORS advised that it agreed with Hyundai's proposal to conduct a field service campaign to rectify all 46,000 vehicles.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

question.para: Is the Government aware of any independent studies which have been undertaken on the viability of the Long Term Operating Plan targets regarding flight paths over various areas of Sydney; if so, (a) what independent studies and (b) what did the studies reveal about the viability of the targets.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: No.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

question.para: How many suburbs north of the Parramatta River suffer from aircraft noise above 70 decibels per noise event from aircraft flying to or from Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: It is estimated that many suburbs north of the Parramatta River experience single aircraft noise events associated with Sydney Airport above 70 dB(A) at some time. The most impacted suburbs are those lying under the flight paths for take-offs to the north-west off the main north-south runway and landings from the north on the parallel runways.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice on 24 November 1998:

question.para: Further to the answer to question No. 3048 (Hansard, 15 July 1998, page 6225) noting the Government's receipt of formal advice on 25 May 1998 of a complaint to the International Labour Organisation by the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions, is it a fact that the complaint was lodged on 7 May 1998 and the Government received notice foreshadowing the complaint; if so, when did the Government receive notice.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

answer.para: The complaint to the International Labour Organisation was lodged by the International Confederation of Trade Unions on 7 May 1998. The Government obtained a copy of the complaint from the International Labour Office through the Australian Permanent Mission to the United Nations in Geneva on 8 May 1998 after being alerted by an article in the press. The Government received formal notice of the complaint on 25 May 1998 in a communication from the International Labour Office dated 12 May 1998.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

question.para: Will the Government amend the Workplace Relations Act to reduce, diminish or restrict the remedy available to apprentices under the Act in respect of dismissal in harsh, unjust or unconscionable circumstances; if so, how.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Workplace Relations Amendment (Unfair Dismissals) Bill 1998 currently before the Parliament would exclude both employees with less than six months' continuous service and those who are employed by a business with 15 or fewer employees from the unfair dismissal laws. However, apprentices and trainees would not be affected by those amendments.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Are directors of community employment services which have been awarded employment placement contracts by the Government personally liable if the services become insolvent.
(2) Will the Government guarantee debts incurred by those services to ensure that their directors are not personally liable for the debts.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The structure of an organisation determines whether or not directors can be held personally liable if their organisation becomes insolvent. This is a matter upon which each organisation should obtain their own legal advice. However I am advised that if the organisation is incorporated under the Corporations law, directors can be held personally liable. This occurs where the organisation involves itself in insolvent trading and the director/s allow the corporation to incur a debt even though there are reasonable grounds to believe the corporation is insolvent or the debt will render it insolvent.

Those organisations which are incorporated under the various State/Territory incorporated associations legislation may find the liability provisions different as that legislation seeks to limit the liability of organisations and office holders.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

question.para: Further to the answer to question No. 2622 (Hansard, 2 April 1998, page 2488), what issues or points of disagreement precluded the arrival at a consensus on the proposed joint venture between the Hurstville Council and the Australian Taxation Office to establish a childcare centre.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: On 29 May 1995, the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) wrote to Hurstville Council confirming it would commit to a 2 1 year agreement regarding the finding of the 20 child care places for ATO staff. These places would join the 40 places approved in 1991 for Hurstville Council under the 1988 National Child Care Strategy (NCCS).

The Commonwealth Government's decision in August 1996 to remove operational subsidy for long day care centres reopened negotiations between Council and the ATO with Council seeking reassurances from the ATO on the previously agreed funding arrangements. Under these arrangements, the ATO had committed to a payment for 20 places which matched the Commonwealth's operational subsidy.

On 23 April 1 997, the ATO wrote to Hurstville Council advising that they would be prepared to enter into a contract for a ten year term, with two five year options, and that they were unable to commit to a payment which matched the Commonwealth's operational subsidy as that would cease on I July 1997.
Council advised the ATO that 21 year period of agreement was not negotiable and continued to seek recurrent finding from the ATO for its 20 child care places.
On 29 January 1998 the ATO withdrew from further negotiations due the reluctance of Council to accept the ATO's position and the changed government policy.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

question.para: Further to the answer to question No. 3084 (Hansard , 15 July 1998, page 6270), has a program for shipment of spent nuclear fuel from the operation of the HIFAR reactor at Lucas Heights, NSW, been developed; if so, under the program (a) how many rods will be transported, (b) how many shipments are contemplated, (c) what are the proposed dates of the shipments, (d) what will each shipment cost and (e) what is the destination of each shipment.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: Spent fuel rods currently stored at ANSTO are of either US or UK origin. ANSTO's program for the management of spent nuclear fuel is based on the repatriation of US-origin fuel rods and the reprocessing of UK-origin fuel rods.

(a) ANSTO currently holds 449 HIFAR spent fuel elements of US origin which will be repatriated. It is anticipated that around 1300 HIFAR spent fuel rods of UK origin will also be shipped overseas for reprocessing. The precise number of fuel rods cannot be determined until the closure date for HIFAR is known.
(b) It is anticipated that there will be two shipments to the United States and four shipments to a commercial nuclear fuel reprocessor.
(c) The dates for individual shipments have yet to be determined, but the program is likely to commence around the end of 1999 and run for about eight years.
(d) Costs of individual shipments cannot be determined at this stage.
(e) US origin fuel will be shipped to Savannah River, South Carolina. The destination of the UK-origin spent fuel will be determined when a commercial reprocessor is engaged in the near future.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Has the new Defence Long Service Medal been gazetted; if so, when; if not, why not.
(2) How many (a) members of the full-time forces, (b) officers in the reserve forces and (c) members of the reserve forces are estimated to meet the eligibility requirements of the medal.
(3) How many serving members will be ineligible for the medal because they have received the (a) Defence Force Service Medal, (b) Reserve Force Decoration or (c) Reserve Force Medal.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Veterans' Affairs; Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. In the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette No. S 352 of 10 July 1998.

(2) and (3) Without a complete review of all Service records, it is not possible to assess how many personnel will be eligible for the Defence Long Service Medal, or how many will not qualify because they hold a Defence Force Service Medal, Reserve Force Decoration or a Reserve Force Medal.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment Services, upon notice, on 25 November 1998:

question.para: (1) How many training providers (a) were granted and (b) still retain a contract under the mutual obligation agreement.
(2) How many persons nationally have been referred to services provided under the mutual obligation agreement.
(3) How many training places have been allocated nationally under the mutual obligation agreement.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) There were three training programs specifically contracted under Mutual Obligation, that is Literacy and Numeracy, Career Counselling and Job Placement, Employment and Training (JPET). There are 68 providers contracted for Literacy and Numeracy; 101 contracted for JPET and one national provider for Career Counselling.
(b) These programs are administered by the Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs and I am advised by that Department that all 170 providers retain their contracts.

(2) Young unemployed people can satisfy their Mutual Obligation by participating in a wide range of work, education or training related activities. Centrelink data show that at 27 November 1998, 11,649 had commenced one of these activities.

(3) The Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs has confirmed that 11,474 training places in Literacy and Numeracy, 8,792 in Career Counselling and 2,200 in Job Placement, Employment and Training have been contracted in 1998-99. In addition, a proportion of job seekers will choose other education and training options, funded under the normal arrangements for the provision of post-secondary education, as a means of satisfying their Mutual Obligation.

subdebateinfo.title: Members of Commonwealth Parliament: Superannuation Scheme
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 217)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 30 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a report in the Sydney Morning Herald of 7 October 1998 stating that he would review the federal politicians' superannuation scheme.

(2) Will the Government review the superannuation scheme for members of the Commonwealth Parliament; if so, (a) when will the review commence, (b) which body will conduct it, (c) which aspects of the scheme will be reviewed and (d) when will the report be delivered.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I am aware of the report.
(2) (a) to (d) The Government has not decided at this time on any review of the Parliamentary Superannuation Scheme.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 30 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Does the Army keep accurate records of travel by Army personnel on civilian commercial flights at Commonwealth expense.
(2) How are bookings on civilian commercial flights made for Army personnel travelling on official business.
(3) If a centralised booking system is used, are preferences shown towards particular carriers.
(4) Does the Army negotiate with various carriers for the least expensive service when approving travel on official business for Army personnel.

(5) How many journeys did Army personnel travelling on official business make from (a) Canberra to Newcastle and (b) Newcastle to Canberra (i) in total, (ii) by direct route and (iii) through Sydney, (A) in 1995-96, (B) in 1996-97, (C) in 1997-98 and (D) from 1 July to 31 October 1998.

(6) What was the (a) arrival time in and (b) departure time from Sydney for each flight by Army personnel travelling on official business from (i) Canberra to Newcastle and (ii) Newcastle to Canberra (A) in 1995-96, (B) in 1996-97, (C) in 1997-98 and (D) from 1 July to 31 October 1998.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) Bookings for Army personnel travelling on official business on civilian commercial flights are made through the Defence Travel Service with QANTAS Airways Limited.
(3) QANTAS Airways Limited is contracted to provide Defence with a comprehensive domestic and international travel agency service including a centralised booking service.

QANTAS guarantees to provide the Best Fare Available At The Time Of Booking, which is sourced from all discounted/advanced purchase fares available from the domestic and regional carriers and, where applicable, less the commercial-in-confidence discounts and rebates in the contract. The Best Fare is sourced having regard to the class of travel specified by Defence, the itinerary and flexibility required, the fare price and the attached conditions, and their suitability given the traveller's requirements.
Where QANTAS and/or its affiliates are competitive in price, schedule, route and seat availability, Defence is contracted to travel on the QANTAS Group carrier.

(5) and (6) Information in respect to the matters referred to in parts 5 and 6 of the honourable member's question is not readily available. To provide a complete response would require considerable time and resources and in the interest of efficient utilisation of departmental resources, I am not prepared to authorise the time and effort involved in obtaining the information.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 2 December 1998:

question.para: On the most recent data how many Child Support Agency clients reside within the postcode areas of (a) 2205, (b) 2207, (c) 2216, (d) 2217, (e) 2218, (f) 2219, (g) 2220, (h) 2221, (i) 2222 and (j) 2223.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: As at 8 December 1998—

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 2 December 1998:

question.para: (1) On the most recent data, how many recipients of (a) Job Search Allowance, (b) Newstart Allowance, (c) Mature Age Allowance, (d) age pension (e) wife pension, (f) disability support pension, (g) carer pension, (h) youth training allowance, (i) sole parent pension, (j) widow allowance, (k) partner allowance and (l) rent assistance reside within the postcode areas of (i) 2205, (ii) 2207, (iii) 2216, (iv) 2217, (v) 2218, (vi) 2219, (vii) 2220, (viii) 2221, (ix) 2222 and (x) 2223.
(2) How many of the persons referred to in part (1)(1) were either on (a) disability support pension or (b) carer pension within each postcode area referred to.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) There have been some changes in payments over the recent years:
• Job Search Allowance has been incorporated into Newstart Allowance since September 1996;
• Youth Allowance is a new payment and replaces a number of existing payments including Youth Training Allowance from July 1998;
• Sole Parent Pension has been replaced by Parenting Payment Single from March 1998; and
• Mature Age Allowance figures are listed separately as Newstart Mature Age Allowance and Mature Age Allowance. The true population is the sum of both payments.
The number of recipients in the requested postcode areas are:
The above numbers are at November 6 1998
The above numbers are at December 4 1998
The above numbers are at November 20
(2) The number of recipients of Rent Assistance in receipt of Carer and Disability Support Pensions in the requested postcode areas are:
The above numbers are at Nov 20 1998

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 8 December 1998:

question.para: (1) How many persons did the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) employ on a casual basis during the 1998 federal general election.

(2) How many persons referred to in part (1) were (a) already employed, (b) receiving Newstart or another welfare payment or (c) registered with Employment National or another job agency in the Job Network when they were offered work by the AEC.

(3) Did the AEC follow a specific strategy during the 1998 federal general election campaign to offer job opportunities and provide appropriate skills training to the unemployed, especially the long-term unemployed.

talk.start.para: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The AEC employed 64584 people on a casual basis during the 1998 federal general election.

(2) (a) The AEC is unable to provide figures on how many of the above persons were already employed. (b) The AEC does not request information on the receipt of Newstart or another welfare payment by such persons at the time of employment. (c) The AEC does not retain records on the number of persons employed on a casual basis who were registered with Employment National or another job agency in the Job Network.

(3) The AEC did not follow a specific strategy to employ unemployed people during the 1998 federal general election. The AEC advertises regularly for people to register for temporary work and selects suitable people from that list according to staffing requirements. Employment agencies are approached to refer staff if there are no suitable people available from the AEC employment registers.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, upon notice, on 9 December 1998:

question.para: Has the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee (GMAC) discussed projects involving any of the organisations or institutions identified in the answer to part (3) of question 3110 (Hansard , 15 July 1998, page 6277); if so, (a) which GMAC members are or were employed by those organisations, institutions or companies, (b) did those GMAC members attend the meetings at which the discussions took place, (c) did the GMAC members step aside from the meetings and (d) when did the meetings take place.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: Yes, GMAC has discussed projects involving CSIRO, the University of Adelaide and the University of Melbourne at its meetings.

(a) Past and current GMAC members who are or were employed by organisations identified in the answer to part (3) of question 3110: Professor Randall Albury, Professor Angela Delves, Professor Ashley Dunn, Dr Wayne Gerlach, Professor Peter Hudson, Professor Staffan Kjelleberg, Professor Byron Lamont, Professor Peter Langridge, Dr John Manners, Professor Kevin Marshall, Mr David Martin, Professor Nancy Millis, Dr John Oakeshott, Professor Jim Pittard, Ms Rosemary Robins, Dr Margaret Roper, Associate Professor Richard Roush, Associate Professor Loane Skene, Dr Jan Tennent, Dr Robyn van Heeswijck, Dr John Watson, Dr Maxwell Whitten, and Professor Harold Woolhouse.
(b) Yes, GMAC members employed by the above organisations have attended meetings at which projects involving their organisations were discussed.

(c) GMAC members stand aside from Committee discussions only if there is a direct conflict of interest in a proposal. Such occasions occurred on 5 June 1991, when Dr Gerlach stepped aside from a GMAC meeting while his project was discussed, and on 17 November 1998 when Dr Oakeshott stepped aside for the same reason.

(d) Meetings at which projects from CSIRO, the University of Adelaide or the University of Melbourne were discussed took place on 13 February, 16 March, 18 June and 17 December 1990; 5 June 1991; 2 July and 29-30 July 1992; 30 June, 29 July and 25 November 1993; 3 March, 24 March, 23 June, 14 July, 3 November and 24 November 1994; 10 March, 2 June, 4 August, 1 September and 24 November 1995; 2 February, 23 February, 7 May, 31 May, 9 August, 10 September, 25 October and 22 November 1996; 7 February, 7 March, 14 May, 30 May, 1 August, 29 August, 30 October and 28 November 1997; 30 January, 27 February, 17 April, 15 May, 26 June, 11 August, 4 September, 16 October and 17 November 1998.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Forestry and Conservation upon notice, on 10 December 1998:

question.para: (1) What sum did the Commonwealth provide to the States under the Forest Industry Structural Adjustment Program (FISAP) in (a) 1995-96, (b) 1996-97 and (c) 1997-98.
(2) What estimated sum will the Commonwealth provide to the States under FISAP in (a) 1998-99 and (b) 1999-2000.
(3) What sum has the Commonwealth provided under FISAP to (a) New South Wales, (b) Victoria and (c) other States to the date of answering this question.
(4) What matching funds did each State referred to in part (3) provide.
(5) Who is eligible to receive FISAP funding and for what purposes may it be used.
(6) Has the Government reduced the total sum allocated over 5 years to FISAP; if so, why.
(7) Will Commonwealth FISAP funding to New South Wales be suspended; if so, what will be the impact on timber companies in New South Wales.

talker.name: Tuckey, Wilson, MP
Mr Tuckey
talker.role: Forestry and Conservation; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (4) New South Wales has provided $15,427,540 to date. Other States have not provided matching funding to date.
Note that the answers to parts (1) to (4) include payments made by the Commonwealth to State Governments and payments made by the Commonwealth directly to individuals or businesses in those States.
(5) There are four categories of FISAP funding. Eligible recipients for each category and the purposes for which the funding may be used are as follows:

Business Exit Assistance is available to native forest businesses which have been directly and adversely affected by Deferred Forest Assessment (DFA), Interim Forest Assessments (IFA) or Regional Forest Agreements (RFA) processes. An independent assessor is engaged to calculate the estimated future maintainable earnings of the business, less the net realisable tangible assets plus extraordinary expenses incurred in closing the business. There is no restriction on how the money may be spent, apart from a requirement that the recipient not re-enter the native forest industry for at least three years.

Worker Assistance is available for workers, including the self-employed, who have been displaced from the native forest industry as a result of DFAs or RFAs. Assistance includes financial support for training, assistance with relocation expenses and assistance with fares when searching for new jobs. In addition, New South Wales pays Special Redundancy payments to eligible workers. A wage subsidy is also available for employees who employ displaced forest workers.

Industry Development Assistance is available to businesses currently engaged in the native forest sector of the timber industry or new business proposing developments in the native forest sector of the timber industry that have the capacity to improve the long term sustainable economic activity of the industry.

The assistance consists of interest rate subsidies on the purchase or lease of value-adding equipment or other investments. The New South Wales Government also provides capital grants to eligible businesses.
Rescheduling Assistance has three elements:

(i) State forest agencies may receive assistance with the planning and development of new roadworks which are required to facilitate access to coupes which have been rescheduled due to the development of DFAs, IFAs or RFAs.

(ii) Native forest industry businesses which can demonstrate adverse financial impacts as a direct result of the outcomes of the RFA processes (including DFA and IFA processes) either through incurring additional transport or other costs in obtaining wood supplies from coupes beyond their normal economic transport distance or as a result of abnormal changes to the composition of log supplies due to rescheduling of logging operations, may receive reasonable assistance to compensate them for the additional costs.

(iii) Private landowners engaged in the business of forestry may receive assistance if logging operations on their land have been substantially modified or prevented because the land has been identified in the DFA or IFA processes as possibly being required for a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system.

(6) The allocation to FISAP was reduced in July 1996 from $107 million to $101 million including running costs. This decision was made in the context of the 1996-97 Budget and the need to reduce Government expenditure.

(7) I wrote to the New South Wales Minister for Forestry, Mr Yeadon, on 25 November 1998 advising that Commonwealth FISAP funding for New South Wales was suspended. This followed the unilateral announcement by the New South Wales Government of "forest agreements" for the Eden and North Coast regions contrary to the agreed RFA processes, the unilateral release by New South Wales of new FISAP guidelines contrary to the spirit of co-operation on which the joint FISAP is based, and the failure by New South Wales to agree to a response to the inquiry into allegations of corruption in the administration of FISAP in New South Wales.
The impact on timber companies in NSW will depend on how soon these issues can be resolved and to that end I will be arranging discussions with the NSW Government.
